29 CONTINUING CONTINUING AND EFFECTIVENESS The Court's audits serve as a direct source of information for decision-makers in the institutions concerned in the European context, primarily the Commission, Parliament, the Council and the Member States.
On the basis of this information, they may take action, with or without reference to the Court's audit conclusions.
Although the Court's audit activities have their main impact on the reports and opinions published, they have already had some effect throughout the course of the audit.
The replies from the audited body, in particular the Commission, will be 29 together. Examples of the impact of the Court's work are the measures taken by the Commission in response to the 2007 discharge resolution (and the impact of which was mainly taken in 2009): in the area of agricultural expenditure, the management and control system for expenditure under the newly created European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) has been aligned with the EAGF guarantee system, so that the largely recognised benefits of this system will also apply to EAFRD expenditure (see point 5.54 of the Annual Report for the financial year 2004 and point 5.57 of the 2007 Annual Report).
In the area of cohesion, the Commission continues to work on a revision of the rules applicable for 2007-2013 to simplify the system for reporting irregularities, and has committed itself to prepare, at the beginning of 2010, a report on the actions carried out in 2009 and the initial impact of all the actions of its Action Plan to strengthen the Commission's supervisory role in the management of structural measures (see points 1.53 and 6.36(a) of the 2007 Annual Report).
In the field of external policies In order to strengthen controls at the level of implementing organisations, the Commission plans to develop a specific instrument to better assist these organisations in the management of EU funds and compliance with EU rules (see point 8.33(a) of the 2007 Annual Report).
In the field of internal policies, including research The Commission has developed a multiannual control strategy for the Sixth Framework Programme, based on the detection and correction of errors that could not be detected by file checks prior to the payment.
In order to simplify the procedures of the Seventh Framework Programme, the Commission introduced a Participant Guarantee Fund, which significantly reduced the number of ex ante financial controls and the protective measures to be taken (see points 7.43(b), 10.34 and 2.42(a) of the 2007 annual report).
Source: Commission report to the European Parliament on the follow-up to the 2007 discharge decisions.
The special reports will also be taken into account in the discharge procedure.
Due to the fact that they are published during the course of the year, the presentation of the special reports and the debate on them have usually taken place at an earlier stage at the meetings of Parliament and the Council.
The impact of the audit reports can be enhanced by the thematicisation of the audit reports in the relevant media, which can be used to attract greater attention and stimulate public debate.
As a rule, the media coverage of the Court's annual report is quite comprehensive.
This was also the case in 2009, with the media focusing primarily on improvements in agricultural spending.
Several special reports were also followed with interest by the press.
For example, the special report on the milk market (No 14/2009) assessing the extent to which the management tools for the market for milk and milk products have achieved their main objectives was the subject of intensive discussions in the Council and in Parliament, and, at a time when the sector is struggling with a variety of problems, the media and the professional groups concerned received a broad response.
The Court is working to further analyse the impact of its activities.
In 2009, it started developing a systematic follow-up procedure for its special reports to identify and document progress made by the audited bodies in addressing the identified weaknesses and the implementation of the recommendations made.
This procedure will provide the Court, as well as Parliament and other interested parties, with additional feedback on the impact of its activities.
31 POSITION OF THE COURT OPINION No 1/2010 – IMPROVEMENT OF THE EUROPEAN UNION'S FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT: RISKS AND CHALLENGES In February 2010, the Court's first opinion on measures to reduce the level of irregular payments at the level of the EU budget and to improve the quality of expenditure (sparability, efficiency and effectiveness).
The Court concluded that, in order to further develop recent progress in reducing the level of irregular payments, legislation in the high-risk areas must be simplified and more cost-effective control systems set up.
Such reforms should be undertaken in the context of the ongoing broader review of EU spending regimes.
The Court considers that improving the quality of expenditure is of high importance, which can be achieved by applying the concept of European added value in the definition of expenditure priorities and by addressing the specific problems identified by the Court in the selection, design and implementation of expenditure programmes and grant schemes.
OBJECTIVES ON THE FIELDS CONCERNED ON THE STRENGTH OF PROPOSED PAYMENTS Although the extent of irregular payments from the EU budget as a whole has fallen, it remains high in the areas of cohesion and external aid, development and enlargement, as well as in the framework programme for research and technological development and in the expenditure for rural development.
Most irregularities are based on the notification of ineligible expenditure by the beneficiaries, the notification of excessive eligible expenditure and the non-compliance with payment conditions, for example in the area of public procurement rules.
They are mainly due to the complexity of the rules and payment conditions and to shortcomings in the systems to manage the risks at the level of the final beneficiaries.
SIMPLIFICATION OF THE SIMPLE LEGAL FRAMEWORK CONDITIONS AND IMPROVEMENT OF MONITORING AND CONTROL The Commission should address the specific system deficiencies identified by the Court in the high-risk areas and improve its oversight.
However, with more and more controls and correspondingly falling error rates, the point at which the cost of controls is no longer proportionate to the benefits achieved is at some point reached.
Simplification should therefore remain a priority objective.
Clearly interpretable and easy-to-apply rules and legislation can reduce not only the risk of errors but also the control costs. 31
32 IMPROVING THE CONCEPT OF EXPENDITURE PROGRAMMES In addition to simplification, the Commission should ensure that clear objectives are set when revising existing and designing new measures.
Often more sense of reality, greater transparency and accountability are needed.
To this end, the Commission could further strengthen existing procedures for the development of future strategies, in particular the ex ante evaluation and impact assessment.
The Court proposes that the concept of European added value be clarified in an appropriate political declaration or in EU legislation in order to provide guidance to the EU's political authorities in defining expenditure priorities.
The Court considers that the Commission should complete the budget review as soon as possible and take account of the results of the preparation of the financial framework starting in 2014.
Improving the quality of expenditure should be of high priority for the institutions of the European Union and thus be the main objective of the new Commission.
33 HOUSEHOLD PLANNING FOR 201010 The Court shall present its future audit work annually in a work programme submitted to the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control and available to the public on the Court's website.
The work programme shall provide interested parties with information on new and ongoing audits and on planned reports.
The Court developed an audit strategy for the period 2009-2012, based on two priority objectives: maximising the overall impact of the audits and improving efficiency by making the best use of resources.
These objectives will have a significant impact on the Court's 2010 work programme and on its efforts to improve continuously.
The Court seeks to maximise the overall impact of its audits over the period concerned by: • selecting and designing audits focusing on issues from risk areas and of the greatest interest to the Court's audience; • continuing to provide sound audit conclusions and useful suggestions for improvement; and monitoring whether these proposals are being implemented; • carrying out a wider range of audits and presenting new types of audit products to complement the current annual and special reports; • producing a wider number of special reports and improving their timeliness and ease of use; • developing its relations with its main addressees, including the relevant parliamentary committees, as well as with the media and the general public; and the Court seeks to improve efficiency over the period concerned by making the best use of its resources.
This includes: • better management; • effective and dynamic human resources policy; • rationalisation of audit tasks; • improvement of IT tools; • strengthening of expertise; • strengthening relations with audited bodies.
33 10 A more complete and detailed overview of the Court's future work can be found in the Court's 2010 work programme, which is available on its website (www.eca.europa.eu).
34 The Court has selected certain audit priorities for the 2010 work programme, including: • the multi-annual nature of the bulk of Community expenditure, including flat-rate corrections and recoveries; • innovation and the internal market; • human capital; • sustainable energy; • the Commission's strategy to simplify the legal framework for businesses and citizens.
FEDERAL PRINCIPLE FOR A NEW BUILDING On 1 July 2009, the foundation stone for a new building, the second extension of the European Court of Auditors, was laid in Luxembourg.
Vítor Caldeira, President of the European Court of Auditors, Claude Wiseler, Luxembourg Minister of Buildings, Patrick Gillen, President of the Fonds d'urbanisation et d'aménagement du Kirchberg, and Eduardo Ruiz García, General Secretary of the Court, signalled the start of the construction work with the symbolic groundbreaking ceremony.
This extension of the European Court of Auditors' building complex, which already consists of two buildings, will enable the staff employed in the course of successive Union enlargements to be accommodated.
The Court will endeavour to broaden its range of audit-related reporting types in 2009-2012.
To this end, it will coordinate with its main external addressees to ensure that it will gain a clear understanding of their different needs and of how it can best meet its expectations in the context of the fulfilment of its mandate under the Treaty.
A significant proportion of the resources available to the Court will be used to audit the accounts with a view to drawing up a statement of assurance (the so-called 'DAS').
This requires the examination and audit of the accounts and the operations of the EU's general budget for each financial year.
Separate Statements of Assurance shall be drawn up on the European Development Funds and on each of the 40 European agencies and bodies.
The audit work covers the period from June of the year n to June of the year n+1, so that the annual reports can be published in accordance with the Financial Regulation in November of the year n+1.
The Statement of Assurance for the financial year 2009 will therefore be drawn up and published in 2010 and the Statement of Assurance for the financial year 2010 will start at the same time11.
The Court's work aims at presenting clear conclusions on the level of accounting and budgetary management in the various areas of the general budget and at providing appropriate and cost-effective recommendations where improvements are possible.
The Court's annual report on the general budget for the financial year 2009 will continue to reflect the structure established in 2007 and will take account of the budget's redeployment12.
The findings are presented in chapters relating to coherent groups of policy areas (thematic areas), which are largely, but not entirely, in line with the headings of the new financial framework.
Furthermore, the Court will have a particular concern to present its results and conclusions even more clearly and coherently, to make them more comprehensible and readable, and to simplify the comparison within and between the themes and between them and between the financial years.
35 11 Further information on the DAS approach is available on the Court's website at www.eca.europa.eu.
12 The Court has set up a DAS think tank to reconsider various aspects of the DAS approach to the examination. In this context, it is also considered to redefine the areas of the specific assessments.
36 36 MEASUREMENT AND IMPROVEMENT OF CENTRAL PERFORMANCE INDICATORS In 2008, the Court decided to introduce a system of key performance indicators (CLI) for its audit and non-audit activities in order to measure performance in achieving the Court's strategic objectives and the objectives set out in the annual work programmes.
ZLI serves to strengthen internal and external accountability and to increase work efficiency and quality. WOU ZENTRALE PERFORMANCE INDICATORS? • To inform management of how successfully the Court as an institution implements what it has undertaken; • To support the decision-making process by focusing the institution's attention on efficiency issues and promoting improvements; • To provide the audience with information on relevant aspects related to the Court's performance.
The CFIs primarily concern the achievement of the Court's strategic objectives, as they cover the quality of the audit, the output, the impact and the economic management of the Court's resources.
They provide information on the Court's performance as "undertakings" and are an integral part of the Court's management system.
THE CENTRAL PERFORMANCE INDICATORS OF THE COURT 37 ZLI 1 Assessment of the quality and impact of the Court's audit activities by the main addressees of the Court's reports ZLI 2 Assessment of the quality and impact of the Court's audit activities by the audited body ZLI 3 Assessment of the content and presentation of the Court's reports by a panel of external experts ZLI 4 Percentage of audit recommendations accepted by the audited body a) Implementation of the audited body within a certain number of years ZLI 5 Number of reports accepted compared to the number of planned reports ZLI 6 Number of reports accepted on time ZLI 7 Percentage of audit reports issued on time ZLI 8 External audit of the Court's financial management: a) Assessment of the independent auditor's financial management b) Decision of the discharge authority ZLI 9 Degree of satisfaction of the Court's staff ZLI 10 Average number of training days per person Quantity and quality of audit work can also be improved by considering the impact of the Court's reports and opinions on financial management.
Four key performance indicators (1 to 4) are used to measure the impact of the Court's work.
They were included in the Court's 2010 annual work programme.
38 Number of reports adopted compared to the number of reports planned In 2009, the Court adopted 91% of the planned number of reports.
The annual report and all specific annual reports were adopted as planned.
Of the planned 24 special reports, only 18 were adopted.
The remaining six special reports were still in the final drafting phase as at 31 December 2009.
Number of reports adopted on time In 2009, the Court adopted 67% of its reports within the timeframe set.
The annual report and all specific annual reports were adopted on time.
Due to delays in the special reports, the Court failed to set the target for the CLI 6. Further efforts are needed to improve compliance with the deadlines for the adoption of the special reports.
Measurement of the number of the most important audit notices prepared on time The Court shall transmit its preliminary audit results to the audited body in an audit report.
It aims to increase the proportion of audit notifications submitted on time by 10 % per year, the long-term objective being to produce 80 % of the audit notifications within the specified timeframe (two months after the final audit visit).
In 2009, the number of audit notices issued on time increased by 16% compared to 2008.
External assessment of the Court's financial management: a) the independent auditor's audit opinion, b) the discharge authority's decision The Court's independent auditor gave a full audit opinion on the financial statements and the use of resources, and the European Parliament gave discharge on the basis of the Council's positive recommendation.
Degree of satisfaction of the Court's staff In an internal employee satisfaction survey conducted in 2009, 86% of the Court's staff were generally satisfied with their work (target: 80 %), while the overall level of employee satisfaction was 2.8 on a scale of 4 (target: 2.5).
Average number of training days for examiners (excluding language courses) In accordance with guidelines published by IFAC (International Federation of Accountants), the Court strives to provide the examiners with an average of 40 hours (five days) of professional training.
In 2009, the average was four days.
39 INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION The Court has actively and fully continued its international cooperation within the framework of the following fora: • the Contact Committee, composed of the Presidents of the Supreme Audit Institutions of the EU Member States and the Court, • the Network of Supreme Audit Institutions of the Countries applying for EU membership, • the European Organisation of Supreme Audit Institutions (EUROSAI) and • the International Organisation of Supreme Audit Institutions (INTOSAI).
The Court contributed to the annual meetings of these organisations and to the improvement of international audit principles and procedures and was also actively involved in the committees and working groups set up by these organisations.
In particular, he took over the following tasks: • Chair of the Working Groups "Common Audit Standards" and "VAT"; • Involvement in the working groups "Reports of National SAIs" and "Structural Funds" set up by the Contact Committee; • Participation in the EUROSAI Environmental Working Group and the IT Working Group, the EUROSAI Group, which prepares a guide to best practices to achieve quality, the EUROSAI Training Committee and the EUROSAI Task Force on the Audit of Disaster Aids; • Chair of the INTOSAI Working Group on the Accountability and Audit of Disaster Aid; • Participation in the INTOSAI Sub-Committees on Guidelines for Auditing Accounting, the Audit of Compliance with Legal Standards and Economic Audits, and the Task Force on the Global Financial Crisis.
40 40 PERSONAL AND SUPPORT SERVICES The Court's most important capital is its employees.
As at 31 December 2009, the Court's staff amounted to 880 staff (officials and temporary staff, but without members, contract staff, seconded national experts and trainees).
Of the staff, 525 (including 115 staff in the members' cabinets) were in charge of audit tasks, 163 were in the capacity of translators, 171 were in the capacity of administrative assistants and 21 were in the capacity of president.
The Court's staff have a broad academic and professional background and the quality of their work and their commitment are reflected in the Court's output.
SUPPLEMENTATION OF THE HOFE'S PLANTS TO THE 31 DECEMBER (occupied and vacant posts) Translation Administrative support The Court has committed itself to achieving its strategic goal of improving efficiency through the best possible use of resources.
Therefore, in 2009 it continued to explore and exploit the potential for efficiency gains in all its activities by simplifying procedures and streamlining services.
In particular, the resources of the support services, which have become available through efficiency gains, have been deducted from these services as far as possible and made available for audit-related tasks.
This process is not yet complete and its impact will be even more evident in 2010.
For human resources, the Court, as the central performance indicator (ZLI 9), has established the assessment of the level of satisfaction of the Court's staff (see page 37).
A satisfaction survey has been conducted to provide information on this issue and to support the decision-making process in this area.
The Court is implementing measures to ensure that opportunities are fully exploited to achieve better results in the coming years.

TERMINATION The Court's recruitment policy follows the general principles and conditions of employment of the EU institutions and the staff consists of both officials and temporary staff.
General selection procedures for Court posts are organised by the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO).
The Court also provides internships for a limited number of university graduates for periods of three to five months.
In 2009, the Court hired 112 employees: 69 officials, 14 temporary staff and 29 contract staff.
The recruitment depends on whether reserve lists of EPSO competitions are available and sufficient.
In 2009, the Court succeeded in recruiting an adequate number of new staff.
73 vacant posts at 31 December 2009 were reduced by 33% to 49 by 26 January 2010 and the number of vacant posts will continue to fall sharply in the coming months, as the latest recruitment wave will result in further audit staff coming in.
At 31 December 2008, 68 posts were not filled.
The reserve list for recruitment on the basis of the EPSO AD/126/08 selection procedure was published in August and the first successful candidates entered the Court in early November, i.e. only three months later.
VOCATIONAL TRAINING The profession of the examiner requires continuous training.
In addition, due to the special circumstances of the Court's audit environment, the auditors need good knowledge of foreign languages.
In 2009, the staff of the Court completed an average of nine days of professional training.
Language courses accounted for 64% of the total number of training days in 2009 (compared to 48% in 2008).
Without taking into account the language courses, the examiners completed four days of professional training in 2009 (see ZLI 10 on page 38).
This figure is expected to increase in 2010 as new staff are required to undergo a mandatory training programme.
Based on the long-term strategic objective of "Development and growth" and on the 2008-2011 Training and Training Framework and the continuing training pathways adopted in 2009, the Training and Training Unit has improved the content of the training and has developed new training courses in line with the priorities adopted by the Court.
Cooperation with the other institutions and with interinstitutional bodies such as the European School of Administration has also been successfully pursued.

The European Union's interest in this region is to promote security and long-term stability.
The rule of law, border security and the fight against corruption are fundamental prerequisites for EU accession and represent a major challenge in the Western Balkans.
The European Commission is the main donor of funding in the region.
The Court's report on the effectiveness of Commission projects in the field of justice and home affairs for the Western Balkans (Special Report No 12/2009) in 2009 provided an insight into the situation in this particularly important area.
The audit covered investment projects as well as institution-building projects in the four areas of asylum, integrated border management, justice and police.
33 completed projects were assessed on the spot, including an asylum centre, a prison in Albania, and a court in Bosnia and Herzegovina responsible for human rights and war crimes.
In addition, several EU-funded border crossing points in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Montenegro and Serbia were visited in order to assess whether EU action has resulted in improvements.
The team responsible for conducting the audit worked closely with the rapporteur, Maarten B. Engwirda.

TRANSLATION Translation is an important activity of audit support that enables the Court to fulfil its mission and to fulfil its communication objectives.
In 2009, the total volume of translation increased by 5.2% compared to 2008.
The proportion of translation services provided on time was over 95 %.
The language support of the auditors in the context of audit visits and in the drafting of reports has been increased.
The Directorate of Translation also supported INTOSAI working groups and met other specific needs related to the audit activities of the Court.
In January 2010, a new computerised application (Artemis) was introduced for the more efficient management of translation work.
INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY Information technology provides auditors with essential tools and services.
The most important developments in 2009 were: • Simplification of processes and continuation of the transition to a paperless office through the application of automated permits and electronic forms, the introduction of electronic signatures and the introduction of work to set up an archive database; • Improvement of the security of the Court's IT infrastructure through the establishment of a data recovery centre and the launch of an enhanced version of the Lotus Note Platform, the Court's basic structure for the Court's news and audit documentation/archiving systems; • Adoption of a long-term IT plan for the 2010-2012 period, in order to align information technology to the Court's main audit strategic objectives and to continue efforts to deliver high-quality services. 45
46 MANAGEMENT AND INFRASTRUCTURE The Directorate for Finance and Support Services is responsible for administrative services and infrastructure.
These include internal controls and accounting and administrative and logistical services.
In 2009, the Directorate focused on reorganising its services to improve efficiency and effectiveness and to release staff to redeploy to the benefit of audit services.
This reorganisation resulted in a reduction in the number of units in the Directorate (from five to three) and the implementation of several posts in audit services.
An important activity of the Directorate concerned the construction of a new courtyard building (the "K3 building").
In 2009, a project manager was appointed after a call for tenders.
Construction will begin in March 2010 and is expected to be completed in 2013.
The time and cost framework set for the project will continue to be respected.
TEST TEST As part of the Court's audit work, the auditors must travel to the Member States and other recipient countries of EU funds in order to obtain adequate audit evidence.
The visits are usually carried out by central and local authorities involved in granting, managing and disbursing EU funds, as well as by their final beneficiaries.
The audit teams usually consist of two to three auditors, and the duration of an audit trip may be up to two weeks, depending on the type of audit and the distance.
Within the EU, audit visits are often carried out in conjunction with the Supreme Audit Institutions of the Member State visited, which provide useful logistical and practical support.
The graph below gives an overview of the number of audit visits carried out by the Court in 2009 in the EU Member States (300).
In addition, 36 verification visits took place outside the Union in 2009.

50 SERVICE "INTERNE REVISION" The "Internal Audit" department of the Court is intended to assist the Court in the implementation of its objectives through a systematic, methodological evaluation of risk management, internal control and administrative procedures.
In addition, the Internal Audit Service is making proposals to increase the efficiency of the Court.
This requires a continuous evaluation of internal control systems within the Court to assess their effectiveness.
In 2009, the Court's Internal Audit Service focused its work on auditing accounting (audit of accounting), checking ex-ante controls, auditing the payroll and deposit accounts, the follow-up of contracts and public procurement procedures and an analysis of the promotion procedure.
Most of the audit recommendations issued by the Internal Auditor in 2009 were accepted by the audited bodies and included in action plans for corrective action.
The Court's Internal Audit Committee shall monitor and ensure the independence of the Internal Auditor.
It shall also examine and approve the work programme and the internal auditor's reports and, if necessary, entrust them with specific audit tasks.
In 2009, the Internal Audit Service was audited and certified by an independent auditor, Deloitte S.A.
EXTERNAL AUDIT OF THE HOFES The report of the independent auditor on the annual accounts of the Court of Auditors for the financial year 2008 was published in the Official Journal of the European Union on 23 October 2009 (OJ 2009 L 233, p.
In its opinion, the Court's independent auditor (PricewaterhouseCoopers SARL) concluded: "As regards the annual accounts, we believe that the annual accounts give a true and fair view of the Court's financial and financial position as at 31 December 2008 and of the financial position and the cash flows for the year ending on that date, in accordance with Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1605/2002 of 25 June 2002 and Commission Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 2342/2002 of 23 December 2002 laying down detailed rules for the implementation of the above Council Regulation and the Court's accounting rules. "As regards the use of resources and the control procedures, we have not, on the basis of the steps we have described in this report, encountered a situation in which we have to conclude that, in all of the essentials and in the light of the above assessment criteria, the resources allocated to the Court have not been used for the purposes envisaged, and (b) the control procedures in place do not guarantee that the financial operations have been carried out in accordance with the rules in force and the regulations in force.

European Court of Auditors ANNUAL ACTIVITY REPORT 2010
EUROPEAN COURT OF AUDITORS OF AUDITORS OF AUDITORS The Court of Auditors is committed to the following values: The European Court of Auditors is responsible for the audit of EU finances in accordance with the Treaty.
As an external auditor of the EU, it contributes to the improvement of EU financial management, while acting as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens by promoting accountability and transparency.
An independent and dynamic Court of Auditors, characterised by its integrity and impartiality, recognised for its professionalism, quality and impact, and providing valuable support to its audience to improve EU financial management.
INTEGRITY, INTEGRITY AND INTEGRITY PROFESSIONALITY VALUE ADDITIONAL EXCELLENCE AND EFFICIENCY Independence, integrity and impartiality for the institution whose members and staff produce relevant, timely, high-quality reports, based on sound findings and evidence, take into account the concerns of its addressees, and take into account important and trend-setting statements, including recognition of the individual's value, support in the development of special skills and reward of performance, promoting team spirit through effective communication, delivering its addressee circle with appropriate audit results, and rejecting any form of influence through external instructions or pressure, maintaining a high and exemplary degree of professionalism in all aspects of its work, active participation in the development of public financial control at EU level and increasing efficiency worldwide in all aspects of its work, contributing to effective improvement of the management of the EU budget and contributing to strengthening the accountability for the management of EU financial resources
3 CONTENTS Page 4 – 5 7 9 – 25 9 – 22 23-25 26–45 26–27 28–33 34–39 40–42 43–45 PRESENTATION OF THE PRESIDENT 2010 AT A GLANCE OF OUR ACTIVITIES Audit reports and opinions Cooperation with other SAIs OUR MANAGEMENT Implementation of the strategy for 2009-2012 Measurement of the Court's performance in 2010 Audit support Financial information Auditing and accountability
4 PRESIDENCY OF THE PRESIDENT Welcome to reading the fourth edition of the Annual Activity Report of the European Court of Auditors. This year, we took the opportunity to regroup the content, namely the two main sections, "Our Activities" and "Our Management" and, for the first time, provide an overview of all the performance indicators.
In 2010, the Court of Auditors provided two important opportunities to participate in the debate on the reform of EU financial management.
At the beginning of the year, the Court presented an opinion to the new Commission on the main risks and challenges of improving EU financial management and, towards the end of the year, an opinion on the Commission's proposals to amend the financial regulation applicable to the EU's general budget.
With a view to 2011, the Court will continue to implement its values and to further expand the performance and earnings achieved.
We will once again present high-quality, independent and objective reports and opinions that contribute to improving EU financial management and that promote accountability and transparency, and, in particular, the Court will continue to closely monitor developments in the EU's economic governance and address the new legislative proposals that will affect EU financial management after 2013.
We plan to publish 45 annual reports, i.e. the annual reports on the implementation of the EU budget and on the European Development Funds, as well as the special annual reports on agencies, institutions and other bodies.
Special reports provide an important opportunity to achieve added value as they focus on areas at high risk and on topics of particular relevance to addressees.The Court intends, in particular, to report on the quality of EU expenditure in a wide range of areas, ranging from financial instruments and the SME Guarantee Facility to projects financed by the EU in the field of eGovernment and the single payment scheme in agriculture.
In pursuing its strategy for 2009-2012, the Court hopes to fully fully exploit the benefits of its recent reforms, including streamlined decision-making procedures. The Court will continue its efforts to recruit the appropriate staff, to limit vacancy to a minimum, and to promote the professional development of its staff.
Without the commitment and professionalism of all the staff of the farm, we would not have achieved what we have achieved in 2010.

9 OUR ACTIVITIES AUDIT REPORTS AND OPINIONS The three main products of the European Court of Auditors are: o Annual reports – with the results of its audits of the accounts and compliance audits of specific financial years (including the separate published special annual reports of the agencies, bodies and other bodies of the European Union); o Special reports – which can be published at any time during the year, with the results of its selected audits, mainly economic audits to assess the economy, economic efficiency and effectiveness of selected EU revenue and expenditure sectors; o Opinions on draft legislative acts with financial implications.

The key statements of the annual report were as follows: • The annual accounts of the European Union represent the financial situation and the results of the transactions and cash flows in all key respects. • With the exception of two areas of expenditure (Economy and Finance), as well as "Administrative and other expenditure), the payments of the budget continue to be substantially affected by errors. • According to the Court's estimates, the most likely error rate in cohesion expenditure was significantly lower than in previous years, and for the budget as a whole the error rate estimated by the Court has declined over the past years. • The Commission has improved its data on recoveries of unduly paid amounts and other corrections.
However, this information is not yet fully reliable, and the Commission's information on corrective measures does not make it possible to make a meaningful comparison with the error rate estimated by the Court. The Court's report, on the basis of recommendations, shows how financial management could be improved by strengthening management systems and simplifying regulations and regulations.

The Court concluded that the monitoring and control systems ensure the regularity of payments in a conditional manner.In the report, the Court made recommendations on improving some aspects of the financial management of the EDF, including the cost-effectiveness of expenditure controls, the control of the annual audit of completed projects and the control of the use and monitoring of budget support.
12 Special reports adopted in 2010 When selecting and designing its tasks for economic and compliance audits, the Court is always concerned with achieving the greatest possible effect and with the best possible use of the resources provided for these tasks.
In selecting the subjects, the Court shall take into account the following factors: • the risks to the economy or compliance with legal standards in the area of revenue or expenditure concerned; • the level of revenue or expenditure concerned; • the time elapsed since any prior examination; • the future developments within the relevant legal or operational framework; • the political and public interest.
In order to obtain the required audit evidence, the selected audit and compliance audits must be carefully planned and carried out. In addition, the Court gives the audited bodies, prior to the publication of the report, the opportunity to comment on its findings and the formulation of answers.
As a result, these examinations usually take more than a year.

In 2010, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: • Effectiveness of the support actions ‘Design studies' and ‘Development of new infrastructures' in the Sixth Framework Programme of Research (Special Report No 2/2010) – ‘Design studies' are designed to examine feasibility aspects of potential future research institutions and the ‘Development of new infrastructures' measure is intended to support the development of new infrastructures or the improvement of existing ones.
In the course of the audit, the Court examined whether the two measures have effectively contributed to the objectives of the 6th Framework Programme for Research for 2002-2006 of the 6th Framework Programme for Research. • Impact assessments in the EU institutions: do they help in decision-making?
(Special Report No 3/2010) – Impact assessments are one of the cornerstones of better regulation policy to improve and simplify EU legislative proposals. The assessment of whether the Commission's impact assessments have effectively supported decision-making in the EU institutions was carried out and the comments made in this report are also relevant to other budgetary areas.
• Are the Leonardo da Vinci programme's design and management of mobility measures likely to produce effective results?
(Special Report No 4/2010) – The mobility projects of the Leonardo da Vinci programme enable organisations active in the field of vocational education and training to provide training to participants in another European country. The measures are part of the integrated programme for lifelong learning. In the course of the audit, an evaluation of the design and management of the projects by the Commission and the national agencies has been carried out to assess whether the measures are likely to achieve their objectives. • Improving transport performance on the trans-European rail axes: Have EU rail infrastructure investments been effective?
(Special Report No 8/2010) (see box ‘Initiation of an economic impact assessment'). • Is EU spending on structural measures in the water supply of households used in an optimal way?
(Special Report No 9/2010) – Over EUR 4 billion were allocated from the Cohesion Fund and the European Regional Development Fund for the 2000-2006 programming period to support projects in the field of water supply infrastructure for households.The Court examined whether these funds were used effectively to address a number of needs such as increasing water availability, increasing geographical coverage, improving the efficiency of water supply systems and improving the quality of services. 15

17 "The test presented the team with some challenges," says Gareth Roberts, the head of the test team. "We had to familiarize ourselves very quickly with the realities of European rail transport and got to see some examples of success of fantastic modern railways, but also some network sections that seemed to come from a different era.
We wanted to explore to what extent the European rail system is gradually developing from a patchwork to a network.
Up to 10 examiners were involved in the work on site, as we had to cover many different languages. "I really enjoyed working on this test.
Since then I have become something of a railway fan!' says Andrej Minarovič, the inspector responsible for the work in Germany and Austria.
At the end of the test, Fernando Pascual Gil was nicknamed "Mulwurf" within the team because he had spent some time in railway tunnels in the Alps and the Pyrenees. The test team visited eight Member States and examined the impact of 21 rail projects co-financed by the European Union within the framework of the trans-European transport networks and cohesion policy on trans-European rail transport.
The team members travelled with freight trains over and through the Alps and visited large tunnel construction sites.
These visits were a valuable addition to the findings the auditors had obtained from a review of reports, interviews of railway workers and the usual financial analyses.
18 Conservation and management of natural resources With a budget of EUR 413 billion for the period 2007-2013, the EU has extensive powers and a high political responsibility in the fields of agriculture and rural development, fisheries and the environment. Three-quarters of the budget will be spent on agricultural markets and direct payments to farmers, financed by the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF), the "first pillar" of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP).
More than one fifth of the expenditure is devoted to support for rural development financed by the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD), the second ‘pillar' of the CAP.
Agriculture and rural development are subject to shared management by the Commission and the Member States.
In 2010, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: • Implementation of the Leader approach to rural development (Special Report No 5/2010) – Leader is a bottom-up approach based on local partnerships to support rural development. In the course of the review, it was examined whether the Leader approach was implemented in a way that, in contrast to the traditional top-down approach, added benefits were achieved while minimising the risks of sound financial management. • Has the sugar market reform achieved its main objectives?
(Special Report No 6/2010) – The EU carried out a profound reform of its sugar sector in 2006, aimed at ensuring the competitiveness of the EU sugar industry, stabilising markets and ensuring supply and ensuring a fair standard of living for the agricultural population.
The EU as a global partner In addition to enlargement, the EU has three main objectives in the field of external relations: to achieve stability, security and prosperity in its neighbourhood (the EU and its neighbourhood policy), and to actively support sustainable development at international level (the EU as a partner for sustainable development), to promote global political governance and to ensure strategic and civil security (the EU as a global player).
Expenditure is mainly managed directly by the Commission through its central services or delegations.
• Commission management of the veterinary control system for meat imports following the 2004 health legislation reform (Special Report No 14/2010) - Veterinary controls on imports are an essential part of the EU's food safety policy and contribute to reducing the risk of the outbreak of diseases and health crises that may cost the EU's budget to a large extent. The audit looked at how the EU's veterinary control system at border inspection posts was monitored by the Commission in the context of the reform of the food hygiene legislation that came into force in 2006.
In 2010, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: • Commission management of general budget support in ACP countries, Latin American and Asian countries (Special Report No 11/2010) – General budget support is generally considered by many donors, including the European Commission, to be the most effective way of providing development aid.
The audit examined whether the Commission effectively managed its budget support programmes in the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) States and in Latin America and Asia. 19
20 • EU development assistance for basic education in sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia (Special Report 12/2010) – Through the Education for All and the Millennium Development Goals initiative, the EU and the international donor community committed themselves to ensuring primary education for all children, eliminating gender inequalities and improving the quality of education. The assessment examined whether EU development assistance has contributed to the achievement of these objectives in sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia and whether the Commission has managed its interventions satisfactorily.
Revenue The European Union budget is primarily financed by own resources and other revenue. Traditional own resources – mainly customs duties – account for around 12% and VAT-based own resources for a further 12% of total revenue. The majority of EU own resources (70%) come from own resources derived from gross national income, which, as a residual revenue, ensure that the budget is always balanced. • Has the new European Neighbourhood and Partnership Instrument been successfully launched and achieved in the Southern Caucasus (Armenia, Azerbaijan and Georgia)?
(Special Report No 13/2010) – The European Neighbourhood and Partnership Instrument (ENPI) provides a framework for the planning and implementation of assistance for partner countries and regions.
Since 2007, more than 311 million euros have been allocated to three countries in the Southern Caucasus. In the course of the examination, the ENPI was examined whether it was successfully launched there and whether it achieved results.
In 2010, the Court adopted a special report on • Simplified customs procedures (No 1/2010) – In the case of simplified customs procedures, authorised economic operators benefit from accelerated customs clearance and from a simplified system for paying customs duties, which are among the EU's revenue.
The audit assessed the effectiveness of the Commission's legal framework and the Commission's and the Member States' control approach.Opinions delivered in 2010 The Court's opinions on proposals for new or amended legislative acts with financial implications also contribute to the improvement of EU financial management.

Other forms of cooperation The Court continued its active participation and participation in improving international auditing principles and procedures through its membership of European and international organisations for public financial control bodies, in particular INTOSAI5 and its European regional group EUROSAI.
A delegation of the Court took part in the XXth INCOSAI Congress, which took place in South Africa from 22 to 27 November 2010.
Since 2004, when the Court became a full member of INTOSAI, it has actively participated in the subcommittees on the various types of examination. In addition, the Court contributed to the subcommittee "Promoting best practices and quality assurance through voluntary peer reviews" and supported the increased activities in the field of the development of expertise of the INTOSAI members.
Since 2008, the Court has chaired the Working Group on Accountability and the Audit of Disaster Relief.
An important objective of this work group is to develop guidelines in the area of accountability for disaster relief and to identify and disseminate best practices, focusing on activities directed to stakeholders (multilateral institutions, relief organisations, governments, private auditors). The interim report of the working group was submitted to the INTOSAI Congress in November 2010.
In 2010, the Court also participated in the INTOSAI Task Force "Global Financial Crisis." Within the framework of EUROSAI, the Court is represented in the Environmental Working Group and in the IT Working Group and participates in the EUROSAI Training Committee.
The Court also participated in the working group set up at the VII EUROSAI Congress in 2008 to draw up a guide to best practices for achieving quality within a SAI. The Court is also one of the auditors of EUROSAI. 25
26 OUR MANAGEMENT IMPLEMENTATION OF STRATEGY FOR 2009-2012 In recent years, after a self-assessment and a peer-review process (2008) on the framework conditions for its audit management, the Court has initiated an internal reform process.
A strategy for the period 2009-20126 was developed to address the weaknesses identified, the overarching objectives for the period being: to maximise the overall impact of the audits; to improve efficiency by making the best use of resources.
Many of the priority actions foreseen in the strategy have already been completed and the remaining actions will be implemented in 2011 and 2012. Key achievements achieved in 2010 include: o the achievement of the target of submitting 12 to 15 reports per year on audit reports; o the development of new products – a document on risks and challenges for the new Commission (Opinion No 1/2010) and the establishment of a new system for reporting on the follow-up of the Court's recommendations from 2012; o the revision of the Court's rules of procedure to streamline decision-making procedures through the introduction of chambers and strengthening the governance structure; o the development of an overview of all performance indicators; o the development of the approach to the annual audit of the EU budget (declaration of reliability) on the basis of recommendations from an internal expert body supported by external experts; o the redeployment of a number of posts from support services in favour of audit services.
6 The audit strategy 2009-2012 is available on the Court's website.
27 INTRODUCTION OF INTRODUCTION IN THE NEW RULES OF PROCEDURE One of the main recommendations arising from the Court's reform process was that the Court should make use of the possibility provided for in Article 287(4) of the Treaty of allowing certain categories of reports and opinions of chambers to be adopted while maintaining the principle of collegiality.
Following the Council's approval of the necessary amendments to the Court's Rules of Procedure, Chambers were set up on 1 June 2010 which are composed of Court members and which adopt special reports, special annual reports and opinions on draft acts. Prior to this, all these reports and opinions were adopted by the entire College, and this is still the case with the annual reports on the EU budget and the EDFs.
Although most of the Court's reports are now accepted by the Chambers, the Chambers have the option of transferring their documents to the Court for adoption.
All members may attend meetings of chambers to which they are not members without the right to vote.
The members of the Court
28 MEASUREMENT DATA ON THE HOUSE'S PERFORMANCE IN 2010 Since 2008, the Court has gradually developed a set of key performance indicators (ZLI) to inform o the management of the progress made in the implementation of the 2009-2012 objectives; o to support the decision-making process; o to provide performance-related information to the Court's audience.
As an overview of all indicators is available for the first time for 2010, this year serves as the reference year for future assessments of progress. The Court is very pleased with the results of its key performance indicators in 2010, in particular with regard to the quality and impact of its work.
More important, however, is the fact that the indicators clearly show the areas in which progress is needed and the problems that need to be addressed in order to achieve a future performance increase.
29 Quality and impact of the Court's work The Court assesses the quality and impact of its reports on the basis of assessments by the addressees and on the basis of expert reviews and follow-up of its recommendations.
Assessment by addressees By means of a survey, the Court asked the main addressees of its reports (the Budget Control Committee of the European Parliament and the Budget Committee of the Council) and the main audited bodies (mainly European Commission staff) to assess the quality and impact of the annual reports published in 2009 (the general budget and the EDF) and special reports.
The assessment should be based on a five-stage scale (1 – very bad, 2 – bad, 3 – appropriate, 4 – good, 5 – very good).
2010 Objective Assessment of the quality and impact of the Court's reports by a main addressee 4.2 ≥4 Assessment of the quality and impact of the Court's audit activities by the audited body The result shows that the main addressees of the Court's reports find them on average for ‘good'.
The Court strives to maintain or improve this level of performance.
Experts' reviews Two external bodies have reviewed the content and presentation of a sample of Court reports published in 2009 and 2010. e reviewers have assessed eight special reports and the annual report on the general budget and the EDFs for both years and assessed the quality of different aspects of the reports on a four-stage scale from ‘significantly impaired' (1) to ‘high-quality quality' (4).
2010 target 3.0 ≥ 3 3.7 ≥4 External expert reviews of the Court's reports and presentation The result shows that the Court's reports are "satisfactory".
The reviews have provided valuable insights and the resulting recommendations will be used to improve the quality of future reports.
30 Follow-up to recommendations The Court uses its audit experience primarily in the form of recommendations in order to contribute to the improvement of financial management.To make changes, the Court's recommendations must first be accepted by the audited bodies and subsequently implemented. The indicator is based on the recommendations in the recommendations published in 2009, i.e. the latest available, annual and special reports.
2010 target 90 % ≥ 90 % Percentage of audit recommendations accepted by the audited body The Court strives to maintain or even improve this high level of acceptance of its recommendations.
In 2010, the Court established a system for monitoring the implementation of the recommendations by the audited bodies.
In the coming years, this system will serve as a basis for a further indicator of the extent of the practical implementation of recommendations and will lead to improvements.
It will also provide the Court with valuable insights to improve the quality of its recommendations and thus to improve their acceptance by the audited bodies.
31 Efficiency and effectiveness of resource use The Court assesses the efficiency and effectiveness of its resource use according to its ability to present reports and audit findings on time, to fulfil its financial management obligations, and to ensure the well-being and expertise of its staff. Timeliness of reports The Court strives to accept all planned reports within the specified time limits.
The publication of the annual reports and the specific annual reports shall be subject to the deadlines laid down in the legislation.
For special reports where there is no publication date laid down in legislation, the scheduled date of adoption shall be deemed to be the date of adoption.
2010 target Number of reports adopted compared to the number of reports planned 90% 100% Percentage of reports adopted on time 80% 100% Overall, the Court failed to meet the target in 2010.
The Court adopted fewer reports in 2010 than planned, comparable to the previous year's performance (91% in 2009), and, while the proportion of reports adopted on time increased in 2010 (80% compared to 67% in 2009), there is still a need for further improvement.
While all annual reports and all special annual reports were adopted and published on schedule, only three special reports were published on schedule.
Six special reports delayed adoption until 2011.
The Court aims to achieve the targets by the end of 2012 by introducing further measures to improve the management of the procedures of special reports.
2010 Target Percentage of audit notices prepared on time 54% 80% by 2012 The performance achieved in 2010 is not yet at the required level, but significant progress has been made over the past two years in achieving the target (43% in 2009 and 27% in 2008).
The Court will continue its efforts to achieve the target. External assessment of financial management The Court will endeavour to obtain a full audit opinion from its independent auditor on the annual accounts and the use of resources and discharge from the European Parliament on the basis of a favourable Council recommendation.

2010 target Average number of training days per person 5.7 days ≥ 5 days 33 In 2010 the required level of performance was reached, which means an improvement compared to 2009 (average of 4 days).
Staff satisfaction level In an internal employee satisfaction survey conducted in 2009, 86% of the Court's employees were generally satisfied with their work, with a total employee satisfaction level of 2.8 on a scale of 1 to 4. Each value above 2.5 indicates general satisfaction.The Court strives to maintain or improve this result when a similar survey is conducted at the end of 2012.
34 AUDIT SUPPORT The success of the Court's audit activities depends to a large extent on the quality of the support provided by the Court's specialised services, which provide the logistical, technical and technical know-how that enables the Court to o employ, maintain and motivate its staff and develop its professional skills; o disseminate the audit results in all the official languages of the EU; o make the best use of information technologies; o manage its budget and maintain its infrastructure; o carry out audit visits to all countries where EU funds are spent.
Staff Staff allocation The Court's most important capital is its staff. At 31 December 2010, the Court's staff was 889 (officials and temporary staff, but without members, contract staff, seconded national experts and trainees).
Of these, 557 are in audit chambers (including 123 staff in members' cabinets), 151 in the Directorate "Translation", 157 in administrative support services, and 24 in the President's services. With a view to the objective of the best possible use of resources, in 2010, possibilities of improving efficiency in all activities were again explored and implemented through the simplification of procedures and the rationalisation of services.
Where possible, the number of posts released outside the audit area has been transferred to the audit service, increasing the number of posts used for audit tasks by 6%, and this process will continue in 2011.

37 Professional training The occupation of the examiner requires continuous training in order to keep pace with new developments and to acquire new skills.
In 2010, efforts were made to implement the staff redeployment plan adopted by the Secretary-General, which aims to move posts and staff from the translation service to the audit service in 2011. On the basis of the 2008-2011 plan of training and the training pathways adopted in 2009, the "Vocational Training" Unit made substantive improvements to training in 2010 and developed new training courses in line with the priorities adopted by the Court.
In addition, the Court's Translation Directorate provided valuable linguistic support to auditors on business trips and the subsequent stages of the drafting of audit reports.
In addition, the Translation Directorate supported INTOSAI working groups and met other specific needs related to the audit activities of the Court.
Work on the Artemis project to improve the functions of this important IT application for translators continued in 2010. In addition, the Directorate for Translation of the Court was actively involved in interinstitutional and international specialised bodies.

In 2010, the Directorate continued its efforts to further improve efficiency and effectiveness to release resources to the audit service. • Use of smart phones and laptop com-puters to enable the efficient execution of audit work at any location and at any time, including in the context of the Court's contingency plan.

The Internal Audit Service of the Court shall assist the Court in the implementation of its objectives by means of a systematic, methodological evaluation of risk management, internal control and administrative procedures. Furthermore, the Internal Audit Service shall, on the basis of assessments of the effectiveness of the Court's internal control systems, make proposals to increase the Court's efficiency.
In 2010, the Court's Internal Audit Service focused its work on the follow-up to its recommendations from previous years, the review of the Court's reform of the Court's ex-ante review system, the review of the Court's implementation of the Court's SOS II/SAP system, and the conformity of the video surveillance system with data protection rules and requirements.
In 2009, the Internal Audit Service of the Court was audited and certified in accordance with the internationally recognised standards of the Institute of Internal Auditors.
The auditor's audit report – PricewaterhouseCoopers SARL – on the Court of Auditors' annual accounts for the financial year 2009 was published in October 20107.

The examination chambers I to IV cover various areas of revenue and expenditure, while the fifth, the CEAD chamber, is responsible for horizontal matters. The chambers are supported by examination directorates.
Each member is responsible for specific tasks, primarily in the examination area, and the members submit proposals for examination and reports on the tasks for which they are responsible, to the respective Chamber and the Court.
The members are supported by their cabinet staff and the audit team appointed for the audit task.

European Court of Auditors ANNUAL ACTIVITY REPORT 2011
EUROPEAN COURT OF AUDITORS PROCUREMENT GUIDELINE VALUES The European Court of Auditors is responsible for the audit of EU finances in accordance with the Treaty.
As an external auditor of the EU, he contributes to the improvement of EU financial management while acting as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens.
An independent and dynamic Court of Auditors, distinguished by its integrity and impartiality, recognised for its professionalism, quality and impact, and providing valuable support to its audience to improve EU financial management.
INDEPENDENTITY, INTEGRITY AND INTEGRITY PROFESSIONALITY VALUE EXCELLENCE AND EFFICIENCY Independence, integrity and impartiality for the institution, its members and staff.
Unbiased examination, which takes into account the positions of the bodies concerned, but rejects any form of interference by instructions or external pressure.
Maintaining a high and exemplary degree of professionalism in all aspects of his work.
To contribute to the further development of public financial control at EU and worldwide level.
The preparation of relevant, timely, high-quality reports based on sound findings and evidence, taking into account the concerns of its addressees, and containing important and forward-looking statements.
To contribute to the effective improvement of EU management and to the strengthening of accountability for the management of EU financial resources.
Promote team spirit through effective communication.
Increase efficiency in all aspects of his work.

4 PRESIDENCY OF THE PRESIDENT Welcome to reading the Annual Activity Report 2011 of the European Court of Auditors.
In 2011, the economic and financial crisis led to significant developments in the EU's economic governance, which have significant implications for the future use of public funding.
Against this background, the Court published a position paper in May, which highlights the impact of the measures taken to deal with the financial and economic crisis on accountability, transparency and public financial control.
Later that year, the Contact Committee of the Presidents of the Supreme Audit Institutions (ORCBs) of the EU Member States and the European Court of Auditors called on EU decision-makers to ensure that the principles of accountability, transparency and public financial control are properly respected whenever public funds are used.
The euro area SAIs called in particular for appropriate arrangements for public external financial control of the European Stability Mechanism.
This resulted in a decision to set up an Audit Committee for the Stability Mechanism, to which a member proposed by the Court will be a member.
Also in 2011 the results of our key performance indicators are encouraging, in particular with regard to the follow-up to the recommendations accepted by our audited bodies as well as the assessment of our audit work by addressees and external experts.
We were able to increase our output in terms of the number of audit reports and opinions adopted in 2011, but we were unable to achieve the ambitious objectives we set ourselves in terms of the punctuality of reporting.
Our annual reports now contained more detailed information and a new chapter on performance aspects. We also produced 42 special annual reports and 16 special reports along with seven opinions and a position paper.
The scope of our institution's audit powers in respect of Union revenue and expenditure, in particular in respect of VAT own resources in the Member States, was confirmed by the European Court of Justice in November 2011.
From 2012 onwards, we will be able to report on to what extent our recommendations will be followed up in practice.
In addition, we will submit our methods of audit to a peer review process with the aim of further improving the process of producing our special reports.
In 2011, we published ethical guidelines to further strengthen the Court's audit management framework, and revised the Court's audit strategies and audit guidelines to streamline the audit process and the reporting process.
We will also launch a new employee satisfaction survey in 2012.
Looking ahead, in 2012 we will complete the preparation of our strategy for the period 2013-2017.
Some of the key challenges have already been identified: the EU regulatory framework will continue to develop and we must continue to insist on proper compliance with the principles of accountability, transparency and public financial control.
The need for a high quality and timely guarantee for the use of EU funds is constantly increasing and we need to further develop our audits and reports accordingly.
As the EU is subject to a constant process of change, we, too, will endeavour to make the best possible use of our audit experience to support policy makers in improving financial management.
Strengthening the EU's financial accountability is an objective that we share with other actors and we will try to pool our efforts by entering into strategic partnerships.
Finally, like the other EU institutions and bodies, we must be prepared to achieve with less, to improve the efficiency of our organisation.
Meeting these challenges will depend to a significant extent on the efforts of all the Court's staff.
The development of the excellence of our employees – a fundamental value of our institution – is and remains an important concern for us.
With regard to the professionalism, commitment and results achieved by our employees in the past, I am confident that the Court will be able to achieve these future goals.
Mr Manuel da SILVA CALDEIRA President 5
