Supporting audit activities 55 Supporting services Professional training To further develop the Court as a professional audit body and to make the best use of its existing knowledge as well as its expertise and expertise, a continuous training of the staff is necessary in order to be able to keep pace with professional developments and to acquire new skills.
In 2014, the staff of the Court (auditors and other employees) completed on average eight days of professional training.
The proportion of language courses in continuing vocational training is continuing to decline.
In 2014, this represented 43% of the total number of training days (compared to 46% in 2013).
In order to make the best use of existing resources and technologies, the Court has been offering its employees, since 2014, individually tailored e-learning courses and training courses in the form of integrated learning, in which, prior to the attendance event, the participants complete the general theory in an online training.
In addition, the objective of exchanging internal knowledge and providing the Court's auditors with the most up-to-date of developments in the public sector audit, and the organisation of presentations of internal and external experts on developments in the audit sector and other relevant areas, were also pursued.
Translation Translation is an audit support activity that enables the Court to fulfil its mission and to fulfil its communication objectives by providing the results it has provided in the languages of EU citizens.
In 2014, the total translation volume was 4% higher than in 2013.
More than 98% of the translations were completed on time.
In addition to normal translation work, the Translation Directorate further expanded the direct participation of translators in the Court's audit and core business: translators provided linguistic support in 40 audit visits throughout the EU and in drafting audit reports.
In 2014, the Translation Directorate focused on quality assurance.
To this end, the first quality assurance manual in the translation sector was adopted and a system for customer feedback was developed.
Finally, in order to make the services more efficient, the process of translation work was reviewed and optimised, and the automation of the process was started in cooperation with the Information Technologies Directorate.
Support for audit activities 56 All processes related to the development and provision of instruments were carried out under the control of security and continued operation: for example, in 2014 after the new K3 building had been purchased, a comprehensive test was carried out to re-launch after the collapse of the IT systems (disaster recovery) and, in addition, central IT components were modernised (e.g. the introduction of the Court's e-mail system migration).
Administration and infrastructure The role of the Finance and Support Services Directorate is to provide adequate resources, services and infrastructure to enable the Court to fulfil its mission and to achieve its strategic objectives, and to ensure that the necessary financing, internal controls and accounting mechanisms are available to support all of the Court's activities.
In 2014, the Directorate continued to focus on making its activities even more efficient and economic.
An environmental management system for the Court is currently being developed in line with the principles of the Community environmental management and audit system (EMAS), with the aim of obtaining certification by the end of 2016.
In 2014, a number of measures were successfully implemented, delivering concrete results and demonstrating the Court's commitment to the environment, including: • the adoption of environmental policy; • the implementation of an environmental analysis and an assessment of environmental law; • increasing the number of environmental awareness campaigns from four in 2013 to eight in 2014; • the adoption of BREEAM environmental certification (the world's leading method of designing and evaluating sustainable buildings) for the K3 building and maintaining the certification mark for good waste management; • the promotion of sustainable transport among workers by providing a new bicycle room with showers and changing areas for cyclists, the installation of a charging station for electric cars and the reservation of good parking places for cyclists.
Support for audit activities 57 Financial information The Court is financed by the general budget of the European Union.
The Court's budget includes around 0.093 % of total EU expenditure and 1.58% of total administrative expenditure.
In 2014, the overall budget execution rate was 98.8%, compared with 92% in 2013.
The higher execution rate is mainly due to better estimation and planning of expenditure in Title 1, which achieved an average execution rate of 98.8%.
For Title 2, the average execution rate was 98.4%.

Supporting audit activities 59 Auditing and accountability Internal audit of the Court The Internal Auditor advises the Court on risk control issues by delivering opinions on the quality of the management and control systems and recommendations on improving the conditions for the management of operations and on the promotion of sound financial management.
The internal auditor also supports the work of the external auditor, whose mission is to certify the Court's annual accounts.
The internal auditor reported to the Court on the results of the audits carried out during 2014, the findings, the recommendations and the measures taken on the basis of those recommendations.
The Court reports annually to the European Parliament and the Council on the results of the internal auditor's work.
In October 2014, the Court's internal audit certified compliance with the definition of internal audit, the Code of Conduct and the standards established by the Institute of Internal Auditors (IAA).
This certification was the result of a comprehensive quality assessment of the Court's internal audit carried out at the request of the Internal Auditor and the Internal Audit Committee by an external evaluator, Deloitte SARL, and was in line with the IIA's international standards for internal audit professional practice.
External audit of the Court The Court's annual accounts are audited by an independent auditor.
This is an important aspect of the Court's approach to applying the same principles of transparency and accountability to itself as to the bodies it is examining.
The auditor's report – Pricewaterhouse‐ Coopers SARL – on the Court of Auditors' annual accounts for the financial year 2013 was published on 18 September 2014.
Audit opinions of the independent auditor – Financial year 2013 On the annual accounts: "We believe that the annual closure provides a true picture of the financial and financial situation of the European Court of Auditors as at 31 December 2013, its profitability and cash flows for the year ending on that reference date, in accordance with Regulation (EU, Eura‐tom) No 966/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2012 on the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the Union and to Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) No 1268/2012 of 29 October 2012 on the rules of application of the Financial Regulation. "As regards the use of resources and the control procedures, in our work described in this report, we have not encountered the facts on which we have to conclude that in all essential respects and in the light of the abovementioned criteria, the resources allocated to the Court have not been used for the purposes envisaged and the control procedures established do not provide the necessary assurance that the financial transactions have been carried out in accordance with the applicable rules and regulations.
Declaration by the 60 authorising officer by delegation The undersigned, Secretary-General of the European Court of Auditors, hereby declares, in his capacity as authorising officer by delegation, that the information contained in this report is accurate and accurate and confirms with sufficient certainty that the resources provided for the activities described in this report have been used for the purposes provided and in accordance with the principles of sound financial management, and that the control procedures established provide the necessary assurance for the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions and for the appropriate management of fraud or suspicion of fraud, and that the costs and benefits of the controls are appropriate.
This security is based on the assessment of the undersigned and on the information available to him, such as the reports and statements of the authorising officers by subdelegation, the internal auditor's reports and the independent auditor's audit reports on previous financial years.
Done at Luxembourg, 26 February 2015 Eduardo Ruiz García Secretary-General

European Court of Auditors 02 About the Court The European Court of Auditors is the independent external audit body of the European Union, based in Luxembourg.
He has 28 members – one from each EU Member State – and employs around 900 staff from all EU Member States in the audit and administration field.
Since its establishment in 1977, the Court has been committed to improving EU financial management and accounting.
The Court's tasks The Court shall verify that the EU funds have been correctly recorded and taken up and spent in accordance with the relevant rules and regulations and that the best use is made of the funds.
It warns against risks, provides security and provides guidance to EU policy-makers on how to improve public financial management and how to ensure that European citizens know how to use their money.
Through its audit work and other activities, the Court contributes to strengthening the democratic legitimacy and sustainability of the European Union.

Foreword by President 04 Dear reader, in 2015, to which this report refers, the European Union was once again faced with major challenges, with major developments in the EU's leadership, policies and financial management, including the establishment of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) and the establishment of the Single Resolution Mechanism for Banks in the euro area.
These and other developments have led to new audit tasks for the Court.
In 2015, we also reviewed the activities of the EU institutions and other bodies and all EU funds paid to Member States, countries outside the EU, international organisations and other beneficiaries.
In accordance with our obligations arising from the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, we have prepared annual reports on the general budget of the EU and on the European Development Funds, as well as special annual reports on the accounts of more than 50 EU agencies and other bodies.
In addition, we produced 25 special reports on numerous topics, the results of which are summarised in the present activity report.
We would like to draw your attention to two special reports in particular: our report on the emissions trading system, which shows that our work goes beyond purely financial matters, and our report on financial assistance to countries in difficulty, which is part of a series of new special reports on financial and economic governance.
We also delivered eight opinions last year on new or amended EU legislation with significant financial implications, including an opinion on the Regulation establishing the EFSI.
To make a difference with our work, we need to pass on the lessons learned to stakeholders at EU and national level.
In the course of the year, we have further deepened our cooperation with the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union, our main partners in ensuring the EU's accountability.
We presented the results of our audits to an increasing number of specialised committees of these bodies, and we took their concerns into account in the planning of future audits.
The Court also paid high-level visits to Member States to strengthen partnerships with national authorities, parliaments and audit bodies.
In 2015, we organised two notable conferences: one in Brussels on EU energy security and the other in Luxembourg on the future of development aid in the context of the new United Nations Sustainable Development Goals.
We also prepared a major internal reform in order to be able to respond better to continuous developments within the European Union.
This report explains some important changes we have made in relation to our relations with stakeholders, our audits and our resources.
In addition, you will receive important information about our human resources management, finances and performance and the results of our internal and external audits of the past year, as well as about the recent annual discharge procedure.
I hope that this report will give you a useful and interesting overview of the Court's activities in 2015, and that this will serve our mission of improving EU financial management, promoting accountability and transparency, and protecting the financial interests of EU citizens.
05 Our activities Our management • Annual reports on the EU general budget • and the European Development Funds for the financial year 2014, which essentially contain the Statements of Assurance and the audit results. • 52 special annual reports with the Court's audit opinions on the accounting of the individual agencies and other bodies of the EU and two summary reports. We carried out an internal reform to streamline our audit and reporting procedures and to allow for greater flexibility in the management of our resources. • 25 special reports on certain management and budgetary areas, including the emissions trading system, youth employment programmes and assistance during the financial crisis. • 8 opinions on new or amended EU legal acts and other decisions affecting financial management, from the proposed Regulation on the European Fund for Strategic Investments to the amended Regulation on the Single Resolution Mechanism. • Meetings, seminars and conferences with our addressees, including two high-level conferences on EU accountability, one on the security of energy supply and the other on the future of development assistance.
We continued our equal opportunities policy in recruitment and in personnel management. • We made considerable progress in integrating audit management and audit documentation information systems. We also made audit-related information available on mobile devices. The premises of the European Court of Auditors in Luxembourg.
Our activities 06 Audits Our audit reports and opinions are an important link in the EU's accountability chain as they are used to hold the bodies responsible for the EU's financial management accountable, in particular in the context of the annual discharge procedure.
These bodies are primarily the European Commission, but also the other EU institutions and bodies.
In areas with shared management, Member States also have an important role to play, such as expenditure on agricultural and cohesion measures.
Our three most important products are: • Annual reports that essentially cover the results of audits of the accounts and compliance audits of the budget of the European Union and the European Development Funds (EDF), but also aspects of the financial management and performance aspects.
• Special reports presenting the results of selected economic or compliance audits on specific expenditure or policy areas, or on budgetary or management issues. • Opinions on new or amended legal acts affecting financial management and other products based on analysis, either at the request of another institution or at the Court's own initiative.
We strive to manage our resources in a way that ensures an appropriate balance between our various activities, while ensuring that the various areas of the EU budget are well covered and that the results are sound.
In 2015, we used a significant share of our resources to prepare the annual Statements of Assurance, which were then presented in our annual reports.
The work of the Statement of Assurance covers the two aspects on which we have to deliver an annual audit opinion in accordance with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union: the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
In addition, we take into account, as far as possible, the work of other auditors (see section on the examination of EU agencies on page 14) and the management declarations in the form of the Annual Activity Reports of the Directors-General of the Commission.
In addition to the statutory audits, we choose to choose specific expenditure or policy areas at our own discretion. This is based on criteria such as the risk of irregularities or inadequate performance, potential for improvement and public interest.
We select these topics completely independently, but take into account the positions of our addressees.
In 2015, we produced 25 special reports, which are, in particular, the result of our audit reports.
The summaries of the special reports are presented in the present activity report (pp. 15-33).
In 2015, we issued eight opinions on proposals for new or amended regulations and regulations (p. 34).
In particular, we would like to draw attention to our opinion on the EFSI to clarify both the issue and the impact of our opinions.
All audit reports and opinions are available on our website (eca.europa.eu).

Our activities 08 audit visits in 2015 While most of the audit work was carried out at the Court's premises in Luxembourg, the auditors also carried out audit visits to Member State authorities, other beneficiaries of EU funds within and outside the European Union (including organisations involved in the award of EU funds, such as the European Investment Bank's regional offices in Kenya and Uganda) and to other EU institutions, agencies and agencies.
Through these visits, we obtained direct audit evidence from the bodies involved in the authorisation, administration, collection and payment of EU funds, as well as from the respective final recipients.
Our audit teams usually consist of two to three auditors, and the duration of a test visit may be a few days, but also several weeks.
The frequency and intensity of the audit work in each Member State and beneficiary country depend on the type of audit and, where appropriate, the sample selection.
The number of visits may therefore vary from country to country and from year to year.
Within the EU, our audit visits are often carried out in conjunction with the Supreme Audit Institutions of the Member States visited.
In 2015, the Court's auditors spent 4 310 days on the ground, in Member States and outside the EU, and obtained audit evidence for annual reports and selected audit tasks (special reports).
They also spent a lot of time with the EU institutions in Brussels and Luxembourg, as well as with decentralised agencies and bodies throughout the EU.
The on-site inspections took less days than in 2014.
This is due to more efficient working methods and an increasing use of technologies such as secure exchange of data and documents as well as videoconferencing.
Detecting fraud Although our audits are not specifically designed to detect fraud, we occasionally encounter cases in which we suspect irregularities or fraudulent activities in our audit work.
In combating fraud against the EU budget, the Court cooperates with the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF).
We shall forward to OLAF any suspicion of fraud, corruption or any other illegal activity to the EU's financial interests, which arises during our audit work.
OLAF will then follow up on these cases, which will decide on possible investigations and, where appropriate, cooperate with Member States' authorities.
In 2015, we forwarded 27 cases of suspected fraud to OLAF (2014: 16 cases).

Our activities 10 Annual reports on the 2014 financial year In 2015, the majority of our audits of the accounts and compliance audits were devoted to the implementation of the EU budget for the 2014 financial year.
The 2014 Annual Report was published on 10 November 2015 and presented to our audience, including the European Parliament and its Committee on Budgetary Control, the Council of the European Union (Economy and Finance Council), national parliaments and governments, and the media.
The main objective of our annual report is to help the European Parliament, the Council and the citizens to assess the quality of EU financial management by submitting findings and conclusions.
In the 2014 Annual Report, we provide a assurance of the use of EU funds during the financial year under review and highlight the areas where the risk of EU funds not being used properly was greatest.
In addition, we analyse why errors have occurred and make useful and cost-effective recommendations on possible improvements.
We have revised the structure of our annual report on the financial year 2014 in order to make the report more readable.
The headings of the chapters now correspond to those of the headings of the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020.
The key element of the report remains the Statement of Assurance, in which we deliver our audit opinion on the reliability of the EU's annual accounts and on compliance with the rules on revenue and expenditure.
In addition, we have specifically assessed all the EU's key areas of activity and provided extensive information on budgetary and financial management.
The report also contains information on the performance of the EU budget and on the performance reporting of the Commission, in particular on progress towards the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy.
President Vítor Caldeira presents the European Parliament with the annual report 2014 of the European Court of Auditors. EU expenditure in 2014 amounted to 142.5 billion euros = nearly 300 euros per citizen

Therefore, we were once again able to give an unqualified opinion on their reliability.
However, we gave a failed audit opinion on the regularity of payments.  the estimated error rate, which measures the extent of the irregularities, amounts to 4.4% of the 2014 payments, close to the error rate for 2013 (4.5%) and consistently above the materiality threshold of 2%.  the estimated error rates we estimated were equal (4.6%) for expenditure subject to shared management with the Member States and for expenditure directly managed by the Commission.
The highest error rates were recorded in the expenditure in the headings 'Economic, social and territorial cohesion' (5.7%) and 'Competitiveness for growth and employment' (5.6%).
The lowest estimated error rate for administrative expenditure was estimated (0.5%).. There is a clear link between types of expenditure and error rates.
The estimated error rate for reimbursement schemes (5.5%), for which the EU reimburses eligible costs for eligible activities on the basis of the cost statements drawn up by beneficiaries, is twice the estimated error rate for schemes based on payment entitlements (2.7%), for which the payment is not reimbursable, but depends on the fulfilment of certain conditions. The corrective measures taken by the authorities in the Member States and the Commission have had a positive effect on the estimated error rate.
Without these measures, the estimated total error rate would have been 5,5 %.
The Commission needs further improvement in terms of risk assessment and the impact of corrective measures. The Commission, Member State authorities and independent auditors would have been able to use all the information available to them, and would have been able to prevent and detect and correct a significant proportion of the errors before they were made. The amounts to be paid in the current and in the coming years are still very high.
The Commission should take action to address this persistent problem.
The Partnership Agreements and Programmes do not sufficiently take into account the objectives of Europe 2020 by the Member States.
Due to these two aspects, the Commission is only able to monitor and report on the performance and contribution of the EU budget to Europe 2020 to a limited extent.  the forthcoming mid-term review of the 2014-2020 multiannual financial framework is crucial for the management of EU expenditure.
It is important that the Commission analyse the areas with persistently high error rates as soon as possible, assess the possibilities for reducing these error rates, while paying greater attention to the performance of expenditure.

Our activities 13 Annual Report on the European Development Funds (EDF) for 2014  the revenue was not affected by errors.  the payments were substantially affected by errors. under the EDF, the European Union grants funds for development cooperation with the African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP States) and the overseas countries and territories (OCTs) countries and territories (OCTs) under the EDF.
The EDFs are financed by the Member States and managed outside the EU budget by the European Commission and by the European Investment Bank, for some aid.
Their revenue was not significantly affected by errors, while payments had an estimated error rate of 3.8%.
As in previous years, we identified weaknesses in ex ante controls.
The estimated error rate is almost two thirds due to errors related to non-compliance with procurement rules and lack of evidence to justify expenditure.
Our annual report on the EDFs will be published together with our annual report on the implementation of the EU budget and is available on our website (eca.europa.eu).
Our activities 14 Special annual reports for the financial year 2014 A total of EUR 4 billion was allocated to all EU agencies, bodies and Joint Undertakings in 2014.
EU agencies, other bodies and Joint Undertakings perform certain tasks on behalf of the EU and are based in different EU Member States.
They are active in many areas, such as safety, health, research, finance, migration and transport, and each has its own mandate, a board of directors, a director, staff and a budget.
In 2015, we produced 52 special annual reports on the financial year 2014.
They covered 41 decentralised agencies, executive agencies and other EU bodies, eight European research Joint Undertakings, the European Schools, the Galileo Joint Undertaking in liquidation and the Sisnet communication infrastructure.
In addition, we published two summaries, which provide an overview of the results of our audits in this area (one of the summaries of the EU agencies and other bodies and the other of the Joint Undertakings).
These reports were submitted to the President of the European Parliament and the Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control, the General Affairs Council and the Council's Committee on Budgets.
In 2014, the individual accounts of the 33 decentralised agencies and other bodies of the EU were independently audited for the first time by a private audit firm.
In drawing up our audit opinions on these financial statements, we took account of this audit work and of the measures taken by the audited bodies on the basis of the auditor's findings.
The financial statements of the other agencies and Joint Undertakings have been fully audited by us.
We found the accounting of all agencies, other bodies and Joint Undertakings in 2014 to be reliable.
The operations were lawful and proper, except for Artemis (embedded ICT systems), ENIAC (nanoelectronics) and ECSEL (electronic components and systems).
In general, the agencies have further improved their procedures by taking corrective measures based on our comments from previous years.
Our special annual reports and the two summaries of the results of our audits of the agencies, other bodies and Joint Undertakings for 2014 are available on our website (eca.europa.eu).
52 special annual reports on the EU agencies, other bodies and Joint Undertakings, based throughout Europe Headquartered by Europol, The Hague, the Netherlands.
Our Activities 15 Special Reports In addition to our annual reports and special annual reports, we publish special reports throughout the year, which contain the results of the economic and compliance audits we carry out on specific budgetary areas or management issues of our choice.
When selecting and designing these audit tasks, we are committed to achieving maximum impact and thus using our resources in the best possible way.
Our economic audits often cover several financial years, and their subject matter is complex, so it can take more than a year for these audits to be completed.
In 2015, the special reports focused in particular on the following topics: the overall EU objective of creating added value and growth, and the EU's response to global challenges such as the sustainability of public finances, the environment and climate change.
Under the respective headings corresponding to the headings of the multiannual financial framework, the 25 special reports prepared in 2015 are briefly presented.
