Internal and external audit Internal audit The Internal Audit Service advises the Court on risk management issues.
It provides independent and objective guarantees and provides advisory services designed to increase and improve the value added of the Court's activities.
It shall also report to the Internal Audit Committee, composed of three members of the Court and one external expert.
The Committee shall monitor regularly the progress made in the various tasks set out in the annual work programme of the Internal Audit Service and shall ensure the independence of the Service.
During 2019, the Internal Audit Service carried out three selected tasks: "Risks and challenges of the Audit Committee", "Travel expenses of members and senior officials, expenses for the representation of members and use of the Court's fleet of vehicles" and "occupational training of the Court".
Our risk management strategy and three annual declarations by authorising officers by subdelegation were also examined.
In addition, the Internal Audit Service monitored the implementation of its previous recommendations by verifying that the agreed action plans have been implemented, and by advising on issues related to the Court's new internal control framework.
Our internal auditor did not identify any deficiencies which, due to their nature or extent, would seriously jeopardise the reliability of the internal control systems as a whole; these control systems had been introduced by the authorising officer by delegation to ensure the legality and regularity of the Court's financial operations in 2019.
External audit Our annual accounts are audited by an independent external auditor.
We attach great importance to this audit, as it shows that we apply the same transparency and accountability principles to ourselves as to the bodies we audit.
The auditor's report – PricewaterhouseCoopers S.à.r.l. – on the Court's financial statements for the financial year 2018 was published on 4 April 2019. 67
Audit opinions of our independent auditor – Financial year 2018 68 On the Court's annual accounts: "According to our assessment, the annual accounts give a true view of the Court of Auditors' financial and financial situation as at 31 December 2018 and of the results of its operations, its cash flows and changes in net assets for the year ending that reference date, in accordance with Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2012 on the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the Union and repealing Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1605/2002 (OJ L 347, 20.12.2012, p.

Regarding the use of resources and the Court's control procedures: "In the work described in this report, we have not encountered the facts from which we would have to conclude that the resources allocated to the Court have not been used for the intended purposes in all the essential respects and in the light of the above assessment criteria or the resources allocated to the Court, and that the control procedures in place do not provide the necessary assurance that the financial operations have been carried out in accordance with the applicable rules and regulations."
Discharge for the financial year 2017 Like the other EU institutions, the Court is also subject to the discharge procedure.
In March 2019, the European Parliament granted our Secretary-General discharge in respect of the implementation of our budget for the financial year 2017.
As every year, we have carefully analysed all the problems raised during the discharge procedure with regard to our audit and management responsibility, we have taken appropriate measures and we have reported to the European Parliament in detail on our follow-up measures.

Declaration by the authorising officer by delegation In accordance with Article 74(9) of the Financial Regulation Statement by the authorising officer by delegation The undersigned, Secretary-General of the European Court of Auditors, hereby declares in his capacity as authorising officer by delegation, or that the information contained in this report, as well as the additional internal information contained in this report in order to fulfil my duties, which contain financial and management information, including the results of the controls, are accurate and accurate, and or confirms with reasonable certainty that, the resources provided for the activities described in this report have been used for the purposes envisaged and in accordance with the principles of sound financial management, the control procedures set up are proportionate to the need to ensure the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions and to ensure the proper management of fraud or suspicion of fraud, the costs and benefits of the controls are proportionate.

DE EUROPEAN COURT OF AUDITORS 2013 Brief information on the audit of the EU Presentation of the annual reports of the European Court of Auditors for the financial year 2013
Luxembourg: Publications Office of the European Union, 2014 ISBN 978-92-872-0998-6 doi:10.2865/23970 © European Union, 2014 Reproduction is authorised provided the source is acknowledged.
EN 2013 Brief information on the audit of the EU Presentation of the annual reports of the European Court of Auditors for the financial year 2013
President's Preface 02 Each November, the European Court of Auditors reports on the results of its annual audits of EU financial management during the previous financial year.
On the basis of the audit evidence obtained, the Court provides a guarantee of reliability for the use of EU funds and highlights the greatest risk of EU funds not being used properly.
The reports also contain recommendations for possible improvements in EU financial management.
In this way, the Court supports the European Parliament and the Council in the review of EU expenditure and contributes to the effective exercise of the accountability of EU citizens.
This "in-depth information on the audit of the EU in 2013" summarises and explains the main findings in our 2013 Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget and on the European Development Funds.
As in previous years, the reports show the extent to which EU and national financial management stakeholders have provided a true picture of the management of financial resources in their reports, ensured the application of EU financial rules, and respected the principles of economy, economy and effectiveness.
2013 was the last year of a seven-year programming period and we are publishing our annual reports on the financial year in a transition period which is important for the EU and its finances.
As our reports show, a new European Parliament and a new Commission are facing both long-standing and new challenges for financial management and accountability in the 2014-2020 programming period, which is now under way.
The pressure on EU and national finances still requires careful management and control of EU funds and better forecasts of long-term financing needs.
In particular, our reports highlight the need for the Commission and the authorities of the Member States to pay more attention to the need to use EU funds to achieve results that could not be achieved equally efficiently or effectively by other means.
At the same time, the Court's audit results show that more can and should be done to ensure that EU spending is in line with the rules.
The Court will be pleased to take the opportunity to assist the new European Parliament and the new Commission in solving these and other problems of financial management and of accountability at EU level.
To this end, we have, on the basis of our audit experience, also prepared two landscape analyses that highlight the main challenges facing the EU in the areas of accountability, audit and financial management.
Mr Manuel da SILVA CALDEIRA President of the European Court of Auditors

Overall Results 04 Key Statements Summary of the Statement of Assurance for 2013 The European Court of Auditors (EuRH, ‘the Court') gives an unqualified audit opinion on the reliability of the accounts of the European Union for 2013.
The total revenue for 2013 is legal and regular.
The overall commitments for 2013 are legal and regular.
The 2013 payments are substantially affected by errors.
The Court therefore gives a failed judgment on its legality and regularity.
The Court estimates the error rate, which measures the extent of the irregularities, at 4.7% for payments for 2013. This figure is close to the error rate for 2012 (4.8%) and consistently above the materiality threshold of 2%. ο Overall, the monitoring and control systems examined, with significant differences between Member States, ensured the regularity of payments due. ο The two expenditure areas of regional policy, transport and energy with an error rate of 6.9% and rural development, environment, fisheries and health with an error rate of 6.7%, were the most error-prone.
In the case of shared management as a whole, i.e. including agriculture: market support and direct payments as well as employment and social affairs, the estimated error rate was 5.2%. ο Corrections and recoveries by the authorities in the Member States and the Commission had a positive impact on the estimated error rate.
Overall results 05 Proper use of EU funds EU funds for 2013 Every year, the Court reviews the EU's revenue and expenditure and assesses the reliability of the annual accounts and the compliance of revenue and expenditure operations with the rules and regulations in this respect.
In 2013, the total expenditure from the EU budget amounted to 148.5 billion euros or around 290 euros per citizen.
These expenditures represent about one percent of the EU's gross national income and represent about two percent of the total public expenditure of the EU Member States.
The EU budget is adopted annually by the European Parliament and the Council on the basis of a seven-year financial framework.
The Commission's primary task is to ensure that the budget is spent properly.
The Commission shares this task with the EU Member States for around 80% of expenditure, particularly in the fields of agriculture and cohesion.
Where do the funds come from?
The EU budget is financed from various sources.
The largest share is made up of payments made by Member States on the basis of their gross national income (EUR 110.0 billion).
Other sources include Member States' payments based on VAT collected (14.5 billion euros) and customs and agricultural duties (15.4 billion euros).
The annual EU budget is spent in a wide range of policy areas (see Graph 1).
Payments are intended to support activities as diverse as research projects, training for the unemployed or agricultural production.

Overall results 09 Errors, waste and fraud The Court's estimated error rate is not a measure of fraud, inefficiency or waste.
It is a damage to the funds that should not have been paid out because they have not been used in accordance with the existing legislation.
Typical errors include payments for ineligible expenditure or purchases where the procurement rules have not been properly applied.
Fraud is a deliberate act of deception with the aim of gaining advantages.
The Court shall forward cases to OLAF (the European Union Anti-Fraud Office) to which it is responsible for carrying out any further investigations in cooperation with the authorities in the Member States, in the course of its investigations and in which it suspects fraud.
A comparison of the error rates estimated for the various areas of expenditure is shown in Figure 5.
Higher quotas in the area of research and other internal policies and in the area of administrative expenditure and related expenditure have been offset by lower quotas in the areas of rural development, the environment, fisheries and health, as well as external relations, external assistance and enlargement.
As in 2012, the two areas of expenditure in the areas of regional policy, transport and energy, and rural development, the environment, fisheries and health were the most flawed.
These two areas together with the other two areas of shared management (agriculture: market support and direct payments and employment and social affairs) have an estimated error rate of 5.2 %.
For all other operational expenditure (mainly managed directly by the Commission), the estimated error rate was 3.7 %.
In addition, the Court found that administrative expenditure had an estimated error rate of 1.0%.

Overall results 12 The Court analyses the contribution of the different types of error and the different areas of expenditure to the estimated total error rate (see Graph 6).
Expenditure that did not meet the necessary conditions to be claimed under EU-funded projects had the largest share of the estimated total error rate (inclusion of ineligible costs in cost statements: 39% or 1.8 percentage points of the estimated total error rate).
Second, projects were projects in which either the funded object/activity or the beneficiary should not have been funded in accordance with the applicable rules (non-eligible projects/activities or beneficiaries: 22 % or 1.1 percentage points of the estimated total error rate).
As the largest expenditure area with the highest estimated error rate, the area of regional policy, transport and energy is by far the largest contributor to the estimated total error rate (44% or 2.1 percentage points of the estimated total error rate).
The agricultural sector: market support and direct payments, where expenditure was almost the same, contributes roughly half as much to the estimated overall error rate.
Corrective measures have a positive impact on the error rate Member States and the Commission are applying corrective measures to protect the EU budget in cases of ineffective control systems or irregular expenditure.
If such corrective measures had not been taken in respect of the 2013 payments audited by the Court, the estimated total error rate would have been 6,3 % instead of 4,7 %.
However, the estimated error rate could be significantly further reduced by better application of existing control systems and corrective measures.
The Court noted that the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the errors in a large part of the error in the areas of shared management before the Commission had been requested to refund them.
For example, this would have reduced the estimated error rate in the area of regional policy, transport and energy from 6.9% to 3.9%, in the area of rural development, the environment, fisheries and health from 6.7% to 2.0% and in the area of employment and social affairs from 3.1% to 1.9%.
New challenges for the presentation of reliable financial information Reporting on the corrective adjustments mentioned above does not clearly distinguish between the main types of corrective adjustments and the information is largely provided outside the accounting system.
This makes more detailed analysis more difficult and reduces the accuracy of the figures presented in the accounts and related financial reporting.
Another development is the increasing use of financial instruments to support investment in potentially economically viable projects in the form of loans, guarantees, equity and other risk mechanisms.
Due to its complex structure, financial instruments require particular care in assessing and recording them in accordance with internationally recognised public sector accounting principles.
Overall results 13 Continuous increase in amounts to be financed from future budgets Among the main features of the EU's budget and financial management in 2013 are: ο a strong increase in the volume of payments to be made by the Commission by means of amending budgets: 9.6% of the initial budget; ο a sustained increase in commitments to be made in the future (by 2.6%) despite the high volume of payments; ο an unchanged period (on average more than two years) between the date of the initial commitment and the date of the Commission's acceptance of the declarations of expenditure; ο only 37 % of the appropriations made available to financial instruments had been paid to final beneficiaries at the end of 2012; ο repayments, interest and dividends of EUR 259 million accumulated since 2008 were not recognised as revenue.
What are obligations and payments?
The EU budget consists of two elements: commitments (in current or future years) and payments (covering the current year of payments).
Payments can only be made against valid commitments.
The annual ceilings for commitments and payments are laid down in the multiannual financial framework agreed by the Council and Parliament.
The nature of EU spending programmes, in particular the long period between commitment and payment, puts increasing pressure on future payment budgets.
This is reflected in a significantly higher budget for payments in 2013, and this trend will continue in a similar way in future budgets.
Overall results 14 How can financial management and management improve the Commission's ability to publish more meaningful information on the functioning of the correction mechanisms (time, origin and nature) and the accuracy of the corresponding figures by recording the information within the traditional accounting systems; ο record and evaluate all financial instruments and financial instruments in line with internationally recognised accounting principles for the public sector, in particular by means of reliable procedures for the identification and recording of impairments; ο provide information on cash to the final beneficiaries until payment; ο prepare and publish a long-term cash flow forecast, which is updated annually; this would make it easier for the stakeholders concerned to identify future payment needs and identify budgetary priorities. ο improve? Would you like to know more?
Full information on the main audit findings can be found in Chapter 1 "Declaration of reliability and related statements" of the annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
Overall results 15 EU funds and results delivery EU funds should be used in accordance with the principles of sound financial management (sparability, soundness and effectiveness).
Against this background, it is necessary to achieve good performance inputs (financial, personnel, material, organisational or regulatory resources required for the implementation of the programme), outputs (to be achieved under the programme), results (immediate changes caused by the programme to the direct actors or the direct beneficiaries) and effects (long-term societal changes, at least partly due to the EU action).
The Court assesses these aspects in its economic audits.
The emphasis is not enough on performance The use of EU funds in the 2007-2013 programming period focused on absorption (use it or lose it – decay in case of non-use) and compliance with legislation and not on good performance.
For example, when selecting projects for EU funding, the need for the use of available EU funding was the first priority, the second was the need to comply with the rules, and the third was the need to achieve results and impacts, and only to a certain extent was the need to achieve results and impacts.
This lack of emphasis on performance is a crucial weak point in the way in which a large part of the EU budget is built.
According to the Commission, the focus of the 2014-2020 programming period is more on performance, with performance-related reserves being the main incentives.
By means of these reserves, the Commission will withhold 6% of the resources allocated to individual Member States until the performance is found to be satisfactory.
However, in practice, input and output indicators will continue to be largely decisive for the release of funds.
The Commission will use result indicators only in a few areas.
Whether performance-related reserves work more effectively will depend on the success of the Commission in negotiating appropriate targets and milestones at the beginning of the programming period and in obtaining accurate, reliable and up-to-date data from Member States in determining whether the targets have been achieved.
The reporting framework is not appropriate for the desired performance culture Performance reporting is spread across several general reports at the general budget level.
These reports do not provide any information on progress towards achieving the Europe 2020 Strategy objectives, nor do they provide a comprehensive overview of the results in the form of EU added value.
However, the fourth evaluation report is a step in the right direction in that it seeks to link the main financial programmes with the available performance information relevant to the Europe 2020 strategy.
At the level of the Commission's individual Directorates-General, the management plans define performance objectives for the policy areas in their respective responsibilities, and report on them in the annual activity reports.
The Court's analysis of the management plans and annual activity reports of the Commission's Directorates-General shows that the assurance of reliability is limited to aspects of regularity and internal control and does not take performance aspects into account.
Moreover, the objectives would be too general to be used for management purposes, and the selected indicators would not always be suitable for performance measurement.
Overall results 16 The added value of EU expenditure is not always demonstrated The 19 special reports adopted by the Court in 2013 deal with a wide range of issues in economic audits and assess whether the EU intervention has been carried out in accordance with the principles of sound financial management (sparability, soundness and effectiveness).
The Court examined the lessons to be learned from its 2013 Special Reports for the development of the new programmes and projects for the 2014-2020 programming period and concluded that ο The EU added value could not always be ensured. ο In several cases, there were potential take-over effects, i.e. the beneficiaries had carried out the activity without EU funding.
Example: European Globalisation Adjustment Fund The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund compensates workers affected by mass redundancies.
The Court noted that one third of the funding was spent on measures that would have been paid by the Member States anyway (Special Report No 7/2013 "Did the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provide an EU added value in the reintegration of redundant workers?").
Example: Risk-Sharing Finance Facility The Commission had not sufficiently demonstrated that the EU funds provided under the Risk-Sharing Finance Facility (Financial Instrument to facilitate access to debt financing in the field of research) resulted in higher investments than the beneficiaries would make without public funds (Special Report No 2/2013 "Did the Commission ensure the efficient implementation of the Seventh Research Framework Programme?").
Overall results 17 Most of the Court's recommendations have been implemented The follow-up to the Court's recommendations made as a result of economic audits is a key part of the accountability cycle and can help to ensure the effective implementation by the Commission of the recommendations contained in the reports.
The Court analysed how the Commission continued to deal with recommendations from eight special reports adopted in 2007-2010, and noted that the Commission had implemented either fully or to a large extent 79 % of the recommendations.
The Court recommends that the Commission: ο The Commission should streamline the framework for its performance reporting in the next revision of the Financial Regulation. ο The Commission should ensure that the evaluation report contains a summary of all available information on progress towards achieving the Europe 2020 objectives. ο The Commission should further develop its performance management and reporting system in order to ensure that it can take responsibility for the sound financial management and the contribution of the EU budget to policy success. ο Would you like to know more?
Full information on the Court's assessment of performance can be found in Chapter 10 on the EU budget and the performance of the annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the 2013 budget.
All special reports are available on the Court's website: http://www.eca.europa.eu/en/ Pages/AuditReportsOpinions.aspx.
The contributions calculated on the basis of the gross national income (GNI) of the Member States and the VAT collected by the Member States accounted for 74% and 10% of the revenue respectively in 2013.
Import duties and the sugar production levy levied by the authorities in the Member States on behalf of the EU accounted for 10 % of the EU's revenue, while the remaining 6 % came from other revenue.
Explanation on the audit of EU revenue EU revenue based on GNI and VAT is calculated on the basis of macroeconomic statistics and estimates provided by Member States.
The Court's audit of the regularity of the underlying transactions relates to the Commission's processing of these data, but not to the initial collection of these data by the authorities in the Member States.
Consequently, the Court's conclusion on the audit concerns the impact on the total amount of revenue of the Commission's errors.
As regards customs duties, the Court is examining the way in which the Commission deals with the reports submitted by the Member States on the claims found.
These data are not sufficiently harmonised among Member States.
A reservation is an instrument which allows the possibility of correction to be kept open for a disputed element in the GNI data transmitted by a Member State.
There is a general reservation regarding the Greek GNI data for 2008 and 2009, as the data are still based on provisional estimates.
This aspect is part of a problem that affects Greece's national accounts.
Detailed examination of revenue and expenditure sectors 19 The customs authorities of the Member States shall carry out checks to verify that importers comply with customs and import requirements.
The Court noted that the quality of these controls was very different in the Member States visited.
This may result in importers deciding to notify goods in a Member State other than the Member State in which they are established in order to reduce the likelihood of a check and to make the levying of the duties due more difficult.
One example that appears to be the case is the case of an importer who unloaded Chinese textiles in Hamburg (Germany) who transported them to Rotterdam, where they were declared for free circulation, to be sent to Poland for final sale.
Our recommendations The Court recommends to the Commission that: ο The Commission should work to ensure that the Member States harmonise their methods for calculating the data on unobserved economic activity. ο The Commission should draw up a detailed action plan with clear milestones and should closely monitor the implementation of the action plan in order to address the problems in the preparation of Greece's economic accounts. ο The Commission should establish minimum standards for the controls of the Member States' customs authorities in order to allow a more targeted focus on high-risk importers. ο Would you like to know more?
Full information on the Court's audit of EU revenue can be found in Chapter 2 of the Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
20 This area of expenditure comprises the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF), one of the two main instruments of the EU's common agricultural policy.
The aim of this policy is to increase the productivity of agriculture, to ensure an adequate standard of living for the agricultural population, to stabilise markets, to ensure supply and to ensure that consumers are supplied at reasonable prices.
Expenditure shall be subject to shared management with Member States.
Yes Estimated error rate: 3.6% (2012: 3.8%) Control systems investigated: Conditionally effective Most expenditure in this area is calculated on the basis of agricultural land.
Many quantifiable errors are the result of inaccuracies in the beneficiaries' applications, the most common being excessive area data (see example).
Example: Overdeclarations – application for aid for non-eligible areas In Germany, Ireland, Greece, France, Poland and Romania*, some areas declared as permanent grassland for which payments were made were, in fact, covered in full or in part with non-eligible vegetation (density of bushes or trees).
No EU aid should have been paid for these non-eligible areas.
In Greece, this error occurred because such areas were classified as eligible grassland and were classified as eligible areas in the agricultural parcel identification system. * Note on the identification of Member States in the examples: the sampling approach used by the Court does not examine operations in each Member State, beneficiary country and/or region each year.
Examples of errors are intended to illustrate the most common types of errors.
They do not form the basis for conclusions on the Member States, beneficiary countries and/or regions concerned.
For all direct EAGF aid schemes, beneficiaries of EU aid are legally obliged to comply with "cross compliance" obligations relating to environmental protection, human, animal and plant health and animal welfare and to the conservation of land in good agricultural and environmental conditions.
If farmers fail to meet these obligations, their aid will be reduced.
In the course of its audits, the Court found that 25 % of the transactions involved in these commitments were infringing.
In the case of a significant number of error cases, the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the error before a refund was requested from the Commission.
If this information had been used to correct errors before the Commission's expenditure had been reported, the estimated error rate in this area would have been 2,5 %.
The Court's analysis of the integrated management and control systems (IPCoS) in four Member States (Germany, Ireland, France and Italy) revealed weaknesses in the administrative control procedures and the quality of the databases in three Member States (Ireland, France and Italy), weaknesses in the quality of on-the-spot checks in two Member States (Germany and Italy), weaknesses in the recovery procedures in two Member States (Ireland and Italy).
In spite of the deficiencies detected during the examination, the IACS contributes significantly to the prevention of errors in the expenditure covered by this system.
In the Member States that joined the EU in 2004 or later, producer groups in the fruit and vegetable sector can receive EU aid.
For recognition as a producer group, certain conditions must be met as regards the number and relative size of the member producers.
The Court found that nine of the 40 producer groups examined in Poland did not meet these conditions.
In its 2013 Annual Activity Report, the Commission reported that it had reserved a risk amount of 25% of the total expenditure under the measure in question in Poland.
Our recommendations The Court makes the following recommendations: ο The Commission and the Member States should take the necessary measures to ensure that the potential of the IACS is fully exploited, for example, to ensure that the eligibility and size of agricultural parcels are properly assessed and assessed. ο The Commission should monitor the corrective measures related to the shortcomings of EU aid for producer groups in Poland. Do you want to know more?
The Court's full information on the Court's audit of EU expenditure on market support and direct payments in the field of agriculture can be found in Chapter 3 of the Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
22 This expenditure covers the policy areas "rural development", "climate and environmental policy", "maritime affairs and fisheries", and "health and consumer protection".
Of the payments in this area, 88% are the responsibility of the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD).
Expenditure is subject to shared management with the Member States.
The EAFRD will co-finance rural development expenditure under relevant programmes in the Member States.
Expenditure covers area-related measures (such as agri-environmental payments and compensation to farmers in areas with natural handicaps) and non-area-related measures (such as modernisation of agricultural holdings and basic services to the rural economy and the population).
Yes Estimated error rate: 6.7% (2012: 7.9%) Control systems under investigation: As a condition of effectiveness Most errors were due to the fact that the conditions for aid were not met, in particular the following conditions: agri-environmental obligations (see example), particular requirements for investment projects and procurement rules.
Example: non-compliance with agri-environmental obligations A farmer in Sardinia (Italy) received compensation for the non-use of polluting plant protection products for the cultivation of artichokes.
During its on-the-spot checks, the Court found that the beneficiary had used such plant protection products 12 times during the period under review.
Therefore, the payment of aid was not eligible.
Similar cases of non-compliance with agri-environmental commitments have also been identified in the Piedmont region (Italy) and in Hungary, the Netherlands, Poland and Romania.
Detailed analysis of revenue and expenditure sectors 23 In the case of a significant number of errors, the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the error before a refund was requested from the Commission.
If this information had been used to correct errors before the Commission's expenditure had been reported, the estimated error rate in this area would have been 2.0 %.
The Court's investigation of the control systems for rural development revealed the following: ο shortcomings in the control of the conditions for aid, for example, non-recovery of non-eligible VAT amounts or the risk of double financing (in seven of the eight Member States examined – Germany, Spain, Italy, Latvia, Malta, Romania and Slovenia; Poland was the exception); ο inadequate assessment of the plausibility of costs (in all four Member States examined – Italy, Latvia, Poland and Romania); ο shortcomings in the design and implementation of cross-compliance controls (in all four of the Member States examined – the Czech Republic, Spain, Italy and Malta); the cross-compliance obligations require beneficiaries to meet specific conditions, for example environmental and social standards, in order to qualify for aid; ο shortcomings in the control of the award rules (in all three Member States examined – Italy, Latvia and Poland; see for example).
For example, insufficient controls on the procurement rules by the Member State In Latvia, the paying agency was the beneficiary of an EAFRD grant of EUR 2 million to finance its outsourced IT system, which was subject to public procurement rules.
The Court noted that several serious errors had occurred in the procurement of the IT system and the subsequent data files.
For example, instead of an open or restricted procedure, as provided for in the legislation, the paying agency applied a negotiation procedure.
Due to non-compliance with the procedures, expenditure is not eligible for EU funding.
Our recommendations The Court makes the following recommendations for rural development: ο Member States should improve the implementation of their existing administrative controls by using all relevant information available to the paying agencies.
In this way, the majority of the errors could be detected and corrected. ο Member States should ensure that the Action Plans, aimed at addressing the high estimated level of rural development, include all regions and take into account all measures, in particular investment measures, and that they take account of the Commission and the Court's audit findings. Do you want to know more?
The Court's full information on the Court's audit of EU rural, environmental, fisheries and health expenditure can be found in Chapter 4 of the Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
A closer look at the revenue and expenditure areas of regional policy, transport and energy EUR 45.5 billion Subject of our audit 24 This audit covered regional policy (which accounts for 96% of the payments in this area of expenditure), mainly financed by the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) and the Cohesion Fund (CF).
The aim of regional policy is to strengthen economic and social cohesion in the European Union by reducing the disparities in development between the different regions.
Expenditure on regional policies is subject to shared management by the Commission and the Member States and is co-financed by approved expenditure programmes.
The remaining 4% of this audited expenditure is covered by transport and energy policies.
Transport and energy policy aims to provide European citizens and businesses with safe, sustainable and competitive transport and energy systems and services.
These expenditure shall be managed directly by the Commission.
Yes Estimated likely error rate: 6.9% (2012: 6.8%) Control systems under investigation: Conditionally effective The Court found serious errors in the award of public contracts, accounting for 39% of the Court's estimated error rate.
The cumulative value of the 122 procurement procedures examined is estimated at EUR 4.2 billion.
Example: Unjustified free-hand contracts for additional construction work at the passenger terminal of an airport in Germany were awarded free-hand to the original contractor.
This additional work was necessary because of the work being done, the planning and implementation of the project, and not because of unforeseen circumstances.
In such cases, a free-handed award is inadmissible, which is why the additional work should have been advertised.
Similar cases of unjustified hands-free award were found in projects in Belgium, the Czech Republic, elsewhere in Germany, as well as in Spain, Italy and Sweden.
Further consideration of revenue and expenditure sectors 25 The Court's auditors are also examining whether EU state aid rules are being complied with.
Illegal State aid confers an unjustified advantage on the beneficiary bodies and therefore affects the internal market.
Errors related to State aid accounted for 17% of the estimated error rate in this area (see example).
For example, state aid for a profitable project for a small or medium-sized enterprise (SMEs) in Slovenia has been granted for research and development in the automotive industry.
However, the SME was wholly owned by large companies and carried out its research activities exclusively for them.
As more stringent public funding rules apply to large companies, the company was not entitled to all the funding.
Similar cases were found in Bulgaria and Hungary.
In the case of a significant number of errors, the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the errors before the Commission had been requested to obtain them.
If this information had been used to correct errors before the Commission's expenditure had been reported, the estimated error rate in this area would have been 3,9 %.
The Court's auditors also noted that in 2013 financial instruments continued to receive low rates of disbursement to final beneficiaries.
The funds concerned support companies or urban development projects through equity investments, loans or guarantees.
The funds will be provided when their legal structure has been established and will then be used to support projects.
A total of 940 financial instruments have been set up in 25 Member States, with a budget of around EUR 12.6 billion.
Our recommendations The Court recommends to the Commission the following: ο The Commission should require the Member States to confirm in their administrative declarations the effectiveness of the primary controls carried out by the managing authority and the certifying authority. ο The Commission should, as required by the Financial Regulation, carry out a thorough assessment of the ongoing problem of primary controls carried out by authorities in the Member States during the 2007-2013 programming period. ο The Commission should analyse the reasons for the frequency of breaches of EU state aid rules. ο The Commission should reduce the ongoing delays in disbursing EU funds through financial instruments. ο Would you like to know more?
The Court's full information on the Court's audit of EU expenditure on regional policy, transport and energy can be found in Chapter 5 of the Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
Further consideration of the income and expenditure areas of employment and social affairs 16.2 billion euros Subject of our audit 26 The audit covered the expenditure area of employment and social affairs, which forms part of the EU's cohesion policy.
The main objectives of spending in this area are to combat unemployment, to develop human resources and to promote integration into the labour market.
Employment and social policy is mainly implemented through the European Social Fund (ESF): 98% of the payments made in 2013 in this area of expenditure were to the detriment of the Fund.
The ESF will support investment in human capital in the form of training and other employment measures.
In a private school in Portugal, the full salary of the school director was charged to the EU project, although he also had other tasks to perform.
Furthermore, the ceiling for co-financing salaries has not been respected.
The Court also found similar findings in projects in Germany, Spain, Italy, Poland and the United Kingdom.
In the case of a significant number of cases of error, the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the error before the Commission had been requested to obtain it.
If this information had been used to correct errors before the Commission's expenditure had been reported, the estimated error rate in this area would have been 1.8%.
Further consideration of revenue and expenditure areas 27 On the recommendation of the Court and with the aim of reducing the likelihood of errors and administrative burdens for the promoters, the application of lump sums and flat rates was extended in 2009 instead of the reimbursement of ‘actual costs'.
In its 2013 audit, the Court did not detect any quantifiable errors in relation to the application of lump sums and lump sums.
This suggests that projects whose costs are reported using such payment options are less error-prone.
Our recommendations The Court recommends to the Commission that: ο The Commission should encourage Member States to strengthen controls on procurement rules, non-project-related costs or projects without EU added value. ο The Commission should ensure that the Member States address the problem that the costs of EU projects are raised at higher rates than those of national projects. ο The Commission should ensure that the Member States have taken into account all the simplification possibilities provided for in the regulations for the European Structural and Investment Funds for the 2014-2020 period. Do you want to know more?
Full information on the Court's audit of EU expenditure on employment and social affairs can be found in Chapter 6 of the Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for the 2013 budget.
28 This expenditure covers expenditure on external relations, development and humanitarian assistance, and on actions for candidate and candidate countries.
Development projects are spread across more than 150 countries around the world and implementation bodies vary considerably in size and experience.
Support for EU funding projects is conditional on compliance with conditions laid down in specific financing agreements, as well as compliance with other requirements, for example with regard to tendering and procurement procedures.
Expenditure is managed either directly by the Commission's Directorates-General – by the Commission's central services in Brussels or by the EU delegations in the beneficiary countries – or jointly with international organisations.
Yes Estimated error rate: 2.6% (2012: 3.3%) Control systems under investigation: Conditional effect Most errors related to ineligible expenditure incurred at the level of the final beneficiaries, such as expenditure incurred outside the eligibility period, the inclusion of ineligible expenditure in project cost statements (e.g. VAT, unjustified personnel costs or overheads) and the expenditure not supported by adequate supporting evidence.
The Commission validated pre-accession expenditure for a total of EUR 150 million, although it was not confirmed by evidence that the expenditure was incurred and eligible.
The validated amounts were based on Commission estimates rather than on incurred, paid and accepted costs, supported by relevant evidence.
Following the Court's detection of this systematic error, the Commission corrected the accounting operations in question.
Example: Unconducted expenditure The Commission signed an agreement of EUR 9.5 million with the United Nations Development Programme to promote social development in Moldova.
In 2013, the Commission accepted contracts worth EUR 1.8 million for reimbursement for which no underlying expenditure had yet been incurred.
More information on revenue and expenditure sectors 29 Commission Directorate-General EuropeAid manages most of the EU's expenditure in the area of external action in the budget.
The EuropeAid systems studied are considered to be partially effective.
In May 2013, EuropeAid adopted an action plan to address the main identified shortcomings.
Our recommendations The Court recommends to the Commission the following: ο The Commission should ensure that the instructions to staff indicate that the final management of expenditure should be based only on expenditure actually incurred and should not be based on own estimates.
The Commission has already agreed to a corresponding change in its procedure for the final management of expenditure. Would you like to know more?
Full information on the Court's external relations, external assistance and enlargement audit can be found in Chapter 7 of the Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
30 The main component of this expenditure area is research and innovation projects, which accounted for EUR 7.7 billion in payments in 2013.
The other internal policies concern spending on a number of policy objectives, including education and culture, security, migration and measures to address the consequences of the financial crisis.
The majority of expenditure is managed directly by the Commission.
Yes Estimated error rate: 4.6% (2012: 3.9%) Control systems under investigation: conditionally effective With most payments in this area of expenditure, the Commission will reimburse the costs claimed by beneficiaries in project cost statements.
Errors arise when beneficiaries report ineligible costs that are not detected by the control systems prior to reimbursement by the Commission.
35% of the estimated error rate is due to incorrectly calculated or ineligible personnel costs.
Among other things, the estimated and not the actual personnel costs and working hours, which were not spent on the project, are claimed.
Apart from non-compliance with the expenditure rules, the reimbursement of ineligible costs is also hampered by the successful implementation of the policy objectives and thus limits the added value of EU support (see example).
Example: Ineligible expenditure reduces EU added value The EU provides funding to ensure efficient and effective controls at EU external borders.
The Court examined a project in Spain involving the purchase of four helicopters, which were to be used 75% for the surveillance and control of the external borders.
The Court noted, however, that only 25 % of the hours of operation of the helicopters were accounted for by this purpose.
As a result, the EU should have paid only 25%, not the 75% actually paid for the helicopters.
Detailed analysis of revenue and expenditure sectors 31 In the framework of the control system for research expenditure, the Commission controls progress reports and cost statements for funded projects before payments are made.
The Court noted that the Commission did not always apply the procedures in a uniform manner, which could affect the efficiency of the programmes and increase the administrative burden on the beneficiaries.
Our recommendations The Court recommends to the Commission the following: ο The Commission should provide the beneficiaries and the authorities in the Member States with timely, coherent and clear guidance on eligibility rules and control rules for the new research programmes for the period 2014-2020 (Horizon 2020) and other internal policies. ο The Commission should make its control activities more risk-oriented by focusing the audits on high-risk beneficiaries (e.g., less experienced institutions with EU support) and reducing the burden on less-risk beneficiaries from controls.
Would you like to know more?

Staff expenditure (contributions, allowances and pensions) accounts for 60% of the expenditure, and expenditure on buildings, equipment, energy, communications and information technology accounts for the remainder.

Our recommendations The Court recommends the following: ο The Commission and the EEAS should take further steps to ensure that the parts of the staff files that affect the payment of salaries and allowances are up-to-date. ο The EEAS should support and guide EU delegations on procurement procedures.

Further consideration of the revenue and expenditure areas of the European Development Fund (EDF) 2.6 billion euros Subject of our audit 33 Under the EDF, the European Union grants funds for development cooperation with the African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP States) and the overseas countries and territories (OCTs).
It will also promote sustainable development and the integration of the ACP States and OCTs into the global economy.
The EDFs are financed by the Member States and are subject to their own financial regulation and are managed by the European Commission outside the general budget of the EU.
The environment in which external assistance financed by the EDF is implemented is at high risk, in particular by the fact that the activities are geographically dispersed and that the partner countries do not have sufficient institutional and administrative capacity.
Our findings Reliability of EDF accounting: the annual accounts of the EDFs in 2013 constitute the asset and financial position of the EDFs, the results of their operations, their cash flows and the changes in the net assets of the EDF as a whole, and constitute a significant error in EDF revenue?
No Control systems under investigation: Does EDF commitments have a significant impact on errors?
Yes Estimated error rate: 3.4% (2012: 3.0%) Failure to comply with procurement rules was the cause of around half of the estimated error rate (see example).
Another significant source of error is the lack of evidence to support expenditure.
Example: Non-compliance with the procurement rules by the beneficiary The Court examined an invitation to tender for IT equipment for a business information centre, financed by a micro and small business support programme.
The test showed that the contract was not awarded to the tenderer with the lowest price offer, although the lowest price was the award criterion.
The error was not detected by the auditor who audited the programme in accordance with the relevant framework agreement with the Commission.
More detailed analysis of revenue and expenditure sectors 34 The EDFs will also provide budget support where payments flow directly into the budget of a developing country, provided that specific conditions are met.
The Court found errors in transactions relating to budget support where the fulfilment of the conditions had been misassessed and where the wrong exchange rate had been applied to the conversion of the payment into the local currency.
Commission Directorate-General EuropeAid manages not only the bulk of external aid expenditure from the EU budget, but also almost all expenditure under the European Development Fund (EDF).
The EuropeAid systems examined are considered to be partially effective.
However, in May 2013, EuropeAid adopted an action plan to address the main shortcomings identified.
Our recommendations The Court recommends to the Commission that: ο The Commission should recover interest on pre-financing. ο The Commission should review the quantification of the benefits of the controls carried out. ο The Commission should report on the progress made in implementing the action plan to remedy shortcomings in the control system.

Background information 35 The audit approach at a glance The Court's audit opinions in the context of the Statement of Assurance are based on objective evidence obtained in particular through audit procedures carried out in accordance with international audit principles.
The EU budget is complex.
The Commission's Directorates-General arrange hundreds of thousands of entries each year based on data from many different sources (including the Member States).
The Court shall examine whether the accounting procedures are working properly and whether the resulting accounting data are properly recorded and recorded in order to determine whether they are working properly. ο Analytical audits of accounting data in order to determine whether they are consistent and plausible. ο Direct verification of a sample of accounting entries to determine whether the underlying procedures are actually in place and correctly recorded. ο Audit of annual accounts to determine whether they represent the financial situation correctly.
1 Payments recorded as expenditure are intermediate payments, final payments and advance payments.
In the course of the implementation of the EU budget, millions of payments are made to beneficiaries within the EU and the rest of the world.
Most of these expenditures are managed by the Member States.
In order to obtain the necessary evidence, the Court conducts direct audits of revenue and expenditure, and assesses the systems by which payments are processed and controlled.

Background information 37 The European Court of Auditors and its work The European Court of Auditors (ECA) is the independent audit body of the European Union based in Luxembourg.
It employs around 900 staff from all EU nationalities, composed of auditors and staff in horizontal services.
Since its establishment in 1977, it has raised awareness of the importance of EU financial management and has contributed to its improvement.
The Court's audit reports and opinions are an important link in the EU's accountability chain.
Our results are used to hold the bodies responsible for the EU's financial management accountable, in particular in the discharge procedure.
This is mainly the Commission, but it also affects the other EU institutions, bodies and agencies.
Member States also play an important role in shared management.

Background information 38 Our results We present the following results: ο Annual reports on the EU general budget and on the European Development Funds; the annual reports mainly include audit opinions in the context of the Statement of Assurance and the results of the audit reports and will be published annually in November; ο Special annual reports on audit opinions on the accounts of the various EU agencies and other bodies; 53 reports to be published in 2014; ο Special reports on selected audit topics to be published throughout the year; these will mainly be economic audits; approximately 25 reports to be published in 2014; ο Opinions to be used by the European Parliament and the Council in the adoption of EU legislation with significant implications for financial management; ο Six opinions to be published in 2014; ο Landscape analyses on selected areas of EU policy in which the major challenges and long-term trends will be analysed; ο The annual activity report, the information and explanations on our activities in the year under review will be published in 2014; ο The annual activity report, the information and the explanations of our activities in the year under review.

2 INTRODUCTION 1. The Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (hereinafter referred to as "the Agency") based in Ljubljana was established by Regulation (EC) No 713/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council1.
The Agency's main task is to assist national regulatory authorities to fulfil the regulatory tasks performed in the Member States at Union level and to coordinate, where necessary, the actions of those authorities.
Under the Regulation on the integrity and transparency of the wholesale energy market (REMIT Regulation)2, the Agency, together with the national regulatory authorities, will be given additional tasks with regard to the monitoring of the wholesale European energy market3.
As regards the financial year 2011, the period from 8 March to 31 December 2011 was therefore examined.

3 DECLARATION OF RELIABILITY 4. In accordance with Article 287 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, the Court has examined the Agency's annual accounts4 consisting of the "annual accounts"5 and the "annual accounts"6 for the financial year ending 31 December 2011 and the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying the accounts.
Management responsibility 5.InitsfunctionasInstructionsmanaging director.The budget in revenue and expenditure in accordance with the Agency's financial regulation.
The Director shall be responsible for the establishment8 of the organisational structure and of the internal management and control systems and procedures necessary to enable the establishment of a financial statement9 which shall be free of material misrepresentations, intended or unintended, 4 5 6 7 8 9 The annual accounts shall be accompanied by a report on the financial management and management of the financial year concerned, which shall include additional information on financial management and management.
The annual financial statements include the financial statement and the financial statement, the cash flow table, the table of changes in net assets and a summary of the main accounting policies and other explanatory notes.

6.The responsibility ofthe auditor 6.The responsibility ofthe Court of Justice to provide the European Parliament and the Council10 with a statement of assurance on the reliability of the Agency's accounts and on the legality and regularity of its underlying transactions.
7. The Courthas carried out an audit in accordance with the International Standards on Auditing as well as the professional conduct requirements of IFAC and the International Standards for Supreme Audit Institutions of INTOSAI.
These standards require the Court to plan and carry out the audit in such a way as to provide sufficient assurance as to whether the Agency's annual accounts are free of material misrepresentations and whether the underlying transactions are lawful and proper.
8.A statutory audit shall include the implementation of audit acts in order to obtain audit evidence of the value estimates and other information contained in the annual accounts and of the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
The selection of audit acts is at the discretion of the examiner. This includes the assessment of the risks of material - intended or unintended - misrepresentations in the financial statements as well as of material - intended or unintended - infringements of the European Union legislation in the underlying transactions.
In assessing these risks, the auditor shall take into account the internal control system relevant to the preparation and appropriate overall presentation of the financial statements and the 5 monitoring and control systems established to ensure the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions to plan audit activities that are appropriate in the circumstances.
An audit shall also include an assessment of the adequacy of the accounting policies used and the representativeness of the estimated values in the accounting and an assessment of the overall presentation of the financial statements.
9.The Court considers that the evidence obtained is sufficient and appropriate to serve as the basis for the following audit opinions.
10.According to the Court's assessment, the Agency's annual accounts11 shall, as at 31 December 2011, reflect its financial and financial situation and the results of its operations and cash flows for the financial year ending on that date, in accordance with its financial rules and the accounting rules adopted by the Commission's accounting officer12, in all material respects.
11 12 The final annual accounts were drawn up on 19 June 2012 and were received by the Court on 2 July 2012.
The final annual accounts consolidated with the Commission's annual accounts shall be published in the Official Journal of the European Union on 15 November of the following year.
The annual accounts are available at the following addresses: http://eca.europa.eu or http://ww.acer.europa.eu/.
The accounting rules adopted by the Commission's accounting officer are based on the International Public Sector Accounting Standards (IPSAS) issued by the International Federation of Accountants (IFAC) or on the International Accounting Standards (IAS) or the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) issued by the International Accounting Standards Board in the case of operations for which there are no IPSAS standards.
In addition, the payment rate was low in relation to the commitments, with 41 % each for Titles II and III.
The high level of unused appropriations and transfers and the low payment rate indicate shortcomings in the planning and implementation of the budget and constitute a breach of the budgetary principle of annuality.
OTHER COMMENTS 14.The transparency of recruitment procedures needs to be improved.
For example, the vacancy notices did not specify the maximum number of candidates to be included in a reserve list, nor did they contain any appeals.
7 the written and oral exams and their respective weights are not prepared prior to the examination of the applications.
15.In 2011, the Agency paid daily allowances of EUR 10 839 to seconded experts who were nationals of the country in which the Agency is based.
This payment is contrary to the rules adopted by the Agency's Management Board for the secondment of national experts to the effect that only temporary staff who are not nationals of the Member State in which they are employed are entitled to daily allowances.

8 Annex Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (Ljubljana) Union competence under the Treaty (Article 114 (ex Article 95 TEC) and Article 194 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union) Responsibilities of the Agency (Regulation (EC) No 713/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council; Commission Regulation (EU) No 838/2010; Regulation (EU) No 1227/2011 of the European Parliament and of the Council) Responsibilities and activities The European Parliament and the Council, acting in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure and after consulting the Economic and Social Committee, shall adopt measures for the approximation of the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States relating to the establishment and functioning of the internal market.
The Union's energy policy, in a spirit of solidarity between the Member States, in the context of the achievement or functioning of the internal market, and taking into account the need to preserve and improve the environment, pursues the following objectives: (a) to ensure the functioning of the energy market; (b) to ensure the security of energy supply in the Union; (c) to promote energy efficiency and energy savings; and the development of new and renewable energy sources; and (d) to promote the interconnection of energy networks.
The European Parliament and the Council shall adopt, in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure, the measures necessary to achieve the objectives.
These measures shall be adopted after consultation of the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions.
Objectives The purpose of the Agency is to assist the national regulatory authorities to fulfil the regulatory tasks performed in the Member States at Union level and, where necessary, to coordinate their actions.
Tasks - supplementing and coordinating the work of national regulatory authorities - participating in the development of rules on European networks - under certain conditions, making binding individual decisions on the modalities of access and operational security of cross-border infrastructures, - advising the European institutions on energy-related issues, - monitoring of developments in energy markets and related reporting, - drawing up a proposal addressed to the European Commission on the annual compensation amount for cross-border infrastructures under the ITC mechanism, - cooperation with national regulatory authorities, ESMA, the competent financial authorities of the Member States and, where appropriate, national competition authorities for the monitoring of wholesale energy markets, - assessing the functioning and transparency of different categories of marketplaces and different types of trade, - making recommendations to the Commission on market rules, recording transactions, trade orders, standards and procedures to improve the integrity of the market and the functioning of the internal market.
The Management Board Composition: The Management Board consists of two members appointed by the European Parliament, two members appointed by the Commission and five members appointed by the Council.
Each member shall have an alternate.

ACER - Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators ACER - Agence de coopération des régulateurs de l'énergie ANSWERS TO THE AGENCY 13. In the first year of its activity, ACER had to recruit a large part of its staff, which had problems and led to job vacancies being filled late, which was clearly reflected in the use rate of the Agency's budget.
This also affected the estimated procurement needs and resulted in the procurement procedures focusing on the end of the year, thus requiring large transfers in order to meet the legal and budgetary commitments made.
As most posts were filled at the beginning of 2012, ACER is now in a much better position to carry out the tasks entrusted to it and to carry out the related budget.
14. ACER takes note of the justification of the Court's observations and has already taken corrective action.
15. ACER takes note of the justification of the provisional finding and has already stopped the daily allowance payments to Slovenian ANS.

C 449/20 Official Journal of the European Union 1.12.2016 EN Court of Auditors comment The Agency carried over EUR 1.57 million and 62 % of the appropriations committed under Title III (operational expenditure) to the following financial year (2013: EUR 3.1 million and 91%).
These transfers were mainly related to the implementation of the REMIT Regulation, a complex multi-annual operational activity to which the implementing regulation was only adopted on 17 December 2014 (1).
The Agency also transferred EUR 0.98 million or 41% (2013: EUR 1.9 million or 56%) of the appropriations committed under Title II (administrative expenditure) to the following financial year. These transfers concerned mainly studies of the implementation of the REMIT Regulation and of the annual appropriations for the implementation of the REMIT Regulation at the end of the year.
In October 2013, the Agency received an additional EUR 3 million for the implementation of the REMIT Regulation through an amending budget, which it transferred to 2014.
However, the REMIT framework will only apply from October 2015 onwards.
Part of the funding was used in 2014 to prepare the implementation of the REMIT Regulation.
At the end of 2014, the Agency provided two pre-financing payments of EUR 1.56 million for the sale of services related to the REMIT Regulation, to be provided in the years 2015-2017, thus avoiding the automatic repayment of unused funds to the Commission(2).
Although the Agency can thereby finance its future REMIT-related activities, this approach is in contradiction with the budgetary principle of annuality.
The agreement between the Agency and the Slovenian Government is to establish a European School in Slovenia, but this has still not happened more than four years after the agreement was concluded.

COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 17. In its May 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) stressed the urgent need to clarify roles and responsibilities and to analyse the workload of the contracting authority in order to increase the efficiency of the processes and procedures.
The IAS also concluded that the planning and monitoring of procurement must be significantly improved.
The Agency and IAS agreed on a plan for corrective measures.
COMMENTS ON BUDGETARY CURRENCY 18. The Agency transferred EUR 4.9 million and 86 % of the appropriations committed under Title III (operational expenditure) to the following financial year (2015: EUR 1.4 million and 59 %).
As in previous years, these transfers were mainly linked to the implementation of the REMIT Regulation on the integrity and transparency of the energy wholesale market(7) and amounted to 4.7 million euros in 2016 (2015: 1.1 million euros).
For Title II (Administrative expenditure), the Agency transferred EUR 1 million and 38% of the committed appropriations to the following financial year (2015: EUR 0.8 million and 35% respectively).
19. The increase in transfers of funds is of concern and is contrary to the budgetary principle of annuality.
The higher transfer rate is directly linked to the conclusion or signing of the procurement procedures and procedures by the end of the year, leading to a shift of deliveries and/or payments to the following year.
In 2016, 98 out of a total of 299 sales were signed in November and December (5 976 122.47 euros and 40 % of the total value of the sales closed in 2016 respectively).
The Agency may use separate budget appropriations to better accommodate the multi-annual nature of the activities and the inevitable delays between the signing of contracts, deliveries and payments.

The Court examined the financial statements of the European Centre for the Development of Vocational Training for the financial year ending 31 December 1995.
In accordance with Article 18(1) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76 (OJ No L 316, 18.12.1976, p.
15), the budget was implemented under the responsibility of the Management Board.
In accordance with Articles 65, 61 and 68 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76, as amended by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1948/93, the latter shall also be responsible for drawing up and presenting the financial statements in accordance with the financial rules.
The Court of Auditors is required to examine these financial statements in accordance with Article 188c of the Treaty establishing the European Community.
The European Council of 29 October 1993 decided to transfer Cedefop's headquarters from Berlin to Thessaloniki.
In order to facilitate this move, certain changes have been made to the conditions of employment of the staff, some of which were not in accordance with the existing regulations.
The exact circumstances are explained in paragraphs 46 - 66.
In addition, a number of other cases have been identified where payments were not fully in line with the existing regulations.
5. In the light of the Court's audit, the Court can, with sufficient certainty, establish that the financial statements for paragraphs 10 to 11 of page 12 of the financial statements are reliable for the financial year ending 31 December 1995 to the extent that they accurately reflect the revenue and expenditure of 1995 and the financial situation at the end of the year.
Apart from the important exception in the area of expenditure mentioned in the previous paragraph, the underlying transactions were, as a whole, lawful and proper.
General comments Background 6. The European Centre for the Development of Vocational Training (Cedefop) was established by Council Regulation (EEC) No 337/75 (l) as the European Community's satellite body and is intended to promote vocational training at Community level.
Cedefop began its work in Berlin in 1976 and moved to Thessaloniki in 1995.
It is the task of the Centre, as defined in the said Regulation, to'support the Commission to promote and develop vocational training and continuing training at Community level', to contribute 'to the implementation of a common vocational training policy' and, in particular, to promote the exchange of information and experience.
In the field of vocational training, the Centre has the task, in particular, of "preparing documentation, contributing to the development and coordination of research, ensuring the dissemination of appropriate documentation and information, promoting and supporting initiatives to achieve a coordinated solution (in particular in the field of the alignment of training levels and mutual recognition of certificates) and of a meeting place for the parties concerned". 8. The Centre is managed by a Board of Directors of 48 members (in 1995 the cost of ECU 334 000) and the Council Regulation (EEC) No 337/75, published on 13 February 1975.
The Board of Directors shall elect, from among its members, a Chairperson and three Vice-Chairpersons for a period of one year.
At the time of the audit (May 1996), the Chairman of the Administrative Council was the Director-General of DG XXII — Education, Training and Youth.
The Director of the Centre shall be appointed by the Commission on the basis of a list of candidates submitted by the Board of Directors.
9. In accordance with the basic Regulation, the Director is responsible for the daily management of the Centre, while the Board of Directors is responsible for the overall management of the Centre.
The Management Board shall take decisions, adopt the work programme and the annual report, draw up the revenue and expenditure plan for the previous year and the estimate of revenue and expenditure for the coming year.
The Commission's role, as set out in the basic Regulation, is not only to represent the Commission's interests within the Management Board, but also to adopt the work programme, to examine the annual report and revenue and expenditure and to forward the estimates of revenue and expenditure to the Council and the European Parliament.
(a) the cost of the budget to support Cedefop; (b) the efficient use of human resources and resources; (c) high-quality products which meet the needs of Cedefop's customers; (d) a clear and coherent role in the framework of the European Community's vocational training policy.
Financial data 14. For the 1995 financial year, the Centre had an appropriation of ECU 16.50 million.
The commitments entered into resulted in payments of ECU 10.11 million and transfers to the 1996 financial year of ECU 4.67 million, the balance of which was cancelled at ECU 1.72 million.
From the appropriations carried over from the previous year, ECU 2.16 million was disbursed and ECU 0.29 million cancelled.
Annex 1 to this report gives an analysis of the use made of the appropriations for the financial year and of the appropriations carried over from the financial year 1994.
Annex 2 gives an overview of the budget accounts for the financial year 1995 and of the balance sheet of assets and liabilities as at 31 December 1995.
Comments on the implementation of the budget Separation of activities 15. Following the move to Thessaloniki, the Centre had not yet introduced adequate procedures to separate the activities of the authorising officer, the accounting officer and the imprest administrator until the date of the audit (May 1996).
For example, it was observed that the accounting officer was involved in the accounting of the imprest administrator.
The proportion of payments made without the approval of the financial control is still high (in 1995 it was 60% without the salaries).
The strong use of the paying agency procedure is not in line with the spirit of the financial rules.
A more acceptable practice would be to deal only with current expenditures and expenditures at a low level, where the risk of irregularities is comparatively low, through the paying agency.
Transfers within the budget 17. Transfers between different budget lines amounted to ECU 922,000 in 1995, i.e. 5.6% of the initial budget compared to 10.9% in 1994.
No. C 81/4 EN.-- Official Journal of the European Communities 13. 3.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
18. The Centre did not carry out any transfers of funds between different titles in 1995.
The Court's comment (2) was therefore taken into account last year.
Transfers and cancellations of appropriations 19. The practice of transferring large amounts of appropriations already observed in previous years (3), continued to increase in 1995.
In 1995, only 61% of the final available appropriations were disbursed compared with 73% in 1994.
The proportion of commitments carried over to 1996 was 28% (compared to 23% in 1994).
The proportion of appropriations lost was 10%, compared with 5% in 1994.
Table 1 shows by title the appropriations carried over from the original 1995 budget and their subsequent use.
The transfer of operational expenditure amounted to 53% of the initial appropriations compared to 40% in 1994.
As 8% of operational expenditure fell, the Centre paid only 39% of its 1995 operational budget in 1995.
At the end of the first quarter of 1996, only 34% of the appropriations carried over from 1995 were paid out under Title 3.
The high number of transfers within the budget and the cancellation of appropriations and the large number of transfers to the next financial year suggest that the work programme has not been implemented as planned and that the principles of economic management have been jeopardised.
This fact and the lack of staff (see paragraphs 42 to 45) will have a serious impact on the implementation of the 1996 budget.
