Expenditure 23. After a decision to move the Centre to Thessaloniki, a new Deputy Director was appointed in 1994, who lived and worked in Thessaloniki at the time.
Staff moved to Berlin and received an institution aid equivalent to twice the basic salary. Not even one year later, i.e. after the move of the centre to Thessaloniki, the same staff received an institution aid equivalent to twice the basic salary.
As the transfer of the Centre took place quickly, the stay of the operator concerned in Berlin took place only in a short time (11 months); in addition, he spent part of the time in Thessaloniki, in addition to receiving the full daily allowances (including weekends); the Court considers that these decisions are not in line with the principle of sound financial management and are contrary to the principles of Cedefop's financial management.
24. The contract of another deputy director, who had already moved from Berlin to Madrid in July 1995', was signed by the Board of Directors with effect from 3 January 1995.
This staff member received a payment of ECU 71 030.
The Court considers that this decision of the Board of Directors is not in line with the principles of economic governance.
25. Article 46 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76 of 1 June 1976, as amended by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1948/93 of 30 June 1993, permits the award of a contract by contract where the total amount of the contract does not exceed ECU 12 000.
At least 12 cases have been awarded for a higher amount than ECU 12 000 without compliance with the procedure for awarding contracts described in Article 45 of the said Regulation.

The Centre is therefore responsible for managing large amounts of cash, although it has little expertise in this area.
The Court reiterates its remark made last year (6) that this situation should be avoided by making the Centre more adaptable to the Commission's actual cash needs on a quarterly basis. - At the same time, the Commission should ensure that it receives a realistic liquidity forecast from the Centre before making its payments.
The Centre was transferred to Thessaloniki General comments ^B 31. The European Council of 29 October 1993 decided to transfer Cedefop's headquarters from Berlin to Thessaloniki in Greece (7).
32. The actual transfer to Thessaloniki took place in August 1995 and in September 1995 the Centre began to operate in Greece.
According to the Court's calculations, the 1995 budget accounts contain about ECU 3 300 000 for the expenditure related to the move.
33. Since 1 September 1995, the Centre has been housed in a building of the Institute of Agriculture and Industry of Thessaloniki.
By 1 September 1999 at the latest, the Greek State will provide the Centre with a permanent accommodation facility.
The Centre has signed four agreements (i) Annual report of the Court for the 1994 financial year.
(6) Annual report of the Court of Auditors for the financial year 1994.
(7) Council Decision 93/C 323/01 of 29 October 1993, OJ C 323 of 30.11.1993, p. 1.
The basic agreement between Cedefop and the Greek State was signed in Thessaloniki on 22 June 1995.
The three other agreements, including an agreement between the Greek State and the organisation responsible for the whole construction, form part of this basic agreement.
Provisional accommodation 34. An annual rent of 273,000 ECU must be paid for the provisional building of the Centre, which can be paid directly to the owner.
35. In accordance with Article 1 of the Agreement between the Greek State and the Centre, the Greek State shall make the building with the provisional premises, including all associated installations, available to Cedefop from 1 September 1995.
The Greek authorities are responsible for electrical and electronic cable connections and for telephone connections.
36. At the handover of the building the Centre did not raise any written objections.
However, during the first four months of Thessaloniki (September to December 1995), the Centre had to invest ECU 120 000 to make the temporary premises of the building workable.
Among other things, electronic and electrical cable connections and telephone connections had to be installed.
37. These investments were fully borne by the Centre and the corresponding costs were included in the 1995 budget.
The agreements do not give a clear indication of who has to take over these investments.
The Greek State is obliged to provide the Centre with a permanent accommodation building by 1 September 1999 at the latest.
Cedefop will pay the Greek State a total amount of 6 879 750 ECU for the construction of the building, which will be paid in four equal instalments of 1 719 937 ECU each.
The first three instalments were fixed as payment dates for 1 September 1995, 1 September 1996 and 1 September 1997.
The final instalment shall be paid at the final handover of the building.
39. The Centre did not ensure that these payments were linked to the actual progress of the works.
The Centre will have paid ECU 5 159 811 more than two years before the building was handed over.
The Court recommends that the Centre should ensure that the interest is used for the first tranche for the benefit of the Community.

Staff: General comments 42. The 1995 establishment plan provides for 79 posts, 24A,11LA,15B,26Cund3D.At the time of the audit (May 1996) 37 persons actually worked for Cedefop (14A, 7B, 14C and 2D), 11 had been taken over by other EU institutions, 14 had left the centre before moving to Thessaloniki, and 17 had left to stay in Berlin.
In 1995 and 1996, many new employees had to be recruited and this development will continue in 1996.
The 17 remaining persons in Berlin are free to work for public and private institutions or other EU institutions and continue to receive their salary for up to a maximum of 18 months, depending on their seniority at Cedefop (each year is equivalent to one month's salary and the minimum period of service must be 6 months).
At the end of this period, the parties concerned may either move to Thessaloniki or seek another solution.
This situation means, among other things, that Cedefop cannot fill these 17 posts (May 1996) since they are blocked in the budget and cannot be filled, since the parties concerned may, at a later stage, decide to move to Thessaloniki.
44. It is unclear what is to happen to those of this group of 17 people who do not wish to move to Thessaloniki after the specified duration of their stay in Berlin.
Article 20 of the Staff Regulations provides that 'the official shall take the place of his official's official's place of employment or of such distance from that place of residence that he is not disabled in the performance of his duties'.
Independently of this, three cases of officials who were not ready to move to Thessaloniki have already been brought to the EU Court of Justice.
This situation, where 17 important posts in the budget are blocked by staff who are not currently working for Cedefop, has had a significant impact on the Centre's work in 1995 and will continue to do so in 1996 and 1997.
Staff: Amendment of the status of 46. I n Article 13 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 337/75 of 10 February 1975, as amended by Council Regulation (EC) No 251/95 of 6 February 1995, states: 'The staff of the Centre shall be subject to the regulations and regulations applicable to officials and other servants of the European Communities.
The Centre shall exercise over its staff the powers conferred on the Appointing Authority.
The Management Board of the Centre shall, after consulting the Commission, lay down the relevant implementing rules."
Council Regulation (EC) No 251/95 also repeals Council Regulation (ECSC, EEC, Euratom) No 1859/76 of 29 June 1976 laying down the conditions of employment for the staff of the European Centre for the Development of Vocational Training.
The amendment was necessary to "consistently manage the staff of the various decentralised bodies (...) at Community level" (8).
While the staff of the Centre were appointed as officials, the staff of the other decentralised bodies were made up of temporary staff.
47. The Court has examined the changes in the conditions of employment and other agreements between the Board of Directors and the staff and has identified a number of irregularities, and the most serious irregularities from the Court's point of view are described in paragraphs 49-66.
The Management Board has not submitted these agreements to the Financial Controller for approval.
Nevertheless, all the appropriations resulting from these agreements were processed through the paying agency procedure and subsequently received the financial controller's endorsement.
In the context of the move to Thessalosniki, the Centre has taken the following measures to adapt the situation of its staff: — In a first step, on 1 March 1995, all staff members were appointed as temporary staff members (Article 2(b) of the Conditions of Employment of the other staff of the European Communities), in the same grade and grade as as in the contract. — In a second step, these staff members were recruited as EU officials as from 1 April 1995, on the basis of an internal selection procedure, which had, in the end, been ‘ar.' on the basis of qualifications.
Infringement of the Staff Regulations in the context of the classification of seniority in the initial appointment of Cedefop's former contract staff at a later date of 50 years. In the initial appointment of Cedefop's contract staff to temporary staff on 1 March 1995, none of the staff should have been classified in a higher seniority than level 3 (or in seniority 4 in grades A 1 (8) Council Regulation (EC) No 251/95 of 6 February 1995 amending Regulation (EEC) No 337/75 on the establishment of Cedefop, fourth recital).
Official Journal of the European Communities No C 81/7 to A 4, LA 3 and LA 4 (see Article 32 of the Staff Regulations, which are applicable under Article 15 of the Conditions of Employment of Other Servants of Temporary Staff).
51. Nevertheless, 33 of the 59 temporary staff appointed to Cedefop were classified to a higher level than level 3.
The Centre published 15 linked job offers and announcements of internal competitions on 1 March 1995.
The first paragraph of Article 27 of the Staff Regulations provides that all the former staff of Cedefop have been appointed as officials. The purpose of the Staff Regulations is to organise a competition between a number of candidates so that the vacancy can be filled with the best qualified candidate.
A selection procedure is therefore by definition linked to a competitive situation and the risk of non-existence (10).
This means that appointment decisions should be regarded as unlawful following a selection procedure in which a misuse of discretion exists ( n ).
56. The Commission's Legal Service came to the same conclusion as the Commission's memo of 4 January 1995 confirms paragraph (c) (12).
57. Since the selection procedures in question have been the subject of a different objective than the one set out in the Staff Regulations, the selection procedures carried out by Cedefop have been considered to have been subject to abuse of discretion, which is why they have to be regarded as illegal.
Infringement of the Staff Regulations relating to the classification of posts in the grade when appointing Cedefop's former contract staff as officials 58. In accordance with Article 31 of the Staff Regulations, Cedefop's staff should have been appointed as officials as from 1 April 1995 as follows: — officials in category A or in the special course of the language service (LA): in the initial grade of their category or in their special course (i.e. A 7 or LA 7) (Article 31, paragraph 1); — officials in the other categories: in the initial category corresponding to the category of posts for which they have been recruited (i.e. Β 1, Β 3 or Β 5; C 1, C 3 or C 5, D 1, D 3 or D 4) (Article 31, paragraph 2); — in the case of up to half of the appointments, other staff members may be appointed as members in the next higher grade group; this applies to six posts to be filled within each grade group (Article 31, paragraph 2 b).
59. Contrary to the provisions of the Staff Regulations, 32 out of 43 staff were appointed to a higher grade than the initial grade of their career (13).
10. Judgment of 29 September 1976, Case 105/75 GI UFFRI DA v COUNCIL, ECR p. 1395. (n) Judgment of GI UFFRI DA, see above.
(12)A selection procedure involves, by definition, the risk of non-existence, and there are obvious legal reasons why this risk margin should remain.
(13)Of 17 staff members appointed in category A, 13 were appointed in a higher grade than A7 (the Staff Regulations provide for a limitation to six appointments); all five members of staff were appointed in a higher grade than LA7 (the Staff Regulations do not provide for a higher grade); of 18 members of staff in category C, 12 were appointed in a higher grade than the initial grade of their career (the Staff Regulations provide for a limitation to six appointments); two out of three members of staff in category D were appointed in a higher grade than in the initial grade of their career (the Staff Regulations do not provide for a higher grade).
No C 81/8 EN Official Journal of the European Communities 13. 3. 97 Failure to comply with probationary obligations 60. Before a member of staff can be appointed as a member of staff for a lifetime, he must be successful in completing a probationary period (Article 34 of the Staff Regulations) and the probationary period must therefore be followed by an objective and retrospective assessment of the staff member on a probationary basis.
The probationary period was clearly described in advance as necessary 'legal formality' which was not really to be regarded as a probationary test (paragraph 4.1 of the 'framework agreement'; letter of 7 February 1995 to the probationary officials, the second subparagraph, and paragraph 1(f) of the Annex: the probationary period is a legal formality to be performed as such by each official on a probationary basis.
65. This means that a system has been established whereby up to 50% of the remuneration of staff is transferred to Thessaloniki in a currency to which a higher correction coefficient applies (namely the correction coefficient of 111.4%) is applied to Greece (for Greece a correction coefficient of 80.2%).
Inequal treatment with other officials by introducing special mobility provisions 66. The Commission has committed itself to introducing specific provisions on mobility to the Centre.
These provisions are contrary to the principle of equal treatment of all officials.
Article 13 of Council Regulation (EC) No 251/95 of 6 February 1995 clearly provides that the Staff Regulations and the Conditions of Employment of Other Servants shall apply to the staff of the Centre.
This means that all the provisions contained therein shall apply to the staff of the Centre, including the subparagraph of Article 29(1) (c), which concerns the taking over of officials by other institutions.
There is therefore no justification for special treatment in relation to mobility. Summary 67. The Court's audit has shown that the Centre's work programme has not been carried out as planned as a result of significant staff shortages.
This led to large-scale transfers and cancellations.
The audit also showed that no functioning management and accounting procedures have yet been established.
68. Two Deputy Directors received remuneration corresponding to the basic salary for four months; these payments and a payment of ECU 71 030 to one of the Deputy Directors were not in line with sound financial management and the interests of the Centre.
69. At the time of the Court's examination, there were 79 approved posts, but only 37 persons were actually employed at the Centre.
17 officials had been appointed as EU officials,' although they had not wished to move to Thessaloniki, nor had they been taken over by another Community institution.
Conclusion 71. It is understandable that efforts were made to keep staff in the institutions of the EU in connection with the move to Thessaloniki and to reduce the complex problems associated with the move.
The problem, however, is that the regulatory framework, "within which the move had to be carried out, was not compatible with the proper treatment of senior staff, even after the changes to the employment arrangements, and that it did not allow Cedefop to move smoothly without noticing its activities.
This report was adopted by the Court of Auditors at its meeting in Luxembourg on 21 November 1996.

The Management Board will follow the structure of the Court of Auditors' observations and conclusions.
The Management Board has the right to expect that all institutions and decentralised bodies will be treated in the same way and on the basis of the same technical standards and procedures that ensure equal treatment.
The Management Board considers that the uniform presentation of the problems fails to mention the essential facts which could be summarised as follows: — the decision of the European Council of 29 October 1993 was taken without prior assessment of the effects of such a transfer.
At his first meeting with the staff, he expressed his firm determination to move to 1 September 1995, a timetable which CEDEFOP maintained despite the problems caused by the transfer of the Centre. — The Chairman of the Board of Directors sent a letter to the Commissioners responsible, Mr van Miert and Mr Ruberti.
On 18 November 1994, the Chairman and Vice-Chairmen of the Management Board of CEDEFOP were received by the members of the Commission.
The President urged the Commission to draw up social measures, in particular for those staff who were unable to leave Berlin.
In the light of the regulations in force, the Commissioners stated that they were prepared to examine the specific problems of some of the staff in a positive and pragmatic spirit.
They also expected this from the other Community institutions (European Parliament, Council, etc.) — The Council of Directors, at its meeting on 8 and 9 December 1994, was unable to decide on the date of the transfer, since it was not acceptable for staff unable to move to Thessaloniki without simply dismissing a modern social plan.
At the same meeting, the Management Board instructed the Director to prepare a Management Council Decision (to be taken at an extraordinary meeting on 27 January 1995) which provided for a socially acceptable transfer of the Centre to 1 September. "— In the second half of December 1994, the Council began to examine the Commission's proposal to amend Article 13 of the Regulation applicable to CEDEFOP, which provided that the Centre's staff were to be subject to the regulations and regulations applicable to officials and other servants of the European Communities.
The Director adopted this amendment on the basis of the formulation of the framework agreement on social accompanying measures relating to the transfer of CEDEFOP to Thessaloniki.
On 23 January 1995, the framework agreement with the staff was signed.
The preparations were carried out in close cooperation with the European Commission, which proved to be very helpful throughout the transition period (1994 to 1996). — The Management Board decided to accept the framework agreement and to move the Centre to Thessaloniki on 1 September 1995.
Official Journal of the European Communities No C 81/13
Under the framework agreement, staff who could not leave Berlin decided to make themselves available to other EU institutions or public/privat organisations and to receive a salary from the Centre for at least six months, with a monthly salary paid for each year of service begun.
The principle of paying a monthly salary for each year of service largely corresponds to the social plans and the usual procedures in Germany and neighbouring countries. — Early retirement in 1995 was considered for 17 employees (aged over 55 years with 10 years of service and over 50 years with 15 years of service).
These measures were not part of the framework agreement and were finally not proposed by the Commission in the light of the decisions of the Council of Ministers of 17 November 1995 to accept the'release' of officials in the context of the accession of new Member States to the European Parliament.
The Management Board will respond in more detail in its opinions on points 46-66.
In general, it should be stressed that the political aspects should be taken seriously and that subsequent criticism should be avoided.
The transfer of a complete Community body within the restrictive framework of a large number of different regulations and given a considerable number of social and individual problems is indeed unique in the history of the Community.
5. The Board of Directors will return below in this reply to the exception mentioned in the last sentence.
The costs of the meetings of the Management Board in 1995 are due to the fact that two additional meetings (in January and June) had to be held in connection with the transfer.
In addition, the December 1995 meeting caused higher costs as a result of the official start of activity in Greece.
Only two meetings are planned for 1996.
The Management Board regrets that the Court did not respond to the European Parliament's decision to postpone discharge for the 1994 budget.
This raises serious questions as — the discharge for 1994 in the context of the Court of Auditors' report for 1994 and the Council's recommendation on granting discharge should be seen and should be in line with the usual rules and procedures; — the European Parliament's assessment of the 1995 financial year without the Court of Auditors' report for 1995 on which the Board of Directors could have given its opinion leads to the mixing of very different situations; — the Centre was transferred to Greece in 1995.
The transfer was carried out smoothly and under acceptable conditions.
This transfer requires a transitional period, which can only be completed in 1997, as a result of the disruptions to which the staff have been subjected.
15. There is a marked improvement in this respect.
In the early phase in Thessaloniki, the staff helped each other to carry out the work.
16. As was pointed out last year, the increased use of the paying agency procedure was made at the request of the financial controller, who justified this by the cost-benefit ratio.
Similarly, the financial controller had to act more frequently.
The use of the paying agency procedure for all expenditure that could require provisional commitments limited administrative costs and avoided delays.
The situation is even more difficult due to the payment arrangements in Greece (most payments are made in cash or by cheque).
Invoices on which bank accounts are provided are rare; contractors collect their claims themselves.
The geographical distance to the financial controller and the lack of reliability of the mail delivery must also be taken into account.
In addition, DHL express deliveries may only be made once a week for cost reasons (3 000 Bfrs per shipment).
An amendment to the decision to set up the paying agency procedure will be submitted to the Management Board shortly in order to be able to take better account of the Court of Auditors' wishes.
17. The transfers over the last two months are explained by the need to make optimum use of the budget (of which ECU 2 000 000 had been deferred and were only released shortly before the transfer of the Centre to Thessaloniki) and by the decision of the Management Board (7./8. 12. 1995) to recruit national experts seconded to the Commission (also to promote the Centre's work).
19. The Management Board was aware that 1995 and 1996 would be years of transition and renewal.
A certain reduction in productivity is inevitable in this international transfer, which, in the opinion of the Board of Directors, has been carried out in an acceptable and smooth manner.
The Centre is still facing problems caused by the transition phase.
20. Since the centre was relocated with a greatly reduced number of employees, the work of the administration and of all other services slowed down.
For this reason, a non-automatic transfer of appropriations was requested and approved.
No C 81/14        81          , Official Journal of the European Communities 13. 3. 97 22. The Management Board notes that the Commission is making every effort to comply with the provisions of Article 26 of the Financial Regulations of the Centre and to pay out the grant in accordance with the actual needs during the first two weeks of the quarter.
In 1995 there was an improvement compared to 1994.
However, due to the long internal procedures (which involve the instructing authority, the financial controller and the accounting officer) and the length of the bank's remittance procedure, a total delay of the processing period (on average 12 days in 1995) cannot be completely avoided.
Nevertheless, in 1995 three payments would have been made almost in accordance with the provisions in Article 26, as they arrived at the Centre less than four days after the end of the first two weeks of the quarter.
If the processing period had been the same for all payments (between 9 and 22 days) as for the average period of 12 days, all payments would have been made in accordance with Article 26 of the Financial Regulation.
The first payment was not in accordance with the rules, but the payment must be preceded by the commitment of funds, which must take some time.
23. The Deputy Director moved from Thessaloniki to Berlin because there was uncertainty about the actual date of the transfer of the Centre.
At the time of the appointment (1 October 1994) no decision had yet been taken on the date of the move (which could have been postponed even further).
It was hoped that his stay would be short, but his ultimate duration was still unknown at that time.
For the usual family reasons, he moved to Berlin under the conditions of his status.
Daily allowances for missions were granted under the same procedure as for other staff.
As regards the second installation aid, the Deputy Director paid back this sum to the Centre after the audit, although he would have had full entitlement.
24. At its meeting in June 1995, the Management Board terminated its contract on 31 December 1995 and instructed the Director to implement this Decision and to arrange for payments in accordance with the Staff Regulations.
The Management Board was pleased that the Deputy Director was prepared to participate in the implementation of the 1995 work programme and to assist the Centre in the re-launch in Thessaloniki.
The compensation (payment of one third of the basic salary from the date on which the obligation of service expired until the expiry of the contract) was in accordance with the contract and Article 47 of the BBSB.
25. In view of the difficulties of the initial phase and the large number of new contracts, the Centre could not, in each case, carry out the usual tendering procedures.
In the case of longer-term contracts, tendering procedures are currently under way or are planned for 1996.
In addition, in order to ensure balanced budgetary management in the course of the year, the Management Board will prefer the adoption of the work programme to allow the services to have the necessary time to tender, to make commitments and to conclude the corresponding contracts in the first months of the financial year.
The 40 % of the commitments for the pilot studies and projects budget line (ECU 300 000) were made in the last few months of the year due to the late release of the appropriations in the 1995 budget by the budgetary authority and the transfer of the Centre to Thessaloniki.
The Centre had to act logically and consistently, and had no other choice, as it had to meet its financial obligations under Titles I and II and could only make further commitments under Title III after the funds had been decommitted.
The possibility of seconding national experts was granted by the Management Board at its meeting in December 1995 and could only be financed by the resources of the secondment.
The Director had to act quickly and within a short period of time to prevent funds (which became available very late) from falling.
The application of the (Austrian) expert (who was officially supported by the government) was already available at the beginning of 1995.
27. The reason for recording rent for January 1996 in the 1995 financial statements was purely practical.
According to the contract, the rent must be paid in advance in two instalments on 1 January and 1 July.
Since the first payment was only made in October 1995 and it would have been difficult to pay immediately again on 1 January 1996, the first payment was made for a period of five months, including January 1996.
28. The inventory is being updated.
29. This will be complied with.
The Centre shall ensure that it submits to the Commission a realistic statement on the cash flow.
The last payment in the year should be the largest, since it must also be used to cover the first months of the following year, in which larger payments are normally to be made.
See comments on point 4. 32. The management of the Centre shall assess the costs of the transfer and assess developments in order to gain a comprehensive picture of the costs and benefits of the transfer to Greece.
Official Journal of the European Communities No. C 81/15 36.-37.
Since it was expected that the Centre would resume its work immediately after the move, some additional investments and changes were needed.
As has been noted, the agreements do not contain a clear statement of this, because the centre needed more power connections and stronger computer cables than the existing ones.
Other investments concerned additional security requirements and communications facilities, such as Europe by Satellite, in order to be able to receive broadcasts directly through the institutions.
The Centre has nevertheless put questions concerning the provisional building on the agenda of the Steering Committee dealing with the new and (if necessary) the provisional building.
The Management Board is aware of the fact that the content of the agreement on the new building gave the Greek Government a great responsibility, the latter of which is currently fulfilling the agreement.
Two points of particular concern concern are: — securing the provision of a high-quality building at a reasonable price; — securing the timely completion of the building (if possible before 1 September 1998).
The fact that substantial payments were made in advance (half of the building has already been paid, although the construction work has not yet started) can also have positive effects, as the actual construction work (after selecting the construction plan and the construction firm in October/November 1996) could progress rapidly due to the immediate availability of the necessary financial resources.
In general, the Board of Directors fully understood the Court's concerns, which were shared by Members of the European Parliament, Mr Kellet-Bowmann and Mr Tappin, who visited the Centre on 1 and 2 and on 14 and 15 May respectively.
The Management Board is ready to act on this issue in accordance with the Commission's recommendations.
42. Due to the various social support measures, the staff situation was very complicated, but all the persons on the salary list of CEDEFOP who were not made available to other organisations or who were seconded in Berlin were working for CEDEFOP and its work programme.
43. The Management Board has taken the decision on the social accompanying measures relating to the transfer (framework agreement) in order to take "appropriate measures as soon as possible" (see the declarations in the minutes of the Council).
The evaluation of the measures must therefore take into account their political background.
The Centre is located in Thessaloniki and the Management Board and the Director decide on the organisation of the work.
It is true that some of the items are blocked as long as the social accompanying measures are effective.
However, at the end of 1996 almost all the measures will expire, and the CEDEFOP will then be able to operate with full capacity on the basis of medium-term priorities (adopted by the Administration in November 1996) and the 1997 work programme, which will also be based on these priorities.
CEDEFOP will therefore move into the future from 1997 onwards with a revitalised and new approach.
44. Persons who cannot leave Berlin for social or personal reasons, when the fixed duration of their stay in Berlin ends, have three alternatives.
In this respect, the President of the Court of First Instance announced three decisions rejecting the requests for transitional proceedings.
Such persons must move, withdraw from the service of the Centre or find solutions in accordance with the Staff Regulations.
45. The impact in 1996 is, of course, serious, but will be minimal after the first months of 1997.
The transfer had its consequences and costs.
However, if they are compared with a similar transfer at national level, such as that of the Centre d'Etudes et de Recherches sur les Qualifications (CEREQ) from Paris to Marseille (where only 21 of the 120 employees moved with the Centre), then the effects of an international transfer of almost 2 000 km have not been unduly negative for CEDEFOP.
Precautionary cost estimates indicate that cost neutrality will be achieved in 2000 and that work will be even more cost-effective (mainly due to lower labour costs in Greece). 46.-66.
(a) As the Court notes in its conclusion (71) it is understandable that efforts have been made to assist staff in order to encourage them to continue their activities for the EU institutions and in order to alleviate the difficult problems of relocation. (b) However, it is not the failure of the Board of Directors, "that the regulatory framework within which the relocation took place [...] was not compatible with the proper treatment of senior staff and that it was not possible for CEDEFOP to move smoothly". (c) Following the decision of the Board of Directors of 27 January 1995, the Council, on 6 February 1995 (Regulation (EC) No 251/95), amended Article 13 of Regulation (EEC) No 337/75 in order that "the staff of the Centre is subject to the regulations and regulations applicable to officials and other servants of the European Communities".
In spite of the absence of transitional provisions, as in the case of the adoption of Council Regulation (EEC, Council, ECSC) No 269/68 (see Article 102 of the Staff Regulations of Officials of the European Communities) (see Article 102 of the Staff Regulations of Officials of the European Communities of the European Communities) (see Article 102 of the Staff Regulations of Officials of the Communities of the European Communities) (see Article 102 of the Staff Regulations of Officials of the Communities of the European Communities of the European Communities of the European Communities of the European Communities)
(d) Since the Community legislation did not provide for transitional measures, the Board had no choice but to act on its own responsibility in order to safeguard the rights and interests of CEDEFOP staff. (e) It should not be forgotten that Regulation (EC) No 251/95, in which the seat of CEDEFOP was transferred from Berlin to Thessaloniki, was a sudden change in the place of employment of the staff listed in the employment contracts: Berlin had been the only seat of CEDEFOP since 20 years and, at no point since 10 February 1975, the slightest indication that that the seat could be transferred, let alone to another, distant Member State.
(f) In view of these circumstances, the Management Board had the obligation to: — provide the staff with a high level of security with regard to their place of work (appointment to permanent officials), — ensure that their category, grade and step, and — provide staff who so wished to assist in their search for a different job. (g) The Management Board also wished to point out that the posts approved by the budgetary authority were permanent posts.
(h) In addition, the wording of Regulation (EC) No 251/95 ('the staff of the Centre shall be subject to the regulations and regulations applicable to officials and other servants of the European Communities') clearly provides for the employment of officials.
Since the posts filled by the staff are of a permanent nature, the decision on the status of officials was appropriate and justified, rather than on temporary contracts.
The Board of Directors also wishes to comment on the individual points raised by the Court: 46. (last sentence) The Board of Directors had the choice to appoint its staff either as permanent staff or to offer them two-year contracts (see opinion (g) above).
It was considered unacceptable to require staff to move from Berlin to Thessaloniki on the basis of a two-year contract.
48. Although it is true that the Board of Directors has not officially submitted the declarations to the Financial Controller for approval, the latter has nevertheless been informed of the decisions taken.
At the time of the signature of the agreement, the outstanding individual decisions of the staff members did not yet determine the exact financial impact of the agreement.
It provided a framework that provided the basis for individual decisions and received the full approval of the financial controller during his visit to Berlin.
50-51.
In the light of the argument referred to above (e), the decision taken (see remark, second indent) was the only possible one.
It also conformed to the Commission's clear statement (see last sentence of the statement to the Council's minutes in the annex) that 'there must be no deterioration in the conditions of employment of CEDEFOP's staff'.
The considerations of the Commission's legal service, quoted only in part in paragraph 56, leave sufficient room for such a decision.
The Management Board reiterates that Article 29 of the Staff Regulations entitles the appointing authority to conduct internal competitions for the purpose of filling vacant posts in an institution (point lb).
The competitions were conducted in full compliance with Annex III to the Staff Regulations.
The aim and obligation of the Management Board was to ensure that as many CEDEFOP staff as possible agreed to move to Thessaloniki.
It should not be forgotten that Regulation (EC) No 251/95 amended the rules applicable to staff with effect from 1 March 1995 and that the move to Thessaloniki took place in August of that year.
The Management Board's approach was based on the following considerations: — it was unthinkable to require the staff to move to Thessaloniki on the basis of a two-year contract (recital (g) and (46) above); — there was not enough time to carry out a general selection procedure before moving to Thessaloniki, and it would not have been realistic to expect the staff to move without a secure commitment to employment.
13. 3. 97 I EN I Official Journal of the European Communities No. C 81/17 56.-59./ The Management Board has already explained (see above, remark (e)) that the move to Thessaloniki meant a sudden change in the place of employment, which inevitably caused social problems and, for a certain period of time, affected productivity.
To require the staff to move after the assignment of a low grade or step would have aggravated their situation even further.
The Commission's Legal Service's note, mentioned in paragraph 56, provides sufficient arguments in point (d) in order to justify the position adopted by the Centre. 60.-61.
All staff members applying for appointment as members of staff for a lifetime period completed the probationary period laid down in Article 34 of the Staff Regulations.
62. In accordance with note (f), 3rd indent, above, the Management Board considered it its duty to assist the staff in an acceptable manner.
This view was also taken by the Commission's Legal Service.
65. The rules governing the transfer rules of part of the remuneration allow for the possibility of increasing this percentage from 35 % to 50 % in individual cases in the event of justified reasons in accordance with Article 4 of the Regulation.
The framework agreement, in individual cases and in the case of certain liabilities provided for in the Staff Regulations, which were received before 29 October 1993 (the date on which the European Council decided to transfer the Centre), allowed the transfer of a higher percentage (> 35 %' according to the Staff Regulations, but < 50 %).
The application of these rules is quite different in the case of CEDEFOP and concerns only a limited number of persons with high liabilities in Berlin.
66. The Management Board would like to thank the Commission for the support it has provided in a number of cases in the search for alternative employment opportunities for staff who have not been able to move to Thessaloniki and for any other assistance it has provided to the Centre almost daily during the move.
68. See comments of the Management Board on paragraphs 23 and 24. 69.-70.
See in particular the general comments in points 46-66.
71. The Administrative Board regrets that the legislator has not introduced any transitional legal arrangements in Regulation (EC) No 251/95 in order to resolve the difficult staffing problems caused by the move to Thessaloniki.
In view of the lack of suitable instruments, the Management Board was all the more obliged to support CEDEFOP's staff to the fullest possible extent.
The Board of Directors believes that, in the present and truly unprecedented circumstances, it has acted in the only acceptable manner.
In the end, it was obvious that he had to make such an effort (as the Court acknowledges), since it is his duty as an employer to carry out the international work of an entire institution in a socially acceptable manner.
The Board of Directors, the Director and the staff acted in this positive spirit, possibly taking some risks, but not taking any abuse of power, nor taking any unlawful action.

The Commission has set up a financial year ending December 1995 and has the task of "contributing to the design and creation of better living and working conditions through action to promote and disseminate knowledge capable of supporting this development".
The Dublin Foundation started its activities in 1976.
The Court of Auditors examined the annual accounts and the financial management of the Dublin Foundation in accordance with the relevant regulations (2).
Financial data 7. For the 1995 financial year, the Foundation had a budget of ECU 12.5 million.
The commitments entered into resulted in payments of ECU 9.3 million and transfers to the 1996 financial year of ECU 3 million, the balance of which was cancelled at ECU 0.2 million.
Of the appropriations carried over from the previous year, 1.9 million ECU was disbursed and 0.2 million ECU was cancelled.
Annex 3 to this report contains an analysis of the use of appropriations for the financial year and the appropriations carried over from 1994 broken down by title.
Follow-up to previous observations Separation of duties 8. The Court repeats its earlier observations that the duties of the authorising officer and the accounting officer are not sufficiently separated.
This is contrary to Article 15 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1949/93 amending Council Regulation (EEC) No 1417/76, which states that the principle of'separation of powers of instruction and accounting' applies and that the activities of the authorising officer, the financial controller and the accounting officer are (are) incompatible with each other.'
Paying agency 9. A large part (1995: 5 9%, without salaries) of payments continues to be made without prior approval by a financial controller.
The extent to which the paying agency is used is not within the meaning of the financial rules.

Transfers from title to title 10. The Foundation continued to carry over from title to title in 1995 (see paragraph 16).
This is contrary to Article 21 of Regulation (EEC) No 1417/76 of the 1 494 000 ECU (11.9% of the budget) and to ECU 756000 (6.5%) in 1994.
16. By transferring ECU 500 000 from Title 1 (staff) to Title 3 (operational expenditure), the Foundation was able to transfer commitments to the following financial year which would otherwise have been cancelled in accordance with Article 6(1) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1949/93 amending Council Regulation (EEC) No 1417/76.
As stated in paragraph 10 above, the Court considers that such transfers from title to title are in breach of the financial rules.
17. As Annex 3 shows, the total payment rate for the payment of appropriations is 75 %, while the payment rate for Title 3 ‘Operational expenditure' is only 54 %.
Table 1 shows by title the transfers from the 1995 budget and their subsequent use in 1996.
The transfers under Title 3 amounted to 45 % of the original appropriations.
By the end of March 1996, only 20% of the transfers had been used.
Revenue 18. The EU grant to the Foundation amounted to ECU 12.5 million in 1995.
The amounts actually requested and received amounted to ECU 2.5 million as at 26 April 1995, ECU 2 million as at 14 June 1995, ECU 4.3 million as at 12 October 1995 and ECU 1.3 million as at 31 December 1995.
The difference of ECU 2.4 million corresponded to the unnecessarily cashed funds that were not called to the Commission in accordance with the Court's recommendation in the previous year.
As in previous years, this type of financing is not compatible with Article 26 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1417/76, as amended by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1949/93, according to which the grant is paid in the first half of each quarter.
Expenditure 19. Under Article 63 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1949/93 of 30 June 1993 amending Council Regulation (EEC) No 1417/76 of 1 June 1976, contracts of more than 12 000 ECU must be awarded following an invitation to tender.
The following exceptions were found: — a contract worth ECU 533 072 for carrying out a Europe-wide survey on working conditions was awarded on a voluntary basis. — Six contracts were awarded in a sample of 26 contracts selected for examination on the basis of Article 46 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1417/76 of 1 June 1976, Council Regulation (EEC) No 1949/93, as amended by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1949/93.

In three cases (supply of computers in one case and study contracts in the other) Article 46 was used in order to avoid the tendering procedure.
20. In two cases it was established that expenditure had already been invoiced before the commitment was made.
In one case, accounts for November and December 1994 were taken into account for the commitment made in 1995, although the framework agreement between the Foundation and the contractor only began on 1 January 1995.
In a sample of 10 study contracts drawn for the examination, the final reports of five contracts were received only months after the deadline laid down in the contract.
22. In its examination, the Court found, in the following cases, that the documents had been modified by means of correction fluid: — the date of an invoice of DM 45 365 (23 817 ECU) faxed to the financial controller was overwritten by correction fluid and modified by hand from 17 January 1995 to 17 December 1994.

The Foundation has introduced a series of measures to separate the tasks of the authorising officer and the accounting officer.
The Court of Auditors has taken note of these initiatives in previous reports.
The only problem that remains in practice is the procedure whereby the authorising officer records expenditure in the existing integrated accounting system.
This problem will be solved once the Foundation has acquired a new accounting system.
Following the consultations in 1995, the Foundation participated in a joint tendering procedure in 1996 with other EU agencies for the purchase of an appropriate accounting system.
The result was, however, that none of the candidates met the requirements of the institutions 100%.
After extensive contacts with the Commission's services, it is expected that the Foundation will acquire an appropriate accounting system from the Commission in the course of 1997 after the work on an appropriate system, which meets the technical and legal requirements of the agencies, has recently been completed.
The Foundation has established links with the Commission services with regard to solutions to the identified problem. 9.
The Foundation has now been informed that this issue will be discussed between the Commission and the European Parliament in the context of the ongoing dialogue on the financial regulation of the agencies.
In the wake of the Court of Auditors' last report, the Foundation asked the Commission's services to clarify the Foundation's Financial Regulation as regards the transfers in question.
The Foundation is now informed by the Directorate-General of DG XIX that the transfers have been carried out in accordance with the Foundation's Financial Regulation (see also paragraph 16).
11. All missions to the Foundation were documented and approved by the authorising officer after he had verified that he had complied with the Foundation's work programme or administrative requirements.
The Foundation will review its procedures for recording and identifying the necessary documentation on missions.
The Regulation establishing the Foundation requires the European institutions to be consulted and the social partners to be involved in their work.
While in recent years there has been a deepening of the exchange of the FOUNDATION with the relevant EU bodies in Brussels, the number of missions to Brussels has not increased.
No missions are made when other means of communication can be used.
As far as possible, telephone, Internet, e-mail and other electronic tools are used. In November 1995, a videoconferencing pilot project was also launched.
Experiments with com-puter conferences have also been carried out.
14. On the basis of a proposal submitted by the Irish authorities, the lawyers are currently preparing a revised lease.
16. As stated in paragraph 10 above, the Foundation has been informed by the Commission that the transfers in question are fully in line with the Financial Regulation, and that the Foundation has been able to use in the most efficient way the resources allocated to it by the decisions of the budgetary authorities.
However, the Foundation appreciates the position of the Court of Auditors and Parliament and endeavours to carry out such transfers only in urgent cases.
These contracts mainly concerned studies with implementation periods of 12 months or more.
The Foundation will remind the Commission services once again that the grant payments will have to be made by the 15th of each quarter.
19. The Treaty implementing a European study on working conditions shows that the Treaty was concluded between the European Commission and INRA (Europe) under the framework contract for the 'Eurobaromètre-Stan-dard' drawn up on the basis of an open tendering procedure.
The award of contracts was entirely in line with the procedure laid down in Article 46 of the Foundation's Financial Regulation and with the criteria to be observed in this respect, and Article 46(d) was applied to the supply of computers.
Only one supplier had the required software as well as the special multi-sprac-big tasta-tures and provided local support: the other two contracts refer to research proposals.
The Foundation's Board of Directors approved at its meeting of 25 March 1994 the introduction of new procedures, which should be fully operational in the course of 1995, for the award of contracts based on calls for expressions of interest published in the Official Journal, and for calls for tender.
The two contracts were concluded during the transitional phase established by the Management Board.
20. The Foundation operates a decentralised ordering system.
The two invoices were part of a series of orders placed by an operational unit whose total orders exceeded the committed appropriations.
Appropriate measures will be taken to prevent this happening again.
The provision of a new accounting system should ensure the automatic implementation of the necessary controls.
21. The monitoring of the implementation of the study contracts shall be carried out on a monthly basis on the programme management basis.
22. The appointment was placed for the departments concerned on 11 October 1994.
The change in the date on the invoice itself had no influence on the transfers.
Nevertheless, the official concerned was reprimanded.
Any necessary manual corrections will be signed and dated in the future.

Main comments on the implementation of the budget of the European Agency for the Evaluation of Medicinal Products for the 1994 and 1995 financial years
During the 1995 financial year, the Agency recovered the Commission's grant (ECU 10.1 million) without issuing the corresponding recovery orders.
Accounting for budgetary operations 1.6.
Until August 1995, there was no journal on commitments and payments for this financial year.
At the end of the year, the Agency established an accounting system.
The Court noted that this system allowed for subsequent changes in bookings without this being apparent.
In the absence of the commitments, the appropriations available (in breach of Articles 29, 35 and 36 of the Agency's Financial Regulation) were exceeded, although the Administrative Director submitted an amending budget approved by the Management Board (transfers of appropriations from chapter to chapter).
By August 1995, the Agency had settled all payments through a paying agency.
This additional use of the paying agency procedure is contrary to Article 45 of the Agency's Financial Regulation, which provides for this procedure only for certain types of expenditure. 1.8.
In addition, the Agency did not start accounting for this expenditure until September 1995.
At the end of the financial year on 31 December 1995, some 937 000 ECU had to be settled.
General bill 1.9.
The accounts and budget accounts were not made until September and December 1995 because of the accounts of the paying agency.
This is contrary to accounting practices.

13. 3. 97 I EN Official Journal of the European Communities No. C 81/31 REPLY OF THE EMEA 1.6.
The commercial accounting systems available on the market do not take into account the specificities of Community financial rules.
For this reason, in 1995 the agencies published a call for tenders for a system in line with their needs.
Until the introduction of the new system, the Agency works with a spreadsheet system.
This system may be used to make subsequent changes to the accounts without the latter being able to understand the accounts of the budgetary operations.
However, these amendments are to be found in the general accounts.
All budgetary operations are documented in the case.
During the initial period, until the appointment of the financial controller in the House, a paying agency was essential for the proper functioning of the Agency.
Only in this way could the decision of the Member States on the establishment of the Agency be implemented rapidly.
With the entry into service of the financial controller the paying agency was less used and closed at the end of July 1995.
75 % of the payments made by the paying agency were settled in December 1995.
Even if a large amount could not be settled until 1996, the Agency achieved a satisfactory final result and did its best in difficult circumstances.

(3) In accordance with Article 137(1) of Council Regulation (EC) No 40/94, the accounts of all the Office's revenue and expenditure for the financial year 1995 were drawn up on 29 March 1996, signed by the President of the Office and forwarded to the Commission, the Committee on Budgets and the Court of Auditors.

The tables in the annex to this report give the financial statements in abbreviated form.
The Court considers that the Office should have issued a recovery order for the entire budget (ECU 10.1 million) in order to be able to meet the commitments carried over to the 1996 financial year (ECU 4.6 million).
During the 1995 financial year, the Office established a accounting system.
This is contrary to the internal financial regulation (Articles 4(1) and 29(1)).
Transfers and transfers 1.7.
The appropriations carried over to 1996 represent 46% of the budget and relate primarily to computer equipment (Titles II and III of the budget).
The appropriations available were also carried over from Title I (staff) to Title II (technical expenditure) totalling ECU 2,529 million (25 % of the budget).
The inventory is kept only in terms of quantity but not in terms of value.
It is therefore not possible to coordinate with the amounts shown in the Office's balance sheet.
The administrative system set up by the Office does not guarantee the proper separation of duties and the proper implementation of the provisions relating to revenue, commitments and payments (authorising officer, financial controller and accounting officer).
The office is currently housed in a building of the Spanish government.
However, there is no contract for the use of this building.
In order to provide its final seat in the future, the Office should clarify the need for the accommodation of its services.

Official Journal of the European Communities 13. 3. 97 REPLY OF THE AMTES Commission grant 1.5.
The need for a recovery order was not known to the Commission or to the OHIM.
OHIM has taken note of this observation by the Court of Auditors and has led to the immediate issue of a recovery order for the 1996 financial year for the total amount of the grant less the provisions.
Accounting for budgetary operations 1.6. It is true that the accounting system currently used by the OHIM allows for subsequent changes in the accounts.
For the period up to the introduction of the Sincom2 system developed by the Commission, the OHIM has made organisational arrangements for additional security guarantees for the use of the current system.
Until then, OHIM has no other option but to wait for the Commission's accounting system, which is likely to be available before the end of the year, because the development of such a system means a large financial burden which an office cannot bear on its own.
In 1995, the Office's budget was adopted in the light of a provision of ECU 2 million requested by Parliament for a general budget of ECU 10.1 million.
The provision was cancelled in two stages: — ECU 1 million in October 1995, — the balance in November 1995.
The temporary blocking of funds has of course had an impact on their use, especially the funds under Title I (Staff), as there was uncertainty as to whether the provisions would be effectively lifted.
OHIM could not, under any circumstances, engage in recruiting staff until the payment of salaries was guaranteed until the end of the financial year.
Following the release of the provisions, measures were taken to use the appropriations released, in the budget lines, where the deadlines for the budget commitment procedures were still possible and where there was real need.
For this reason, the Office has requested the transfer of the appropriations from Title I to Title II, in order to create, in the main, computer equipment, which was particularly needed in the start-up phase of the Office.
It should be recalled that OHIM began its activities on 1 April 1996 and that more than 30 000 trade mark applications have been received since then, while the workload had been estimated at 15 000 applications for the whole financial year.
Inventory 1.8. At the time of the Court's audit, OHIM had only just received the software for the computerised management of the inventory from the Commission; it was just installed at the time.
Division of tasks 1.9.
A question to the Court of Auditors made it clear that this item concerns the order of the signatures to be observed in the budgetary and payment procedures.
It is therefore not a confusion as to the duties of the authorising officer, the accounting officer and the financial controller.
This was because of the fact that the operation was first signed by the accounting officer and then by the authorising officer. · This procedure had the advantage of ensuring, in the initial phase of the Office, that the funds were available before a procedure was signed by the authorising officer. · Having now had the OHIM a fund manager, the following sequence of signatures can be followed for the various budget documents: 1. the manager of the budget, 2. the authorising officer, 3. the financial controller, 4. the accounting officer.

Accounting - The Foundation shares the opinion of the Court of Auditors.
The latter has also played a crucial role in the introduction of a uniform system for the management of the budget and the accounting system in all the departments.
Discussions are currently under way with the Commission's responsible departments, which will enable all the concerns expressed by the Court of Auditors to be overcome by the introduction of a new system for the management of the budget, which will enter into force on 1 January 1997.
It should be stressed that none of the budget appropriations made available had been exceeded over the period under review.
1.6. Management of advance payments It must be stressed that the advance payments had not been used for all purchases of equipment or for participation in real estate, which represented a significant part of the budget.
In addition, the use of the general advance payments has at present been reduced in accordance with Article 43 of the Financial Regulation and all accounting documents of a given month shall be sent to the auditor in Brussels within the 10th and 20th of the following month, respectively.
Contracts On the one hand, the contracts under discussion, closely linked to the activities and projects of the Foundation's work programme, represent an extremely small proportion of the Foundation's activities, both in terms of number and budget.
On the other hand, it is true that the inclusion of the competition that led to these contracts was done informally.
This procedure was chosen at the time mainly because of the urgency of the matter.
In addition, the contracts under discussion had the task of organising conferences and seminars on behalf of and on behalf of the Foundation and under its strict control.
The budget was divided into two parts: the fixed part of the remuneration (under ECU 12 000) and the operational part, which was fixed in advance by the Foundation and remunerated on the basis of the supporting documents.
On the basis of these elements, the Foundation considered that the actual contract amount would not exceed ECU 12 000.
When it became clear at the beginning of 1996 that the Court of Auditors did not share this view, this system was abandoned.

In Titles I (Personnel expenditure) and II (Expenditure expenditure) of the budget, a number of overruns of some ECU 0.4 million have been recorded.

Paying agency 1.7.
Almost all payments to be charged to Titles I and II of the budget have been settled through a paying agency.

This seems to be the main reason for the above-mentioned excesses.

As at the end of 1994, a very large proportion of the available appropriations was carried over at the end of 1995 (7 million ECU — 57.2% of the total).

The division of tasks was not complied with in the administrative department of the agency.

• The European Environment Agency was established in Copenhagen in mid-1994.
A first budget of ECU 10.2 million was adopted on 31 October 1994.
Since the decision on the seat of the Agency had been delayed, the work of the Environment Agency had to be carried out at a particularly rapid pace at the beginning of its work.
Projects could be identified and committed before the end of the year thanks to a large amount of work, but for obvious reasons the implementation of the commitments could hardly begin before the end of 1994.
In 1995, the Agency was faced with the difficult task of implementing not only the 1994 budget but also a new budget of ECU 10.5 million for 1995, before the Agency's regular staff began their duties.
The Agency's vacancies were advertised in November 1994 and after a lengthy selection process with more than 7 000 applications, the first selected candidates started their work in the summer of 1995.
In short, the Agency had an ambitious work programme and had practically two budgets, but had only a very limited number of staff for this task.
Nevertheless, the work progressed and in 1995 major projects, such as the Dobris Management Report and the revision of the 5th Environmental Action Plan, were completed.
Five European thematic contact centres were set up and the EIONET was set up.
The Agency's regular staff increased by 1 person on 1 January 1995 (supported by 10 temporary staff, such as national experts and auxiliary staff) and reached the level of 22 regular staff on 31 December 1995 with 10 temporary staff.
The administrative machinery of the Agency has gradually been expanded, as the same open recruitment procedure has been applied.
Nevertheless, in 1995, the Agency was clearly not sufficiently equipped to deal with the procedural and financial aspects of the work.
As far as the financial side is concerned, only one person was available in the first half of the year to work on the financial, budgetary and contractual aspects of the work programme.
In June 1995, the Head of the Administration Department began his duties and only at the beginning of 1996 did the other staff for financial and contract matters come in.
The Agency did its job, but in the area of finance and the budget some mistakes were made in relation to the prescribed procedures.
Overruns Some budget lines have been overrun.
On the one hand, this was because the Agency's budgetary control system was not working satisfactorily and, on the other hand, some payments made were not recorded because the Agency's financial department was clearly understaffed.
Consequently, the clearance of the accounts resulted in a discrepancy between the accounts and the payments actually made, which appeared as an overdraft of certain budget lines.
As there is no longer any possibility of offsetting between different budget lines after 1 January, these amounts must be included in the 1996 accounts, i.e. financed from the 1996 budget.
In 1996, expenditure and the appropriations available under Titles I and II (i.e. the 1995 problem points) were carefully monitored in order to avoid an expenditure surplus.
Non-compliance with procedures (subsequent referral to the financial controller) A work programme was drawn up during the development phase of the Agency and its implementation started before the administrative procedures were clearly defined and an administrative structure was available to monitor compliance with the procedures.
In some cases, this led to work being commissioned and carried out, and to some procedural rules being disregarded.
In particular, work was commissioned without the financial controller's endorsement being obtained in Brussels, which is a prerequisite for this type of operational expenditure.
The error was purely procedural and was justified in the fact that work had to be done, but that the necessary administrative structures, which had to ensure compliance with the rules laid down by Brussels, had not yet been set up.
A clear delegation of the powers of delegation has been carried out and the staff are informed of the procedural rules.
Separation of tasks As in all public institutions, certain functions of a financial technical nature should remain separate with the Environment Agency.
One of the basic principles is that commitments and payment orders should not be made by the same person.
However, during the construction period of the Agency in Copenhagen, the staffing levels were so low that this principle could not be respected.
This fact is rightly criticised by the Court of Auditors.
In the case of the Environment Agency, the financial controller of the Agency and of the Commission shall be one and the same person, established in Brussels.
This would significantly impede the work of the Agency.
The way out of this dilemma is to set up a paying agency.
I m principle, it works like a small cash reserve, although the amounts covered by it are quite significant.
Instead of obtaining the prior approval of the financial control, the agency orders the disbursement and sends, once a month, the establishment of the procedures of the paying agency for subsequent approval of the financial control.
On the one hand, this will facilitate the work of the paying agency, but on the other hand, this will also be a two-part sword, since the internal control of the agency and the financial department will have to be able to fulfil this additional responsibility.
In this respect, the Court of Auditors' complaint is understandable, but as long as the financial controller is based in Brussels, the Agency does not see any alternance to the extent of the Agency's extensive use of the Agency. · For this reason, the Agency has taken the Court's recommendation to the effect that the Agency's Commission is in a position to provide financial assistance.The Environment Agency is in favour of such a step.
Computerised accounting system The Court of Auditors stresses the need for the Agency to implement a modern accounting system covering both general accounting and budgetary control.
Such a computerised system is essential for the EU's complicated financial system if we are to avoid a large financial and budgetary commitment.
The Environment Agency supports the conclusions of the Court of Auditors from the bottom of its heart.
Since the beginning of 1995, the Agency has repeatedly tried to find a solution to this problem.
It is in the same form for the other EU agencies.
In 1996, the agencies issued a joint call for proposals, which, however, remained unsuccessful, i.e. no satisfactory system was found.
The Agency is currently considering the possibility of using the new Sincom 2 budgetary control system.
The plan foresees that it should be installed and operational in good time in order to implement the 1997 budget.
But there will continue to be a soft spot for budgetary control and another for general accounting.
The Agency will continue to look for a suitable solution to these problems and will endeavour to coordinate this work with the other agencies.
13.3.97 EN Official Journal of the European Communities No C 81/49 REPORT on the financial statements of the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction (EMCDDA-Lisbon), together with the Centre's replies (97IC 81/07) (period from 1 November 1994 to 31 December 1995) 1.1 This report was submitted to the Management Board of the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction pursuant to Article 11(11) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 302/93 of 8 February 1993 No 1.2.
The Court examined the financial statements of the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction for the financial years 1994 and 1995.
In accordance with Article 11(8) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 302/93 (2), the budget was implemented under the responsibility of the Director.
In accordance with Article 11(10) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 302/93 (2), as amended by Council Regulation (EC) No 3294/94 of 22 December 1994 (3), the latter is also responsible for drawing up and presenting the accounts (4).
The Court of Auditors is required to examine this account in accordance with Article 188c of the Treaty establishing the European Community.
This is a report on the first review of the Centre.
The Court has carried out its audit in accordance with the generally accepted audit standards in so far as they apply to the Community context.
It has carried out checks on the accounts and has applied other audit procedures deemed necessary in this context.
The financial statements for 1994 and 1995 are reliable and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions are ensured overall.
Main comments on the implementation of the budget of the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction for the 1994 and 1995 financial years
In 1995, the Centre only issued a recovery order for 57% (ECU 3 million) of the grant and recovered the corresponding funds.
The Court considers that the Centre should also have issued a recovery order for the ECU 2.3 million in the balance sheet (a total of ECU 5.3 million) in order to meet the commitments carried over to the 1996 financial year (ECU 2.8 million).
Aid granted by the Portuguese Government 1.6.
An amount of ECU 614 015 (including interest) made available by the Portuguese Government to the Centre for the Centre for the Establishment of the Centre for the Establishment of the Centre is not shown as revenue in the budget but is shown in the balance sheet only.
Accounting for budgetary operations 1.7.
This may lead to excesses of funds.
Paying agency 1.8.
During 1995, the Centre carried out a large part (45%) of its expenditure through paying agencies.
The systematic use of the paying agency procedure is not compatible with Article 43 of the Financial Regulation for the Centre, which provides for this procedure only for certain types of expenditure.
The accounts for this expenditure were delayed, as the documents had to be sent to the financial controller in Brussels.
In 1995, substantial appropriations were carried over to 1996, i.e. ECU 2.8 million, representing 52% of the Centre's budget.
Some appropriations, which had been carried over from 1994 to 1995, had to be cancelled (ECU 4,607 million in total) (ECU 0,368 million, i.e. 8% of the appropriations carried over).
Division of tasks 1.10.
Financial controller 1.11.
In view of the current situation, the internal control system could be improved by the allocation of a financial controller on the spot.

The following remarks concern the Court of Auditors' most important comments on the implementation of the EMCDDA budget for 1994 and 1995 (points 1.5 to 1.11 of the Court of Auditors' comments).
The EMCDDA shares the Court's view that it would have been more appropriate to issue a recovery order for all the appropriations entered in the balance sheet as a contribution to the Commission, and for the 1996 budget, appropriate action was taken. (b) The Portuguese Government (point 1.6 of the Court's observations) The EMCDDA acted in accordance with the Commission's financial control (which is also the EMCDDA's financial controller). The EMCDDA, within the meaning of Article 54 of the Financial Regulation for the general budget of the European Communities, and Article 82 of the Implementing Rules for the same (in accordance with the spirit of Article 142 of the Financial Regulation for the general budget of the European Communities), first used the payment account for the expenditure entered in Article 54 of the abovementioned implementing rules.
However, the EMCDDA is aware that this can only be a provisional system (based on Excel) and that it needs a more efficient accounting system.
In this context, the decentralised agencies (including the EMCDDA), coordinated by the European Training Foundation in Turin, launched a call for proposals at the end of December 1995, with the aim of equipping themselves with an integrated, integrated, integrated system for general accounting and accounting.
No. C 81/54 EN..- Official Journal of the Communities 13. 3.-97 For the following financial years, the EMCDDA shall implement a plan for the programming and monitoring of the implementation of the budget and its work programme to improve the use of the appropriations allocated and, in particular, to limit the transfers to exceptional cases.- (f) Separation of tasks (point 1.10 of the Court of Auditors' observations)- (c) Due to its very limited staff in the years 1994 and 1995, the EMCDDA was unable to fully ensure compliance with the principle of separation of tasks, as the Court of Auditors pointed out.
The separation of the duties of authorising officer, financial controller and accounting officer, as required by Article 16 of the OEDT financial rules for the duties of authorising officer, has been fully complied with.
The EMCDDA is already working to ensure the separation of tasks in the execution of the various tasks in question.
In this context, it shall, as far as possible, take into account the requirements as communicated by the Court of Auditors in defining their short-term requirements in order to ensure that the administrative tasks referred to by the Court of Auditors (payment management, accounting, management of staff and contracts) are carried out by different persons.
(g) Financial Controller (point 1.11 of the Court of Auditors' observations) When the EMCDDA's financial rules were adopted in June, the EMCDDA's Management Board adopted a negative decision in respect of the delegation of the financial controller's tasks to a EMCDDA staff member (in particular on the basis of the European Commission's objections).
Since the European Commission's financial controller is also the EMCDDA's financial controller, it would also be up to the Commission to review the feasibility of the possible designation of a financial controller on the spot, taking into account the rules on this issue in the other decentralised agencies.
