If errors are identified, the Agency shall charge the difference between the original fee paid and the final fee paid and, in addition, an administrative fee.
On 31 December 2017, the amount to be recovered amounted to 4.7 million euros, of which 3.2 million euros were related to the excessive administrative charges.
However, the Agency appears to be encountering difficulties in the recovery of administrative fees.
In its 2017 financial statements, the Agency recorded a reduction of EUR 2.8 million in irrecoverable claims (i.e. EUR 600 000 more than at the end of 2016).
3.7.12.
The exercise of powers of enforcement of the quantities declared by the undertakings is the task of the Member State authorities responsible for enforcement and the Agency has no powers of enforcement (see the paragraph highlighting the facts in paragraph 3.7.5).
The measures taken by the enforcement authorities of the Member States are coordinated by the Forum for the exchange of enforcement information.
On 6 December 2017, the Forum adopted new strategies and minimum criteria for the enforcement of the Chemical Regulations (ăStrategies and minimum criteria for enforcement of Chemical Regulations), which provide a framework for the development of national enforcement strategies.
The Agency's ability to fulfil its mission depends on the effectiveness of the implementation of this framework by the national authorities.
In its general report for 2017, the Agency states that around two thirds of companies did not update the registered information on the quantities of chemicals they handle.
This concerns the effective implementation of the REACH Regulation and also the accuracy of the calculation of costs.
COMMENTS ON THE ECONOMICITY OF BUDGETARY CURRENCY AND SERVICES 3.7.13. The Agency publishes job advertisements on its own website and on social media, but usually not on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO).
OTHER COMMENTS 3.7.14.
The Agency's revenue from fees is linked to the registration periods for chemicals in the EU as laid down in the REACH Regulation (2010, 2013 and 2018).
The agency therefore does not raise any regular fees and has to fight with a mismatch between relatively stable expenditure and more fluctuating, less predictable revenues, which makes budgeting more difficult.
The Agency is supported in dealing with this situation by a grant received by the Commission.
As the third and final registration period for chemicals expires under the REACH Regulation in 2018, it is expected that revenues from fees and charges will fall from 2019 and that the Agency will be dependent on the EU budget for the financing of its operations.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/59 Year 2014 2016 2016 2016 State of the correction decision (completed/in progress/in progress/in progress/in progress/in progress/in progress/in progress/in progress (1) In progress In the course of the pending ANNEX Follow-up of comments from previous years Statements of the Court The expenditures of the Court for the procedures related to a new specific activity of the Agency, the implementation of the regulation on biocidal products, were, in principle, covered by fees for the evaluation of the fees for the registration of these products.
However, the fees collected in 2014 covered only 17% of this expenditure, so that the rest of the budget was actually financed by contributions from the Union (6.3 million euros) and EFTA countries (0.2 million euros) to the Agency's budget. At 10.1 million euros and 39% (2015: 7.3 million euros and 32%), the rate of committed appropriations to Title III (operational expenditures) was still high, at 1.3 million euros and 68% (2015: 1.5 million euros and 74%), respectively.
Such a high transfer rate is contrary to the budgetary principle of arrears. The agency may decide to use arrears of separate budgetary resources to better cope with the multi-annual nature of the activities and inevitable arrears between contract signings, deliveries and payments.

EN C 434/60 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE AGENCY 3.7.10.
The relevant legislation (REACH (EC) 340/2008) does not provide that the Agency should carry out an ex-post review of the size of all SME registrants.
The Agency's Board of Directors approved a concept whereby SME registrants with the largest financial impact (i.e. with the largest number of registrations within the largest volume range) will be given priority.
The agency                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            
In the future, we will increasingly carry out the agency on the basis of the cost-benefit-principle on the basis of the size of SMEs.
3.7.11.
REACH Regulation (EC) No 340/2008 does not provide the Agency with any tools necessary for the enforcement of the collection of excessive administrative charges.
The Agency proactively reminds debtors of their obligation to pay. If this does not succeed, it commissions local law firms to enforce the outstanding fees and charges directly in the Member States.
The law firms have so far contacted 74% of the companies that have to pay the administrative fees of the company. The result of this initiative is then subjected to a cost-benefit analysis to determine the next steps.
Member States have the primary responsibility for the enforcement of the REACH and CLP Regulations, in particular the obligation to register chemical substances.
The ability of the agency to accomplish its mission and to generate revenues from the fees to the appropriate extent depends on the effectiveness of the practical implementation of enforcement strategies by the national authorities.
Discussions are being held with the Commission to address this problem.
3.7.13.
The Agency takes note of the previous comment, which is a horizontal matter which concerns a number of agencies.
The Agency publishes job advertisements similar to other agencies on its own website, on social media and on the website of the EU Agency Network (EUAN) (https://euagencies.eu/).
To increase transparency and publicity and make it possible for women and women to access job vacancies, the Agency recommends that the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO) refer for its part to the EUAN website.
3.7.14.
The previous remark is correct.
The Agency shall be financed by a combination of revenue from fees and charges and by a compensatory subsidy from the European Union.
The Agency has submitted a number of alternative financing proposals to the Commission, including the introduction of regular fees, as with a number of other EU agencies.
The Agency points out that, according to its Communication on the revision of the REACH Regulation of 5 March 2018 (COM(2018) 116 final), the Commission will implement all possible options to ensure the Agency's sustainable financing in the future.

EUROPEAN INNOVATION AND TECHNOLOGY INSTITUTE (EIT) INTRODUCTION 3.9.1.
The European Institute of Innovation and Technology (hereinafter referred to as the Institute of Innovation and Technology (hereinafter referred to as the Institute of Innovation and Technology), based in Budapest, was established by Regulation (EC) No 294/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council (82).
The aim of the Institute is to contribute to sustainable economic growth in Europe and to increase competitiveness by strengthening the innovation capacity of the Member States and the European Union.
The Institute receives financial support from an increasing number of Knowledge and Innovation Communities (KICs) that link higher education, research and business, and thus support innovation and entrepreneurship.
The KICs coordinate the activities of hundreds of partners.

Other comments 3.9.7.
In December 2016                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           
The modification of the individual grant agreement with Climate KIC was signed even in January 2017, after the end of the funding period.
The increase in individual reimbursements agreed in these changes allowed the KICs to receive an additional EUR 15 million in EIT financial assistance (EUR 6.0 million in addition for Climate KIC, EUR 5.6 million for EIT Health, EUR 2.2 million for KIC InnoEnergy and EUR 1.2 million for EIT RawMaterials).
This approach is contrary to the intention to encourage the KICs to develop sources of finance and to encourage them to gradually reduce their financial dependence on the EIT.
It could also affect fair competition between the KICs, as the co-financing of expenditure also plays a role in the annual grant decisions.
3.9.8.
Also due to changes in the business of KIC InnoEnergy and EIT Digital some in the original business of not planned activities in the total value of about 3.3 million euros and 0.6 million euros in the original business of KIC InnoEnergy and EIT Digital were added.
The Court considers that the activity added to KIC InnoEnergy constitutes a substantial change in the original business plan on the basis of which the maximum amount of financial assistance in question was obtained.
Since the amount of the grants awarded to each of the KICs is the result of a performance-oriented review procedure to which their originally proposed operations are subject, further substantial changes to these operations are the subject of the grant decisions and the equal treatment of the KICs, and thus a violation of Article 180(4) of the Financial Regulation.
3.9.9.
COMMENTS ON THE RELIABILITY OF THE CURRENCY 3.9.10.
In 2017, the Institute introduced a paperless payment system.
Although this led to changes in his procedures and his accounting system, the accounting system has not been revalidated since 2012.
COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.9.11.
In order to further strengthen the internal control system for financial assistance to KICs, the EIT provided centralised ex ante controls for those KIC partners whose cost statements exceeded EUR 325 000.
The controls were carried out by two economic operators on behalf of the EIT (86) and carried out on certified cost statements of the KIC partners.
The results of ex post controls carried out by another EIT-commissioned business enterprise confirm that the new approach to certified cost statements is effective and important, as most of the material errors identified concerned cost statements that had not been subject to these ex ante controls.
(86) In previous years, the certification was carried out by numerous private economic operators on behalf of the individual KIC partners, whose submitted cost statements exceeded the threshold of EUR 325 000 (refund of actual costs and unit costs).

In the first wave KICs, according to the EIT assessment reports, the performance of Climate KICs was, in particular, insufficient.
3.9.14.
The EIT evaluated the implementation of the business plans and then calculated some corrections.
These corrections did not have any financial impact on the KICs.
In line with the Horizon 2020 methodology for the grant calculation, the EIT applies only the higher of the two in the case of corrections, which are necessary due to financial controls and performance assessments.
While this methodology is appropriate for individual Horizon 2020 projects, it is less appropriate for the grants granted to the KICs to finance a wide range of different activities.
It is questionable whether it is justified to set aside corrections to be made on the basis of the performance, e.g. for educational activities, against corrections to be made on the basis of financial controls, which, for example, may affect innovation projects.
3.9.15.
In 2017, all KICs, in line with EIT's strategies, have adopted a viable financing, which is an important step in the direction of the KIC's greater sustainability in the future.
Nevertheless, the first wave KICs still generated little revenue (between 2% and 6% of the cost of the KICs' value added activities) and little progress was made in 2017.
The co-financing by the KIC partners is also low (and lower than is foreseen in the original individual financial assistance agreements): the KIC value-added activities are still financed by 62% to 90% by EIT (depending on the KIC).
3.9.16.
The EIT publishes job advertisements on its own website and on the DG Human Resources and Security website, but usually not on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO).
3.9.17.
In line with its framework financial regulation, the agencies should establish a single framework for the electronic storage and exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (88). Since a corresponding framework also applies for the EU institutions, the Commission is currently developing a comprehensive IT framework, covering all stages of public procurement procedures.
It launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), the electronic tender in the online edition of the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and the electronic submission of tenders (2015).
OTHER COMMENTS 3.9.18.
The current interim director of the EIT took office in July 2014.
A selection procedure for the appointment of a new director was launched in 2016, but was unsuccessful.
Since then, no new recruitment procedure has been initiated.
To fill this post over such a long period of time ad interim is contrary to the statute, according to which a post may be temporarily occupied for a period of a year at most.
3.9.19.
Article 5(1) of the Statute of the EIT shall be the staff of the EIT [...] employed directly by the EIT within the framework of a fixed-term contract of employment and shall apply to the staff of the EIT to the conditions of employment of other servants of the European Union.
The EIT can therefore only offer temporary temporary workers with a maximum duration of five years, which can be extended by five years.
Those employees who have started their work at the EIT shortly after the EIT was established in 2009 will reach the maximum contract period of ten years in 2020, which in the coming years could lead to complaints in connection with the continuity of the measures and the administration.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/69 DE Comments of the Court of Justice of the EIT-Gründenverordnung regarding the tasks of the institute the ămobilization of funds from public and private sources and the use of resources according to the provisions of this regulation.
In particular, the Institute aims to raise a significant and growing share of its budget from private financial contributions and revenue generated by its own activities.
Despite this provision, which clearly refers to the budget of the EIT, the contribution from Horizon 2020 budget amounted to 99% of its budget for 2015.
Although the institution may use unused funds (i.e. funds not committed or released at the end of the year) in the budget of the following three years, it has not adjusted its procedures in time to allow the budget of 2015-2017 to estimate EUR 26.6 million in the 2014 grant agreements.
These funds were available because the KICs used less funds than expected.
According to the Commission's original objective, the Institute should gain its financial autonomy in 2010.
In June 2011, however, the Institute received only partial financial autonomy, since financial assistance and procurement procedures worth more than EUR 60 000 are still subject to prior approval by the Directorate-General for Education and Culture, which is subordinated to the Institute.
The Institute supports the Master School programme of EIT Digital, in which 16 European universities participate.
The model for the reimbursement of the costs of the universities is based on a combination of a lump sum of a maximum of 8 000 Euro/students (comprising the provisions of the Erasmus Mundus programme) plus the actual costs including a flat-rate calculated indirect costs.
On this basis, the universities received an average of 15 000 Euro/students in 2015 (including the lump sum).
However, the model was not defined at any time, and it is not possible to distinguish between the activities to be covered by the lump sum and those to be covered by the actual costs.
The Institute should switch to a clear and formal model based on a single methodology, such as a single lump sum based on proof of costs.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/71 EN Court of Auditors' comments The financial assistance for the calendar year 2015 was only awarded in April 2015 and the grant agreements were signed in June and July 2015.
The award of the grants and the signing of the grant agreements took place in April 2016 for the 2016 calendar year.
Despite an improvement in 2016, these delays in the decisions on the granting of grants and the signing of the grant agreements lead to uncertainty and the willingness of the partners to commit resources at the beginning of the year and to initiate the activities.

This not only violates the Statute, which states that the temporary occupation may not last longer than a year, but that the frequent changes and long-term interim changes also confuse the stakeholders and affect the strategic continuity. With a budget of 2.4 billion euros in the period 2014-2020, the Institute is an important player in the implementation of the Horizon 2020 programme.
The Commission has created a central support body for Horizon 2020 to ensure coherence between the programme-run bodies in areas such as legal services, IT tools, grant management, dissemination and exploitation of research results, etc.
However, unlike institutions such as the Commission's executive agencies and public-private partnerships, the Institute does not have direct access to the support body, but must, in any case, be approved by the Commission's superordinate Directorate-General.
This requirement affects the efficiency of the Institute's activities.

C 434/72 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 EN Court's observations The coordination and representation of the KICs is carried out by the legal entities of the KICs, which are financed almost entirely by the Institute.
The Court paid particular attention to the procurement procedures carried out by these bodies, which it considers to be a highly risky area.
In accordance with the 2015 grant agreements, the legal entities of the KICs and/or the KIC partners must ensure that the best possible price/performance ratio is achieved in procurements, or that the lowest price criterion is applied where appropriate.
For all contracts of more than EUR 60 000, the legal persons of the KICs and/or the KIC partners shall, according to the grant agreements, request at least three economic operators to tender and document the award procedure to demonstrate its transparency.
The Court carried out a sample of procurement procedures worth around EUR 7 million carried out by the legal entities of the KIC and financed entirely by the EIT.
The examination revealed significant shortcomings, such as direct procurement, lack of essential elements in tenders, significant extensions of original procurement in terms of duration and/or scope, extensions without limitation of duration and/or scope, or quality/price weightings, which instigated price competition.
The Institute also identified the M the M the KICs' procurement procedures with a KIC legal entity and set up an action plan to improve the procurement procedures of all KICs' legal entities in the future.
Despite the substantial increase in the budget from EUR 309 million (2008-2013) to EUR 2.4 billion (2014-2020) and despite the fact that there have been six and no longer three KICs since the end of 2016, the number of posts approved to the Institute has barely changed (see Table 2).
As the Court noted in its Special Report No 4/2016 (9), there is a risk that the Institute will not have sufficient capacity to address the increased workload.
The interim director of the institute pointed to this risk in the annual report of the institute for 2015.

The EIT should make it clear that it is possible to submit changes to the KIC Framework Partnership Agreements of the EIT at any time during the period under review in relation to the individual grant agreements in accordance with the provisions of the KIC Framework Partnership Agreements.
The KICs's amendments were subject to a technical and financial assessment by the EIT and prior approval by the European Commission.
Subsequently, the changes were signed in December 2016.
In the case of EIT Climate-KIC, the KIC was formally notified of the approval of the amendment application on 21 December 2016 (i.e. within the period of application).
As regards the increase in the individual reimbursements, the EIT points out that the KICs did not receive any additional financial assistance as a result of the changes to the individual financial assistance agreements in 2016.
The total amount of the final financial assistance (241.8 million euros) was significantly lower than the amount initially awarded (274.9 million euros).
As regards the call for KICs to develop their own sources of funding and to become financially viable, we refer to our response to Section 3.9.15.
In the context of the assessment of the change proposals, the EIT, after consultation with the European Commission, concluded that the adjustment of the individual refund proposals was in line with the applicable legal basis and did not affect the equal treatment of KICs.
The possibility of adjusting the individual refund rates was open to all KICs on equal terms.
As regards the second observation, the EIT considers that the amendments corresponded to Article 180(4) of the Financial Regulation, since they did not call into question the decisions on the award of grants and did not run counter to the equal treatment of applicants.
It should be noted that there is no provision for a materiality threshold that indicates what change of a measure is to be considered to be significant when assessing whether the change is relevant for the provision of the grant.
Whether the inclusion of new activities of the said provision corresponds, must be determined on the basis of the relevance and impact of the activities for the entire KIC business plan on a case-by-case basis.
The EIT carried out the assessment prior to the approval of the change proposals and concluded that the changes did not call into question the decisions on the award of grants.
Since each KIC had the ability to include new new KICs in its changed business on equal terms, the equal treatment of KICs was also ensured.
Finally, the EIT points out that, in the case of EIT InnoEnergy, the only activity in question was only 3.9% of the modified budget estimate of the KIC budget.
For EIT Digital, this share was 0.6%.

3.9.13.
The 2016 individual financial assistance agreements with EIT Health and EIT RawMaterials were signed more recently than foreseen, as the framework partnership agreements had to be signed first.
The individual financial assistance agreements for 2017 and 2018 were systematically signed in February, so that the KICs were able to take up their activities in good time in the respective year.
Due to their dynamic and fast-moving nature, innovative measures cannot be planned linearly.
Some innovation projects or projects do not meet the expectations of their potential and need to be stopped during the implementation of the grant agreements. Moreover, some of the operational activities of the KICs, such as master and doctoral studies or long-term research and innovation projects, are planned from the ground up for several years.
The EIT intends to address this problem after 2020 by entering into multi-annual grant agreements with KICs, provided that the EIT budget allocates corresponding appropriations for commitments in multi-annual tranches.
In fact, the EIT has followed the methodology laid down in the legal basis ăHorizont 2020, for the calculation of grants without restriction, and will continue to comply with the current legislation in the future.
The financial sustainability of KIC is a unique ambition of the EIT-KIC model and one of the most difficult aspects of the EIT's mission.
In the meantime, some of the innovation communities can already have a serious co-financing, with which they compete, and generate considerable revenue compared with their budgets.
EIT Digital, for example, co-financed 26% (22 million euros) to cover the costs for the 2016 KIC value-added activities. In addition to this, the partner organisations carried out and paid for the KIC activities to the tune of more than 200 million euros.
Another example is EIT Health: KIC generated more than 6 million euros in revenues in its first year of operation compared to the total funding it had received from the EIT (around 19 million euros).

COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.10.8.
In 2014, the Commission concluded a framework agreement with a contractor on the acquisition of software licenses and maintenance and support services on behalf of more than 50 EU institutions and bodies (including the Agency).
The contractor of the framework agreement acts as intermediary between the agency and companies that can meet the agency's needs.
For these intermediate services, the contractor of the framework agreement adds two to nine percent to the supplier prices. In 2017, the contractor of the framework agreement made payments of a total of 1.7 million euros.
The Agency did not systematically compare the calculated prices and prices with the offers of the companies and did not systematically compare the invoices issued to the contractor of the framework agreement. Following a court decision, EPSO decided that only job advertisements in the official languages of the EU or in the languages indicated in the Agency's decision-making act can be published on the EPSO website.

EMSA would like to see a solution which would provide both a sufficient degree of transparency and the principle of sound financial management.

DE ANNEX Follow-up of observations from previous years Statements of the Court The Agency plans to transfer the administrative staff from Heraklion to Athens in 2016 in part.

This high rate is mainly due to transfers to Title I (personnel expenditure) and Title III (operational expenditure) and is mainly related to IT investments and the acquisition of a service car just before the end of the year.
As foreseen in the Agency's financial rules, external evaluations of the Agency's performance in 2014 and 2015 were carried out and the final reports were submitted in October 2015 and May 2016 respectively.
The 2014 evaluation concluded that the operational core activities carried out under the 2014 Work Programme are clearly related to the Agency's legal mandate and that the Agency's effectiveness has been well assessed.
However, there was a need for improvement in the division of the Agency between Heraklion and Athens, which leads to heavy work and a lack of communication and cooperation.
The 2015 evaluation concluded that the Agency's activities and outputs meet the needs of network and information security across the EU and across the Member States and that the Agency effectively meets the expectations of its stakeholders.
However, the report stressed that the communication between the Agency and its stakeholders, who believe that the mandate and scope of the Agency are too limited, needs to be improved.
The Agency is implementing an action plan, which it has subsequently agreed with the Management Board.
In 2016, the Agency moved eight more employees to Athens, reducing the number of employees in Heraklion to 14 (1).
As the Court pointed out in its 2013 report, the costs could probably be further reduced by the pooling of the entire staff in one location.
EN C 434/82 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE AGENCY 3.11.8.
Although the transfer to the new accountant was never formalized, informal meetings with the former current accountant were held to pass on knowledge.
The new accountant also received an updated training on SAP to ensure a good understanding of the accounting system.
Nevertheless, ENISA will take corrective measures to ensure an adequate transfer between outgoing and new staff.
3.11.9.
All job offers published by EPSO must be translated into all EU official languages.
In view of its limited budget, ENISA is unfortunately unable to bear these costs.
However, the Agency uses traditional and social media, and has committed to the creation of an agency-wide portal to reduce the risks associated with the publication of job advertisements, as many of the decentralised institutions face the same problem.
ENISA has not carried out a formal operational and financial impact assessment of Brexit, as it has no significant direct impact on ENISA's budget, operation and management.
Nevertheless, internal procedures, i.e. procurement and recruitment, were revised in the context of Brexit.

In December 2016, the Agency's accountant was appointed interim head of the Financial and Procurement Department in addition to this function.
In this additional function, he is responsible for the management of the staff, which is responsible for the introduction and the management of commitments and payments.
The financial rules of the Agency stipulate that those financial operators are under the authority of the authorising officer.
However, according to the principle of separation of duties, the powers of instruction and the management of accounts are separate functions and are mutually exclusive.
In 2014, the Commission concluded a framework agreement on behalf of more than 50 EU institutions and bodies (including the Agency) with a contractor on the acquisition of IT hardware and software and on maintenance and support services (IT services).
In the event of a paid payment of about 47 000 euros, the agency had acquired, via the contractor, IT services without a competitive process or prior market analysis. In 2017, payments of a total of 1.1 million euros were made to the contractor.

AGENCY FOR EUROPEAN GNSS (GLOBAL SATELLITE NAVIGATION SYSTEM) (GSA) INTRODUCTION 3.16.1.
The Agency for the European GNSS (the Global Satellite Navigation System) (hereinafter the Agency), also the Agency, whose seat was moved from Brussels to Prague on 1 September 2012(131), was created by Regulation (EU) No 912/2010 of the European Parliament and of the Council (132) repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 1321/2004 (133) on the administrative bodies of the European satellite navigation programmes and amending Regulation (EC) No 683/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council(134).
The European GNSS Authority, established under Council Regulation (EC) No 1321/2004, officially took over on 1 January 2007 all the tasks previously entrusted to the Galileo Joint Undertaking, the Agency continuing to carry out these tasks as an agency for the European GNSS on the basis of Regulation (EU) No 912/2010, as amended.

Emphasis on a situation 3.16.7.
On 15 December 2016, the Agency concluded a framework agreement worth EUR 1.5 billion on the operation of the Galileo satellite system during the period 2017-2027.
The agreement was awarded following a public procurement procedure.
One of the tenderers involved brought proceedings against the Agency before the Court of Justice of the European Union in order to challenge the outcome of the award procedure.
The judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union will decide on the legality and regularity of the procurement procedure for the framework agreement and all associated individual and future payments.
The Agency has reported the facts in the previous financial statements 2017 and has explained and in addition stated that in 2017 49 million euros (7 % of the budget of 2017 including the amounts received by the transfer agreements) were paid out in connection with the framework agreement.
Note 3.16.8.
Negotiations on an agreement on the details of the withdrawal are under way.
The Agency operates both the Galileo Security Centre (GSMC) and Galileo ground stations in the United Kingdom.
In the annual accounts, the Agency, in the chapter ăEvents following the closing date, refers to the Commission's decision, adopted on 24 January 2018, to move the second location of the Galileo Security Centre (GSMC) from the United Kingdom to Spain.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/101 EN ANNEX Follow-up of comments from previous years Court's comments The property, plant and equipment (net book value: EUR 1.0 million) are not insured.
The accounting systems were last validated in 2012.
The promised validation of the systems due to the expected major changes in the procedures and the flow of information after the relocation of the agency did not take place.
The new accountant plans the next validation for 2020.
The Agency has established Emergency Continuity Plans for the security sites in France, the United Kingdom and the Netherlands.
However, there is no contingency plan for the headquarters in Prague and the agency as a whole.
The Agency's annual work plan for 2015 was adopted only in March 2015 and the adoption of its multiannual work programme for 2014-2020 is still pending.
The late adoption of central planning documents entails risks for the achievement of the Agency's objectives.
In 2015, the agency had a high staff turnover with 14 outgoing and 26 new employees.
In its November 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) concluded that no agency-wide annual risk assessment was carried out in 2016 and that the significant risks for the Agency are not recognised in its planning documents or in its annual reports.
In addition, the IAS noted that the terminology used for the various elements of the performance measurement system is not uniform, making performance monitoring more difficult.
The Agency and IAS agreed on a plan for corrective measures. At 2.8 million euros and 46% respectively (2015: 2.5 million euros and 42%), the rate of committed appropriations for Title II (administrative expenditure) for the following financial year was high.
EN C 434/102 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE AGENCY 3.16.10.
The GSA agrees with the Court's comment.
In 2015, the GSA outsourced its accounts to the European Commission, so that the Commission's accounting officer (within the DG Budget) provides all the services, including the validation of local systems, that are required under Article 50 of the framework financial regulation applicable to the agencies.
The validation approach is currently being developed and planned within DG Budget services.
3.16.11.
The publication of job advertisements on the EPSO platform requires translation into all EU official languages, whereas English is the Agency's only working language and the publication of vacancies in English is regarded as a second preselection step in order to ensure that our working language is first understood.
Furthermore, the translation of job offers into all EU official languages would mean an additional financial and time-consuming effort for the agency, so that it would not be useful for the above-mentioned reasons. Instead, the GSA intends to publish all job offers on the agency-wide portal, which the agencies consider to be equivalent to the EPSO and offers the EU citizens a sufficient amount of transparency.
In addition, the agency also publishes its job advertisements on specialized space websites.
Electronic communications in TED (published by the Office for Publications) for the publication of contract notices, contract notices, notices of corrections, notices of amendments, etc. are currently used in the GSA, whenever this is indicated in accordance with Article 264 of the application provisions.
The Agency also intends to use the e-Tendering system TED to create and publish tenders.
Against this background, the GSA is currently coordinating with the Office for Publications to register and create a system account.
In view of offers of high value (above the thresholds of Article 118(1) HO), the GSA is currently taking the necessary administrative steps to use the ăe Submission module of the information system ăe-PRIOR (provided by DG DIGIT) developed by the European Commission to ensure that the electronic system that is set up for the submission of all offers meets all the requirements of HO and AB.
It is noted that the module ăe-Submission is currently supported exclusively by open procedures and that the GSA is therefore allowed to use it only for such procedures.
In this context, the GSA has already held an initial coordination meeting with DG DIGIT and is in the process of concluding and signing an agreement with it in order to define the framework for ăe Submission and to begin its implementation.

COMMENTS ON THE ECONOMIC AFFAIRS OF THE BUDGETARY AFFAIRS AND SERVICES 3.17.9.
The Agency welcomes the fact that the Court wishes to further improve its management of the ETZ in terms of both financial and operational controls.
In order to resolve a repetition of the problem encountered in 2017 at the ETZ of inland, coastal and marine waters, the task in question was taken out of the annual action plan and transferred to the Agency.
The Agency is committed to maintaining the current level of control of grants granted to the ETZ.
The Agency confirms that it has changed the requirements for the financial performance of bidders in the course of 2017 and that the bidders are now required to provide information on financial indicators (liquid, solvency and profitability), and that, in accordance with the provisions of Article 147(1)(a) of the provisions on application (AB), a minimum turnover of at least twice the value of the estimated annual value of the contract is now required.
The Agency would like to stress once again that the decision to offer framework contracts to individual contractors has been taken consciously and taking into account the fact that the competition is limited to the relevant markets and the nature and complexity of the services to be provided.
When awarding individual contracts on the basis of the framework contracts, the Agency takes into account not only the contractually agreed days, but also the number of days required for the execution of the tasks, in order to calculate a value for the budget, which must be set for a specific individual order.
Only then will negotiations be opened with the contractor with regard to the details of his offer, with care being taken to achieve the best price-performance ratio.
In the event of a resumption of the tender, the Agency has no control over further negotiations on the bids of the tenderers.
In accordance with the decision of the Management Board of 9 November 2015 to introduce an electronic invoicing in the EEA for the electronic handling of the procurement procedures, the Agency introduced electronic invoicing in the course of 2014 for certain procedures, and is now in the process of extending the application of this module to all its procedures, while the electronic tendering procedure has been in force since 1 January 2015 for all general invitations to tender.
The integration of the electronic submission of tenders was launched at the beginning of December 2017 and the first call for tenders for this module was launched on 18 June 2018 (EEA/COM/18/002  the provision of publishing services for the EEA).
The Agency takes note of the Court's comment and confirms that it is currently adapting its selection and recruitment procedures in the following points: a) The completion of the individual steps in the various phases (pre-selection, selection, interview and written examination) is confirmed in the relevant documents, in addition, with the time (not only with the date). b) An electronic (paperless) procedure is introduced in order to improve the reporting process and the written examination is systematically prepared in the pre-selection phase.
3.17.14.
The EPSO has rejected a publication for the agency with the view that the precondition for the translation of all job offers into all official languages has not been fulfilled.
However, the Agency does not have the resources or resources to respond to the EPSO's call.
In this case, not only all job offers should be translated, but also the applications should be processed in all official languages, which is associated with unsustainable additional costs.
Like most other EU agencies, the Agency has therefore looked for an alternative to the EPSO website and, since May 2018, has been using a website for the same purpose, which has been set up and maintained by the network of EU agencies.
In addition, the agency uses LinkedIn, its own website and its own Facebook pages to ensure the best possible distribution.
EN C 434/108 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 COMMENTS ON BUDGETARY CURRENCY 3.17.15.
Before concluding the transfer agreement for Copernicus with DG GROW, the Agency has subsequently indicated that the conditions for pre-financing are not compatible with the financial regulation (Article 7 AR of the 2014 Financial Regulation).
First of all, DG GROW, in its reply, showed its intelligibleness, but DG BUDG, which is responsible for the preparation of the standard template, refused to change the transfer agreement.
Following the start of the implementation of the transfer agreement, the Agency continued to point out the problems and stated that it is regularly obliged to apply exceptions in order to continue its operational activity; this prompted DG GROW to change the pre-financing conditions of the transfer agreement in August 2017 and to make additional pre-financing in November 2017.

Emphasis on a point of view 3.20.8.
From the end of 2017, the personnel situation at the B thero deteriorated exponentially.
At management level, four out of ten head of unit and 18 out of 27 head of unit were not filled.
Three out of four Head of Unit posts and five out of ten Head of Division posts were not filled in the Department of Administration, which represents a serious challenge for the Head of the Department.
Furthermore, at the end of May 2018, 129 posts were filled for temporary staff, but 78 were still open.
Of the posts for contract staff, 71 were staffed and 13 were still open.
The B Thero does not currently have the administrative capacity to fill so many vacancies (see Table 2).
Overall, the continuation of the activities of the B, to the present extent, is greatly affected by this situation.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/119 COMMENTS ON LEGAL ACTIVITY AND ORDERAL ACTIVITY OF PAYMENTS AND INTERNAL CONTROLS OF ENTERPRISES The nature of its activities gives rise to major risks for the European Union 3.20.9.
Since 2016, the B thero has been faced with an unprecedented expansion of tasks and activities to provide operational and technical support to Member States in the context of the migration crisis.
This is reflected in an increase in the budget budget from the original EUR 19 million in 2016 to EUR 79 million following the second change in the budget in 2017.
The number of procurement procedures increased from 87 in 2015 to 140 in 2017.
Payments increased by 225% from 2 578 in 2015 to 8 381 in 2017.
3.20.10.
The B Thero is one of the few institutions of the European Union, which has several locations.
In addition to its headquarters in Malta, with 179 staff, the B thero manages two major support activities in Greece and Italy, in which in 2017 747 experts from Member States and associated countries, 202 cultural mediators (interpreters), 178 temporary staff and 21 staff members of the B thero were involved.
3.20.11.
As the Court noted in its Special Report No. 6/2017 ăReaction of the EU to the refugee crisis: the Hotspot concept, the Court of Auditors, in high proportions, refrains from providing sufficient resources to the Member States.
The efficiency of the activities is particularly affected by the fact that the Member States send their experts for a very short period of time (six to eight weeks).
The extraordinary operational challenge posed by the migration crisis was not weakened by a sound management structure and effective internal controls 3.20.12.
When the activities to support Greece and Italy were launched in 2015, the B thero was confronted with the fact that the Member States were providing insufficient resources for deployments.
It had already been difficult for the Bureau to fill the posts provided for in its establishment plan.
Since 2014, the court has regularly repeated its remark that the B thero has to struggle with a high staff turnover.
The Court has repeatedly stressed in its previous annual reports that this situation represents a serious risk for achieving the objectives set in the annual and multiannual work programmes.
Despite repeated attempts (36 recruitment procedures and 100 new recruitment procedures in 2017), the B thero has failed to recruit and maintain employees (see also paragraph 3.20.8).
3.20.13.
The extraordinary challenge in the operational area caused by the migration crisis was not weakened by a solid management structure.
The Board of Directors did not set up an internal audit post at the Board of Directors, and the actions in Greece and Italy were not subject to an internal audit.
By the end of 2017, the Board of Directors had limited supervision of the budget.
3.20.14.
The B Thero does not set up an internal legal service nor are legal documents systematically internalized.
The B sucho assigns most of the legal questions (mainly personnel and procurement questions) to other legal questions, without, in internal decisions or guidelines, being clearly defined, who may assign which legal questions externally, to which law firm and under which conditions.
Although the B thero uses at least eight different law firms, a comprehensive list of all the relevant firms, cases and expert opinions is missing.
3.20.15.
Legal services are not adequately carried out at the B theo to ensure that they are exclusively used to defend the interests of the B theo and not to defend the interests of individuals.
The relevant procedures for protecting against conflicts of interest are not always effective.
In general, the use of external means reduces the possibility of settling disputes before bringing an action.
3.20.16.
The facts set out in paragraphs 3.20.13-3.20.14 expose the bank to the risk of financial losses and losses of reputation.
These matters are currently being investigated internally by the B thero.
Many essential obligations against rules resulting from lack of internal controls Payments for auxiliary services 3.20.17.
In 2017, €7.7 million of €7.7 million was paid for auxiliary services.
Since no competitive public procurement procedure had taken place, the Court found the order for auxiliary services in Greece, in respect of the year 2016, to be contrary to the law.
Nevertheless, the B thero made payments in the course of this illegal order in 2017 of 4.8 million euros.
EN C 434/120 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 3.20.18.
The procurement procedures for auxiliary services carried out in Malta in 2017 (volume of payments in 2017: EUR 1.0 million) were inexhaustible in their execution (e.g. short deadlines for the submission of tenders, lack of transparency for extension of the deadline), which made the competition one of the most important reasons for the public procurement procedures.
As a result, the procedures had to be repeated several times because no tenders were received.
3.20.19.
The accounts were insufficiently monitored for compliance with national regulations for temporary employment, which exposed the bank to significant financial and reputational risks.
In addition, there were significant weaknesses in the supervision of working time certificates for auxiliary staff and identified irregularities.
Payments for staff expenditure 3.20.20.
The personnel-related payments amounted to 13.5 million euros in 2017. The Court found serious errors in four of the 14 recruitment procedures.
3.20.21.
For example, the B thero did not publish a job advertisement to fill the post of senior consultant, but did the recruitment directly on the basis of a reserve list, which had been prepared for the post of head of department.
The extension of the deadline was not always justified in view of the number of applications received by the original deadline.
3.20.22.
Some procedures for hiring AD staff were not suitable for the advertised grade.
In a procedure for filling a management post in the ăVerwaltungstungsteilung ăVerwaltung the job advertisement was more restrictive than for the same posts in other departments.
In a further procedure, the examination of the suitability of the applicants was not adequately documented by the B thero.
Payments for rents and related works 3.20.23.
The total rent for all B for the different locations amounted to two million euros in 2017.
The Court noted that the B Thero had signed the rental contracts for the extension of the headquarters in Malta and several new B Theros in Athens, Lesbos and Chios, without having previously adequately analysed the local market.
3.20.24.
In June 2017, the B thero signed a lease on the B therofl on Lesbos.
It also accepted a contract with the landlord   the without any contest  the works for the adaptation of the rented building to the needs of the B theos.
The value of the contract (0.7 million euros during the first months of the lease contract) exceeded the annual value of the contract many times.
The investment of significant investments in rented buildings is accompanied by significant financial and operational risks.
3.20.25.
In 2018, the B thero decided to contract a rental contract to B to B to the bank in Chios and related construction services.
It is currently designed to limit the financial exposure to the exposure to risk as a result of the exposure to risk.
Travel expenses 3.20.26.
The Court found at its examination in 2016 an order for travel services for the value of 4 million euros in violation of the law.
The contract was awarded to a bidder who did not meet all the selection criteria.
On the basis of this irregular order, the B, the B, continued to make payments in the amount of 1.5 million in 2017.
3.20.27.
In 2017, the B thero identified significant errors in the recognition of travel services, in particular the lack of evidence to demonstrate that the travel services in question were actually requested or provided.
This matter is currently being examined internally by the B iso.
Other payments 3.20.28.
Other services, such as cleaning services, security services, interpreting and consulting services, which were based on public procurement procedures, were also systematically affected by the same rules.
The Court established significant rules for the determination of the needs for the firm, the preparation of the specifications, the choice of the type of contract, the award procedures applied, the deadlines for the submission of tenders, the evaluation and award procedures (i.e. the weighting of the price criteria against the quality criteria), the changes and extensions of contracts, the execution of the contracts and the execution of the services provided.
These rules have an impact on the principles of competition, transparency, equal treatment and non-discrimination of bidders.
The following digits contain some examples for the above mentioned angels.
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/121 3.20.29.
In 2017, the B thero awarded a service contract on advisory services relating to the implementation of the Action Plan on the Greek islands directly.
The contract was awarded to a pre-elected economic operator without any of the procurement procedures provided for in the Financial Regulation being applied.
The procurement procedure and all related payments (EUR 992000) were therefore unlawful.
3.20.30.
Since then, the B, the B, has changed the original contract of EUR 5000 with a law firm in 2016 several times and increased it to EUR 259000 in 2018.
Payments of a total of €98332 were made to the contract in 2017 in the amount of €98332, partly for consultancy services that required a competitive public procurement procedure.
The changes and payments concerning these advisory services were therefore contrary to the rules.
3.20.31.
The execution of the 2013 contract (value: 120 000 euros, 2017 raised to 132 000 euros) about the organization of four to six major events in an international hotel for a period of four years was not in line with the original subject matter of the contract.
The B Thero used the contract instead for about 50 smaller events.
The execution of the contract has therefore not been carried out in accordance with the law.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/123 Court's observations A framework agreement with a duration of two months with a value of 3.6 million euros of auxiliaries in connection with the resolution of the migration crisis was awarded in February 2016 directly by the Court.
The framework contract was awarded to a pre-selected economic operator without any of the procurement procedures provided for in the EU Financial Regulation. Therefore, the award of the contract is not in accordance with the relevant EU rules and the 2016 payments in the amount of EUR 592 273 based on the contract are in breach of the rules.

The total value of the framework contract for the four lots awarded and awarded (Lose 2-5) was 60 million euros over four years.
However, this contractor fulfilled the financial requirements of the selection criteria (annual turnover of EUR 1 million) only for two of the three previous years; for the other year, an undertaking was concluded with a joint organisation, according to which the contractor made its turnover (equity loan) available to the contractor.
The extraordinary meeting of the European Council of 23 April 2015 and the ten-point plan on migration adopted by the Foreign and Home Affairs Ministers on 20 April 2015 called on Member States to ensure the collection of fingerprints on all migrants.
This required the purchase and subsequent donation to the Greek State of 90 fingerprint scanners and 90 compatible computers (equipment) of an amount of 1.1 million euros under a grant agreement between the Commission and the B thero.
However, there were no officials of the B, who were on the spot to meet this demand. DE C 434/126 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE BLYROS The BLYRO thanks the Court for the very helpful report.
At the same time, the Court is grateful for the Court's appreciation for its appreciation of the first difficult situation, in which the Court found itself in the period under review due to the enormous expansion of its tasks: in addition, it was charged to support the Member States and to participate in the implementation of initiatives at EU level, to which the redistribution and declaration of the EU-Turkey, the increase in the budget, the exponential increase in payments and the increase in the award procedures (both in terms of number and complexity).
In addition, the company has to manage a large number of sites and a large number of management positions (department heads, department heads, sector heads) are not filled.
In his answer, the Bureau will refer to some of the Court's observations, but, overall, it will accept the report and the observations it contains.

3.20.6., 3.20.8. and 3.20.12.
The Court rightly underlines the fact that the staff situation in the B thero has deteriorated and is insufficient and that it is also an obstacle to the proper functioning of the internal control system.
The current personnel situation is one of the major challenges of the Court's observations, which can largely be seen as a result of the lack of resources for structured and regular work.
The B-ro is addressing this problem directly and is urgently addressing recruitment procedures to fill management posts and other important (operational and administrative) posts on the basis of a sound recruitment plan preceded by a need assessment.
In addition, the company makes efforts in the area of employee satisfaction in order to solve the problem of staff turnover. Although, in this context, it must be taken into account that the low correction coefficient, compared to the fairly high cost of living in Malta, plays an important role in this, the company acknowledges that efforts must be made to improve employee satisfaction.
Some measures such as flexible work opportunities, improved internal communication and organisation of employee events have already been introduced.
3.20.9. and 3.20.19.
The Court gives a correct account of the difficulties and the rapid increase in financial transactions and procurement procedures, expressed in absolute figures.
These figures speak a clear language, but basically reflect the balances in the financial sector and in the awarding of the balances not in an appropriate way.
These figures do not take into account other facts and measures which add to the compulsory situation in the procurement field, such as the following two aspects: the involvement of externally funded experts (Articles 204 and 287 of the Financial Regulations), which represents a high workload for the procurement sector.
In the coming years, further deterioration can be expected in this respect, as the medical expert has to be involved in supporting tasks related to medical information about countries of origin.
, market-specific difficulties and restrictions related to our geographical territories.
In the Italian and Greek regions, the conditions for a competitive market for the provision of services and products for the B thero are not very good.
In addition, the company is not typical as a customer as regards the order size of the economic operators in Malta, as they mostly lack the capacity to meet the requirements of the company, which is the result of a larger size of the company.

It should also be noted that, due to its operational capacity, its geographically widely spread area of operation and (as the Court rightly points out) the restrictions on the use of Member State experts, the company is dependent on contractors on an unusually large scale.
This is a factor which is a factor which augments the tasks associated with the award and financial sector (including decentralised financial actors) as a result of the fact that in Greece, Italy and Cyprus, the financial sector and the financial sector, in particular, is in the process of becoming operational in Greece, Italy and Cyprus.

The Institute was the defendant at the end of the financial year 2017 in four disputes in connection with three award procedures brought before the Court of First Instance by rejected tenderers.
In each of these cases, the applicant requested the annulment of the award decision and the award of damages.
The claim for compensation in these four cases amounts to EUR 700 000 or 9% of the annual budget of the Institute.
According to the evaluation of the Institute's external attorneys, a reduction of EUR 75 000 (or 1% of the Institute's annual budget) was recorded to cover the expected losses.
The judgment of the Court of First Instance in each of these cases will decide on the legality and legality of the award procedures for these contracts and the future payments.

The six agreements on business tariffs and the 2016 payments on the basis of them in the amount of around 2.1 million euros are therefore in breach of the rules.

In 2016, a total of 8.9 million euros of payments were made to the contractor of the framework contract.
The Agency did not systematically compare the calculated prices and prices with the offers of the suppliers and did not systematically compare the invoices issued to the contractor of the framework contract.

COMMENTS ON THE ECONOMICITY OF BUDGETARY CURRENCY AND SERVICES 3.26.8. In 2017, the Agency had difficulties in reaching a sufficient number of tenderers in a number of medium-value procurement procedures.
3.26.9.
The Agency is currently managing three dedicated, non-integrated IT systems (SIS II, VIS, and Eurodac), all of which process data on the EU's freedom, security and justice policy area.
This approach could prevent the Agency from achieving economies of scale and synergies between the different systems.
The current changes to extend the Agency's mandate in the coming years to the management of several additional IT systems underpin the increasing urgency of this problem.
The Agency should draw up a detailed cost-benefit analysis in consultation with the Commission and the Member States in order to contribute to a discussion on the future development strategy for the systems.
3.26.10.
The project for the construction of a new building at the site in Stra§burg was considerably lost.
Although the Agency had already paid the full price for the construction work in 2016, the work had still not been completed at the end of 2017 and the progress reports on the work on which the work had been carried out covered only around 70% of the work.
Some of the agency's staff have already taken over the new building, although the work was still ongoing.
The agency and the contractor blame each other for the delays. In December 2017, the contractor made financial demands for the agency and filed a complaint.
The agency is exercising its own legal claim against the contractor (205).
3.26.11.
3.26.12.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/155 3.26.14.
The Agency uses a outsourcing model for the development and implementation of IT projects, in which around 90% of the corresponding work is carried out by contractors.
There are three main framework agreements with three consortia, one for each system.
Payments made to these framework agreements in 2017 amounted to EUR 3 million for Eurodac, EUR 16 million for SIS II and EUR 13 million for VIS.
Although all phases of IT projects, from the definition of requirements and milestones to the commissioning of new system components, are the property of the Agency and are subject to its control, a model in which the development of such sensitive IT systems are outsourced to this extent carries considerable risks in terms of a superior independence from the contractors.
This is all the more true in view of the limited number of potential contractors from operational and security areas that can deal with systems of these areas and these requirements.
3.26.15.
At the same time, the low number of staff in operational key meetings, in particular in the ăReferat for Application Management and Maintenance (AMM), carries a significant risk for the continuity of the operation.
In the second half of 2017, the head of the AMM unit temporarily held the position of head of the operative department and the position of head of the department of operation and infrastructure, thus uniting the three highest management positions in the operative department, which entails further risks for the continuity.
3.26.16.
The framework agreements concluded with the consortia concerned for the operation of the main IT systems include not only the normal maintenance but also the development maintenance work, the price of which cannot be calculated on the basis of the cost estimates attached to the framework agreements.
The prices for the individual units are calculated by the Agency using a combination of a fixed price and an estimate of the time and resources involved, which is aimed at a sound cost control.
For the VIS contract, the agency also relied on the IFPUG (208) method, a standard method based on the function point analysis for determining the prices for developmental abilities.
The agency could also use the IFPUG method for other systems in development.
COMMENTS ON BUDGETARY CURRENCY 3.26.17.
The Agency made global commitments of EUR 69.9 million to cover future expenditures for new tasks and IT systems to be transferred to it in 2017 but for which the legal basis had not yet been adopted by the end of the year (Eurodac recast and allocation system to Dublin) or only shortly before (Regulation on the Entry/Exit System of 30 November 2017).
The corresponding appropriations for payments have been reduced by two amending budgets amounting to EUR 85.6 million, from EUR 153.3 million in the original budget to EUR 85.6 million in the final budget.

The agency besties the high participation of external contractors in IT projects (operational and organisational).
This high outsourcing rate is directly linked to the Commission's Communication COM(2013) 519 on financial and human resources planning for the decentralised agencies for the period 2014-2020.
In the establishment of the Agency in 2012, the establishment plan did not provide sufficient posts for the scope of the tasks entrusted to it.
In addition, the scope of the Agency's tasks was significantly increased from 2013 onwards, but its requests for additional staff were rejected, and the Agency had to reduce its staff, as requested in the Commission's communication (a total of seven posts).
In order to ensure a proper separation of tasks, the contractors involved in the quality assurance do not provide external support services for the operational management of IT-Group systems.
The agency is concerned with this extraordinary situation, in which a staff member had to carry out temporary additional tasks.
The appointment was forced due to the long absence of the head of the operational department and the ongoing recruitment procedure for the further free leadership position.
To remedy this situation, the Agency appointed another employee, the head of the ăSecurity Unit, as the head of the ăOperation and Infrastructure Unit, until the newly recruited leader took up his duties on 1 July 2018.

EN C 434/168 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE AGENCY 3.28.8.
Europol employs over 220 liaison officers from EU Member States and third countries and organisations.
The common working language of Europol is English. Therefore, Europol's internal language arrangements adopted by the Management Board set out that, unless otherwise agreed, recruitment procedures should be carried out in English.
For this reason, Europol's job advertisements are published in English.
Europol has an effective and transparent recruitment process with a 0% vacancy rate at the end of 2017. In the 89 recruitment procedures carried out in 2017, there were an average of 58 candidates per selection process.
For the publication on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO), the translation into the EU official languages is required in addition to the English version.
Due to the high number of job vacancies per year, translation into the EU official languages would entail high costs and the length of the procedures would be longer.
Europol focuses on operational needs in budgetary expenditure, so that job vacancies are translated into all EU official languages, including EPSO, only in certain cases (e.g. the Executive Director or Deputy Executive Directors).

EUROPEAN AGENCY FOR THE FRONTEX INTRODUCTION 3.30.1.
The European Agency for Border and Coast Guard (hereinafter referred to as the Agency), was established by Regulation (EU) 2016/1624 of the European Parliament and of the Council (228) (the new Border and Coast Guard Regulation), repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 2007/2004 (229).
It was developed         was maintained by the abbreviation ăFrontex and the Warsaw headquarters on the basis of the European Agency for Operational Cooperation at the external borders of the Member States.
The new regulation extends the agency's mandate, and the agency's task is to ensure an integrated border management at the external borders at the European level to effectively manage the crossing of external borders.
This includes the fight against migratory pressure and potential future threats at these borders, while at the same time contributing to the fight against serious crime with a cross-border dimension, in order to ensure a high level of internal security within the Union, with full respect for fundamental rights and respect for freedom in this area.

3.30.8.
In 2016, the Court recommended that the Agency identify the most appropriate financing mechanism in an in-depth analysis (233).

3.30.9.
In view of the migration crisis facing the Union, the Agency's mandate was significantly expanded in 2016.
The Agency's budget was increased by 75% in 2016 and the budget for 2017 was again 21% higher than in the previous year.
Personnel increased by 18% in 2016 and by an additional 43% in comparison with the previous year.
The adaptation of the systems and procedures to the new mandate and the new circumstances is still in progress.
The following remarks do not call into question the Court's judgement and are to be read against the background of the challenges the Agency had to tackle.
COMMENTS ON THE RIGHTS AND ORDERS OF THE PROPOSALS 3.30.10.
Following an open call, the Agency received four offers of guidance services for the promotion of migrants within Greece.
After examining the selection criteria, three offers were retained and one was excluded.
The only criterion for the award was the price.
In April 2017, the Agency signed a framework agreement of EUR 2 million for a three-year period with the company that had offered the lowest price.
However, the contractor's funding capacity was limited from time to time and he had problems to complete the contract, so the agency had to complete the contract at the end of 2017.
In order to ensure continuity of services, the Agency signed for the remaining period a new framework agreement of EUR 1.8 million with the second-ranked bidder, who had offered the second lowest price in November 2017.
It did not negotiate the terms of the replacement contract with the tenderers in second and third place, but signed the new contract on the basis of the original tender submitted by the second-placed tenderer.
The direct award of the replacement contract was contrary to the rules, as the original award procedure was completed and a negotiated procedure to agree the terms and conditions of the contract, which was to apply until the conclusion of a new open procedure, did not take place.
No payments were made for this replacement order in 2017.
3.30.11.
The Staff Regulations provide that, in the case of an external selection procedure, temporary staff shall be recruited only in grades SC 1 to SC 2, AST 1 to AST 4 or AD 5 to AD 8 (234).
In 2017, the Agency hired two staff members (2016: 14) in higher AST grades.
(233) Special Report No 12/2016 ăThe use of grants by agencies: not always appropriate or demonstrably effective. (234) Article 53(2) of the Staff Regulations.

3.30.13.
The Agency also co-financed the use of an aircraft used by the Spanish Guardia Civil.
In the absence of evidence for the costs claimed for inspection and maintenance work, the Agency reimbursed 430 000 euros on the basis of average costs per flight hour.
These average costs were calculated on the basis of the cost ceilings used in exchanges between the Spanish authorities and private contractors for inspection and maintenance work.
There is a risk that higher costs have been reimbursed than actually incurred.

COMMENTS ON BUDGETARY CURRENCY 3.30.15.
The Agency again cancelled a large number of committed appropriations carried over from the previous year for the reimbursement of the expenditure of states participating in joint actions, amounting to EUR 7.7 million or 16.5% (2016: EUR 5.6 million or 17.6%).
This shows that the cooperating States had again clearly overestimated the expenses to be reimbursed by the Agency.
Although joint actions had to be cancelled for two consecutive years, the Agency transferred EUR 9.6 million from other budget lines to joint actions in 2017, once again transferring an amount of EUR 40.5 million to the following financial year.
Joint actions represent 69% of the total amount cancelled in 2017 (EUR 11.1 million) and 46% of the total amount transferred in 2018 (EUR 87.6 million).
3.30.16.
In 2017, 66.5 million euros were available for return operations. However, fewer actions were carried out than funds were available.
The Agency therefore paid back to the Commission EUR 13.5 million and EUR 20.3% (2016: EUR 23 million and 37.5%).
In addition, the Agency paid EUR 4 million in the budget in Title I (staff expenditure) back, as not as many new employees could be recruited as planned in 2017.
3.30.17.
The Agency's original budget for 2017 amounted to 8.8 million euros for the required operational financial default for the financing of immediate border security operations and return operations (235).
However, in September and again in October 2017, the Agency transferred 1.9 million euros (in the sum of 3.8 million euros) from the reserve to its operational budget in order to finance other activities.
3.30.18.
After the implementation of transfers from other budget lines and the establishment of an amending budget, the appropriations entered in the reserve amounted to 24.7 million euros and 8.1% of the original budget.
The Agency, however, used the reverse mainly to finance standard operations (8.4 million euros) and to finance a project for remote air surveillance (drones, 7 million euros), for which it had estimated only 1.1 million euros.
The estimation and use of unmandatory complaints is incompatible with the principle of the speciality budget and is incompatible with the transparency of the budget.

C 434/178 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 EN Court observations The Internal Security Fund was established for the period 2014-2020.
It includes two instruments: the instrument for financial support for external borders and visas, and the instrument for financial support for police cooperation, for which EUR 2.8 billion (external borders and visas) and EUR 1 billion (police cooperation) are allocated for the financing of EUR 1 billion.
Under the instrument for financial support for external borders and visas, the Commission shall reimburse the Member States for the cost of equipment such as vehicles or ships, as well as for operating costs such as fuel or maintenance costs.
The Agency shall also reimburse participants in joint actions for such costs.
There is therefore a risk of double financing (4) which is not taken into account.
The costs incurred at border crossings of participating states are determined on the basis of costs incurred, which include ăFix costs (depreciation and maintenance costs), ăvariable expenses (mainly fuel) and ăUse costs (mainly expenses and other expenses for crew members).
The reported costs are based on actual values and correspond to national standards. Consequently, the approaches of the participating states differ, which leads to a particularly complex system for all participants.
In its Special Report No 12/2016, the Court recommended that the agencies make use of simplified cost options whenever this seems appropriate to avoid such inefficiencies (5).
The Agency's previous declaration of approval, which was in force until 5 October 2016, provided for the financing of joint financing operations carried out with participating countries.
However, from January to October 2016, the Agency financed national reverse actions with an amount of EUR 3.6 million.
These payments are illegal.
The Staff Regulations provide that in the case of an external selection procedure, temporary staff shall be recruited only in grades SC 1 to SC 2, AST 1 to AST 4 or AD 5 to AD 8 (6).
In 2016, the Agency hired 14 staff in higher AST grades.
At EUR 6.4 million and 43% (2015: EUR 3.2 million and 38%) for Title II (administrative expenditure) and at EUR 67.3 million and 37% (2015: EUR 40.2 million and 35% respectively) for Title III (operational expenditure), the rate of committed appropriations for the following financial year increased.
The Agency may use separate budget appropriations to better address delays that inevitably arise between legal obligations, mandates and obligations, as well as the corresponding payments.
30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/179 EN Court of Auditors' observations The cancellation rate of the committed appropriations carried over from 2015 was high for Title III (operational expenditure) of EUR 6.4 million and 16% respectively, as the expenditure for 2015 that had yet to be reimbursed to the participating States was overestimated.
The Agency's expanded mandate places a high emphasis on reverse actions; the Agency's budget for 2016 allocated a budget of EUR 63 million for reverse actions.
However, 23 million euros or 37.5% of this amount were paid back to the EU budget, as fewer reverse actions were carried out than planned.
The significant reduction in the procurement procedure for a framework contract of EUR 50 million for the chartering of aircraft and related services for Frontex return operations contributed to this situation and continues to have a negative impact on the number of return operations organised by the Agency.
The launch of this award procedure was scheduled for March 2016 and was still not completed by the end of the year.
On 22 December 2015, the Commission and the Agency, as co-rapporteur and coordinator of three other co-rapporteurs (EASO, IOM and UNHCR) (7), signed a grant agreement of EUR 5.5 million for the regional support of the protection-oriented migration management in the Western Balkans and Turkey, for a period of three years from 1 January 2016.
However, the cooperation agreements with the three partners (legal obligations) of EUR 3.4 million were signed only in the period August to November 2016.
In the case of two of these agreements, the commitments with which the funds must be released, before legal commitments were made, were only made in October and December 2016.
In addition, commitments amounted to EUR 1.2 million, covering only pre-financing payments.
Such action is contrary to the provisions of the Financial Regulation on the management of the budget; moreover, the late signing of the agreements led to uncertainty regarding the operational cooperation between the partners.

The agency regularly stresses difficulties in recruiting employees with the required profiles, which is partly due to the correction coefficients for the employees, which is due to the correction coefficients for the employees, which is 66.7%.
