After Frontex had decided to terminate the contract, it was necessary to ensure the continuity of the services until the selection of a new contractor.
In view of the limited market for the services in the region (the very limited number of economic operators) it was considered that the most appropriate solution was the conclusion of a contract for the acquisition of services in the region with the company that was the second best provider in the original tender for the selection of shipowners.
Therefore, in this case, this is not a continuation of a tendering procedure that has already been concluded.
The agency took into account in its decision that the company had already had experience in providing the services for Frontex and that the relevant reports were very positive and that the services offered met all the minimum technical requirements.
The contractor agreed to provide the services on the same terms as were required and offered in the original tender.
In November 2017, an exemption was signed in which the hindsights for this decision were explained.
The agreement was signed by both parties in December 2017 and entered into force in January 2018.
The application of the price as the sole criterion had been carefully tested and was based on the experience of Frontex in the past two years with the award of the contract for the provision of funds for the acquisition of funds between the Greek islands and Turkey.
Due to the market restrictions in the geographical region  to the very small number of operators with a limited range of routes  to the market, it was not the purpose to establish qualitative award criteria.
The services provided by Frontex were short journeys between the Greek islands and Turkey for the promotion of returnees in the framework of the return agreement concluded between the EU and Turkey, ensuring that these actions were carried out in a safe environment and in full respect of fundamental rights.
In line with the last sentence of Article 31(2) of the Staff Regulations ( In order to take account of the special needs of the institutions, the recruitment of officials can also take account of the labour market situation in the Union.) In the recruitment of officials, Frontex took into account the labour market conditions (= low correction coefficient against the required work experience).
This decision was fully in line with the posts (which form part of the budget) and had never been questioned by the budgetary authorities.
Since March 2017, Frontex has not hired any external applicants in higher grades than grade AST 4.

The costs for inspection/maintenance work are defined as costs for all inspection/maintenance work during the entire service life of the service (...).
The data set is based on the data provided by the manufacturer or the maintenance site of the manufacturer using the device.
This means that the hourly rate can be expressed in the form of a cost statement of the eligible persons, either based on the manufacturer's estimates or on a price calculated on the basis of the actual costs incurred in previous years, or on a cost statement, using reference data for similar means of use, in the case of a new means of use and no data are available.
Invoices (or due to the amount of data of equivalent booking documents) can only be made available if the hourly price is based on the actual costs incurred during the reference year.
However, the person concerned also has the ability to set an hourly rate on the basis of average reference prices, if no invoices were actually issued.
This was the case with the chosen payment, with the Icelandic K, Frontex, presenting an estimate of the cost of maintenance.

The total amount of an hourly rate for all inspection/maintenance work of an aircraft with fixed wings is based on three aircraft with special rules: : maintenance of the engines : The signed contract provided for a maximum amount of EUR 9 010 475.50; the payments are based on the hourly rate for the maintenance of an engine.
The Guardia Civil calculates Frontex the hourly rate for engine maintenance according to the contractual specifications.
If less time is spent on engine maintenance, the overall limit is not reached.
Therefore, in this case, the hourly rate is not the total value of the contract, but the hourly rate.
EN C 434/182 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018  the General maintenance work of the contract is a contract for a total price (not a framework contract) with monthly invoices for the individual work of the contractor.
The Agency assumes that the Guardia Civil will pay the total amount indicated in the contract upon termination of the contract.
The amount of an hourly price is calculated by dividing this total cost by the number of hours of flight.

The Agency assumes that the Guardia Civil will pay the total amount indicated in the contract upon termination of the contract.
From the above-mentioned grounds, the agency cannot join the Court's risk assessment, since, on the basis of a contract on a total price of a contract, the Court's risk assessment, on the basis of which the contract was reimbursed, was ultimately equivalent to those which are reimbursed on the basis of concrete invoices.

COMMENTS ON BUDGETARY CURRENCY 3.30.15.
The main challenge is related to the feasibility of commitments during a given year.
To avoid the risk of high cancellations, Frontex, in the fourth quarter of 2016, asked the employees to submit their requests for final payment for the first half of this year, and to submit their requests for final payment for the first half of this year, and to forward Frontex's requests to the employees for the costs of the current cancellations (December 2016) or for the planned cancellations (January 2017) in the context of the operational activities of 2016.
The main objective of these calls was to identify possible over-implementations, to reduce the corresponding SFD allocations and to re-use the funds in 2016.
Despite some positive results of this action, the transfer of funds was still high.
Consequently, despite a proper assessment of the actual financial needs, Frontex required additional funds to ensure the financial coverage of operations in the autumn of 2016, since the suspended funds of the terminated and ongoing operations were not available at that time.
The Agency has developed a simplified support scheme, which will be implemented from the 2018 operational cycle, which will be used in the case of increases of up to a year to a much higher extent, the Agency not only intensifies the monitoring of the implementation of increases, but also strives to reduce the cancellation of transfers.
The Agency's main objective in the context of the return operations has been achieved in spite of the return of funds to the Commission: to provide Member States with technical and operational support for return operations and to carry out specific measures in the pre-return period (to identify returnees, training/training, exchange of knowledge between Member States, etc.).
In 2017, the number of return actions coordinated by Frontex increased significantly: with an increase of 47% over the previous year, the number of migrants increased from 10,700 in 2016 to 14,200 in 2017.
This represents a share of 10% of the total number of migrants actually returned from the EU to third countries (in 2014 the corresponding figure was 2%).
Recruitment Repayments of staff expenditures were mainly due to the difficulties and the associated delays in recruitment procedures: lengthy procedures, long deadlines, insufficient number of applicants and a lack of geographical balance due to a low correction coefficient.
Nevertheless, the Agency considers it to be a success that, within a year, over 250 new employees have been recruited and recruited.
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/183 3.30.17.
2017 was the first year of the implementation of the new ECC Regulation for the Agency.
Article 75(13) obliges the Agency to include in its budget an operational financial reserve of 4% of the appropriations earmarked for operational measures in order to finance emergency measures for the purposes of border management (RABIT) and return operations.
On 1 October each year, at least one quarter of the year's reduction should remain available, so that needs that occur until the end of the year can be met.
The required operational reserve was introduced so that during the year the agency can at any time provide a certain reserve for the execution of the immediate items for border protection purposes and for the coverage of the possible costs of such an emergency operation.
The European Parliament had amended the original text of the ECC Regulation proposed by the Commission by adding that by 1 October only a quarter of the European Parliament's budget had to remain available for the remaining three months of the year.
The ECC regulation is silent on what is to be done with the remaining three-quarters of the deficit after 1 October; this point is unclear.
The first transfer at the end of September was intended for the financing of strengthened operational measures in the air and at sea and the purchase of own air monitoring services; the second transfer took place after 1 October.
The Board of Directors was informed in the monthly report on transfers.
The Agency considers that the legislator should provide clarity.
The unmandatory situation had already been envisaged during the preparations for the Single Programming Document (SPD) 2017-2019.
In accordance with Article 75(3ff) of the ECC Regulation, the preparation of the SPD and the estimate of revenue and expenditure was started in N-2 and completed in the late autumn of N-1.
The ECC Regulation entered into force in October 2016.
The Agency had to plan the detailed annual work programme 2017 (as part of the SPD 2017-2019) for the whole year 2016 without the final result of the deliberations on the ECC Regulation and thus without a clearly defined legal basis.
Towards the end of 2016, the SPD 2017-2019 was already completed and was available for approval to the Board of Directors, which fully supported the creation of the non-restricted situation in view of the transition to the European Border and Coast Guard.
The Commission stated in its opinion on the SPD 2017-2019, (C92016)8722, in paragraph 63: ăThe Commission stated that emergency planning has become a guiding principle for the preparation of the annual work programme and that the Agency intends to provide almost 10% of its operational budget for the so-called ‘operational flexibilit'tÔ (...).
In this context, the Commission calls on the Agency to set up two separate actions within its budget, the first fully in line with Article 75, paragraph 13, of the ECC Regulation, and the second to enable the Agency to maintain the operational flexibility in order to deal with emergency situations that are not immediate.

C 434/186 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 EN ANNEX Follow-up to the Court's observations in previous years In 2016, an external evaluation of the Foundation was carried out on behalf of the Commission.
This was the first step in the cross-cutting evaluation of the four agencies in the field of employment, social affairs and integration(1).
The evaluators concluded that the significant restructuring of the Foundation has not had a significant negative impact since 2011 and that the internal and external stakeholders had the most positive impact, in particular in terms of strategy and effectiveness.
The management structure of the Foundation was considered efficient and effective.
The evaluation also stresses that the Foundation has further improved its surveillance capacity since 2011, but that it has to present its capabilities and achievements even more clearly.
Harmonisation and simplification of indicators within a single intervention logic and the use of a common terminology throughout the Foundation would help to improve.
The Foundation drew up a plan to implement the recommendations of the evaluators.

EURATOM SUPPLY AGENCY INTRODUCTION 3.32.1.
The Euratom Supply Agency (hereinafter ‘the Agency') based in Luxembourg was established in 1958(244).
Council Decision 2008/114/EC, Euratom(245) replaced the previously applicable Statute of the Agency.
The Agency's main task is to ensure regular supply of nuclear materials to EU users, in particular nuclear fuels, in accordance with the principle of equal access to supply sources through a common supply policy.
3.32.2.

In 2017, procedures for awarding and awarding grants were not adequately documented.
In the procurement of services by means of low and medium value contracts, there were inconsistencies in the published procurement documents, there were no records to explain the pre-selection of candidates in low value contracts, and no evaluation reports were produced by the Office for the procurement procedures for the recruitment of temporary contracts.

Payments Jurisdiction of the legality and regularity of the payments underlying the annual accounts 3.34.6.
3.34.7.
In 2017, the Office cancelled EUR 3.2 million and 15.9% of the committed appropriations carried over from the financial year 2016.
The Office continued to use fixed prices for services (258).
The prices used in the individual service contracts are based on unit prices (price/persons' day, etc.) set out in the framework agreements and the number of units used for the service in question.
The Office shall ensure that unit prices are correctly applied in order to ensure that the prices offered by the contractors are the same.
3.34.10.
However, the list of services to be provided in connection with the framework agreement was not exhaustive in the case of a framework agreement with a value of EUR 80 million on general consultancy, consultancy and project management services, as well as studies.
In order to evaluate the offers, the service descriptions contained two business cases relating to the management of a project and a multi-project programme.
This framework agreement is a multi-frame agreement, partly a cascade procedure (general advisory and project management services) and partly a renewed call for competition (praction and studies).
The protected units were pre-defined by the Office, but the bidders were asked to determine the distribution between the different profiles.
The framework agreement and also some of the associated individual agreements were therefore advertised on the basis of unit prices, types of profiles and quality, but not on the basis of the estimated number of units, which is another essential element in the calculation of a fixed price agreement.
3.34.11.
A single contract with a fixed price of EUR 145 447.50 was awarded to this framework agreement, which mainly concerns the provision of support services for the execution of a document management project.
The necessary staff days for the provision of these services cannot be derived either from the business cases described in the service descriptions or from the description contained in the individual contract.
Therefore, in the case of a fixed price as defined in this individual contract, there is a risk that the services will not be provided in the most economic way.
3.34.12.
If not all the conditions for the provision of services for the award of the framework agreement can be laid down, the individual contracts are more appropriate for the reopening of competition among several contractors of the framework agreement.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/197 EN Year 2016 State of correction (completed/in progress/outgoing/n.e.) Completed (3) ANNEX Follow-up of observations from previous years Court observations The Office's budget implementation rate was low at 89%, suggesting an inaccurate estimate of its expenditure in the 2016 budget.
As a result of the most recent changes to the Foundation Regulation and the Office's financial regulations, it has become more important that, if necessary, the Office, by means of an amending budget, should draw up a detailed budget, since the budget's budget's budget means that the mechanisms, such as the allocation of resources to an Actions Fund(1) and a corresponding compensation mechanism (2), are now to be applied.
In 2014, the Office launched an invitation to tender for a four-year framework agreement covering an estimated market volume of EUR 30 million for the procurement of advisory services covering a wide range of activities, including services, project management, general advisory services and studies.
However, the procurement procedure and the subsequent use of the framework agreement were partly not adequately managed.
The objectives and the activities to be carried out had not been set precisely enough to make a precise assessment of the volume of the framework agreement.
Therefore, the resources of the framework agreement were exhausted after only two years and six months.
In addition, despite the diversity of the services to be procured and the very different expenses of each activity, no lots had been used.
The use of lots would encourage smaller companies to participate in the low-value process.
Finally, the price competition was neutralised and the contract was granted by the contractor, since fixed price offers were requested by a single contractor using the framework contract.
The Office should decide to enter into agreements with several suppliers and, if necessary, to call again for competition.
The Office's Office's declaration states that the translations required for the Office's work are made by the Translation Centre for the Institutions of the European Union (CdT), which leads to the fact that the Office is the Centre's principal client.
The Office is increasingly resorting to internal solutions such as linguistic and translation memory as well as additional software.
These instruments are designed to improve the cost-effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of the Office.
However, from the perspective of the European Union, the current situation could lead to a doubling of expenditure and the corresponding costs.

While the cancellation rate is just over 15%, the amount of the cancelled committed transfers is the lowest of the last ten years (since 2008) at EUR 3.2 million.
The Office will continue to work with the national authorities to reduce the cancelled transfers with the help of interim reports on the implementation and half-yearly inspections with reinforced control measures, which form an integral part of each new cooperation agreement.
Further measures were also implemented internally, such as awareness-raising measures through coaching, training, information notes and meetings with financial actors.
In addition, the Office expected that the level of cancelled transfers would exceed 15% before the end of 2017 and proactively took additional measures to reduce transfers for the next year.
The Office took note of the Court's observations.
It should be noted in advance that the scenarios described in the procurement documents for the future use of the contract were aimed at being as vivid and representative as possible and were not expected of them in detail with each specific contract.
As regards the adequacy of the re-opening of the competition mechanisms and as stated in the Office's response to the 2016 audit, this concept has already been introduced in the audit and studies framework agreement.
The Office has compared the added value of this mechanism with the related administrative costs and, given the Office's intensive use of advisory and project management services, has concluded that this cannot be considered the most efficient way of managing the latter types of services.
Taking into account the fact that the current framework agreement is valid until 2020, the extension of this mechanism to the advisory and project management services would require a new tender at that time, which the Office does not consider appropriate.
In the existing cascade system for consulting and project management services, the Office repeats the answer to the 2016 audit for the use of the fixed price procedures.
The main reason for choosing this option is that proceedings against the Office before the Spanish Labour Courts are relevant in relation to a non-right-by-right transfer of employees, which are inter alia related to the use of the earlier ăTime and Means.
In the case of the fixed price procedure (within the cascade system), the Office has experience in the evaluation of tenders.
The EUIPO has set up a specific team, which, on the basis of previous practice and expertise, is able to set up the resources needed to carry out the tasks behind the fixed-price performance.
However, we believe that the Court's concerns can be addressed by other contractual methods than the ăfixed prize, such as the ăQuoted Time and Means, a method that the Office could, in the future, draw in a single case.
The Office undertakes to provide further information and to document its own estimates of resources required to carry out the tasks of fixed price services before issuing the request for information to provide proof of the above-mentioned experience of the Office in advance.

Emphasis on a situation 3.35.9.
Without questioning its rulings in paragraphs 3.35.6-3.35.8, the Court would like to stress that the contributions to the Fund are calculated on the basis of the information sent to the Committee by credit institutions (and some investment firms).
The Court relied on this information when examining the Committee's revenue, but this information was not relied on by the Court's powers.
The SRM Regulation does not provide for a comprehensive and uniform control framework which ensures the reliability of the information.
Furthermore, the Committee cannot disclose details of the contributions per credit institution, calculated on the basis of a risk assessment, as the calculations are not available and include confidential information on other credit institutions.

EN C 434/204 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE COMMITTEE 3.35.9.
The annual contributions to the Fund collected in advance shall be calculated on the basis of the information provided to the Committee by credit institutions and certain investment firms.
Although the SRM Regulation does not provide for a comprehensive and uniform control framework that ensures the reliability of this information, the SRF pays any attention to this aspect.
The data provided are provided on the basis of the data transmitted by the institutions in the previous year and the data contained in the ECB database.
Deviations are reported to the national resolution authorities, who are asked to clarify the facts. Thus, it was possible for the SRF to improve the quality of the data in the previous cycles.
Furthermore, the Committee cannot provide details of pre-investigations per institution, calculated on the basis of a risk assessment, since the calculations are not available and therefore confidential information on other institutions would be disclosed.
However, the SRF has disclosed the calculation method and detailed calibrations to ensure transparency and cooperation.
3.35.12.
In 2017, the financial team's capacity was insufficient to ensure the efficient handling of all financial transactions, including bills, due to a combination of unexpectedly high workloads, a regrettable staff turnover in the financial team, and general difficulties in finding experienced staff.
Since the fourth quarter of 2017, the team's capacity has been strengthened and measures have been taken to ensure the timely processing of invoices.
By this date, nearly 98 % of the invoices were settled within the deadlines set in 2018.
Every case of late payment is now being closely examined in order to achieve further improvements in this area.
3.35.14.
The SRB's 2017 procurement plan was adopted in 2016, when the Committee was only in its second full year of existence.
At that time, no resolution cases had been dealt with and the Agency had little experience on the basis of which its procurement plan could be drawn up.
As a new agency, the SRB was able to use various interinstitutional frameworks managed by the European Commission.
This led to the fact that several procurement procedures to be initiated by the SRB in 2017 were ultimately not implemented.
In 2018, the implementation of the procurement plan will be closely monitored and additional efforts will be made to improve the planning of procurement procedures.
In 2017, the SRB spent a total of EUR 20 million on the provision of legal advice.
Almost all negotiated procedures without prior publication of a contract notice concerned litigation (eight out of ten out of a total of EUR 10.9 million) which did not fall within the scope of Directive 2014/24/EU.
This also includes a large number of disputes brought before the ECJ after the first resolution procedure of the SRB.
The SRB does not therefore consider that it uses such methods in aberm such a way.
As regards the economic and financial valuation of two of the two cases in 2017, the re-implementation of a competition proved to be unsuccessful. Therefore, the SRB was forced to resort to negotiating procedures.
Due to the subject matter of the contract and the need for the highest degree of confidentiality, the contract notice was not published in accordance with the applicable rules.
3.35.16.
Online access to tender documents has been available to economic operators since the Committee was established on the SRB website and has been fully integrated into the electronic tender platform since the end of 2017.
In June 2017, the SRB requested that it be able to use the electronic submission of offers, but the Commission has not yet gained access.
The SRB has found that such publications on the EPSO website are neither the quality nor the number of applications and are also very expensive due to the mandatory translation of the job advertisements.
Therefore, the SRB publishes its job advertisements preferably on its own website as well as on EU_CV online and LinkedIn and informs its stakeholders (central banks, finance ministries, national authorities, other EU agencies and permanent representations).

Note 3.36.7.
The Centre's task is to provide the EU's agencies and agencies with translation services which they provide for the functioning of their services, which is also carried out by the EU institutions which can use the Centre's services.
The establishment regulations of most agencies and agencies provide for them to use the Centre's translation services.
Some agencies and institutions (which more than half of the Centre's revenue is generated) are increasingly resorting to in-house opportunities or other alternatives to the in-house.
This means, however, that the capacity of the Centre is not used to the maximum, that there is a duplication in the development of systems and the running costs at the European level, and that the business model and the business development of the Centre could be carried out.
In 2017, an external assessment of the adequacy of the Centre's business model was carried out.
The final evaluation report had not yet been adopted at the time of the Court's examination (268).

EN C 434/212 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE AGENCY 3.37.8. The Agency considers that its accountant has a high degree of independence.
In addition to the appointment by the Steering Committee and the function-related injunction to the Committee, it should be noted that the invoicing officer of the EACEA, as a seconded higher-ranking Commission official, is, per se, considerably less independent than the invoicing officer in the field.

The Agency will analyse the Court's comment and take into account the potential actions of other EU agencies and/or Commission organisational guidelines.

COMMENTS ON THE RELIABILITY OF THE CURRENCY 3.38.8.
In the course of this year's examination of the EU agencies, the Court analysed the accounting system, including the hierarchical position and the independence of the accountants, as well as the aspect of the timely (re)validation of the accounting systems.
The head of the agency's accountant is the head of the financial department.
The Court therefore considers it necessary to strengthen the independence of the accountant by directing it to the Director (administrative concerns) and to the Agency's Steering Committee (functional concerns).
3.38.9.
In addition, the Agency's mandate was significantly expanded in 2014: it is now managing EU actions in various areas in cooperation with seven Commission Directorates-General.
Despite significant changes in the Agency's procedures and a significant increase in its budget and staff, a revalidation of the accounting system took place most recently in 2012.
In accordance with the Financial Regulation, the executive agencies should establish a uniform format for the electronic storage and exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (282). As a requirement also applies for the EU institutions and agencies, the Commission is currently developing a comprehensive IT format covering all stages of public procurement procedures. It has launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), the electronic publication of documents for contract notices in the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and the electronic submission of tenders (2015).
REPORTS OF THE INTERNAL AUDIT SERVICES 3.38.11.
In 2017, the Commission's Internal Audit Service presented the Agency's audit reports on the management of COSME (the programme for the competitiveness of enterprises and small and medium-sized enterprises) and the management procedures of the Agency's Human Resources Department(283).
The Agency has drawn up action plans to take action in areas where there is a potential need for improvement.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/215 EN ANNEX Follow-up to comments from previous years Court observations The rate of committed appropriations for the following financial year was high for both Title II (administrative expenditure) of EUR 1 250 000 and 33% (2015: EUR 998 324 and 14% respectively) and Title III (support to the operational activities of the Agency) of EUR 2 550 000 and 62% (2015: EUR 4 million and 65% respectively).
Under Title II, the transfers were mainly related to rent (0.6 million euros) and the purchase of hardware, which had not yet been delivered at the end of the year (0.5 million euros).
The appropriations for Title III concerned the evaluation and monitoring of the LIFE programme by external experts (EUR 1.5 million), ongoing ex-post inspections (EUR 0.5 million) and IT services (EUR 0.5 million), which were commissioned in 2016 but were only partially delivered at the end of the year and were not yet invoiced.
The Agency may use separate budget resources to better accommodate the multi-annual nature of the activities and the inevitable delays between the signing of contracts, deliveries and payments.
The high cancellation rate of the appropriations of the previous year of Title I (personnel expenditure) of EUR 32000 and 8.3% respectively shows that the appropriations needed have been overestimated.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/227 EN ANNEX Follow-up of observations from previous years observations of the Court In its December 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) concluded that the Agency's overall staff management is appropriate.

On behalf of the Commission, the performance of the Agency was subject to an external evaluation in the period 2012-2015, for which the final report was submitted in May 2016.
The conclusion of the evaluation is that the Agency has carried out its tasks in the period considered in an effective, efficient and cost-effective manner, that its mission for the Commission and the staff of the Agency is still relevant for the first time and that the transfer of operational tasks from the Commission to the Agency has been successful.
However, the evaluation experts also made it possible for the activities to be made even more effective and effective, and the Agency and the Commission were invited to improve their internal dialogue and cooperation, communication, and certain aspects of IT and human resources management.
The Agency and the Commission agreed on a plan for corrective action.
EN C 434/228 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE AGENCY 3.41.9
The introduction of the audited recruitment procedure, which identified weaknesses, took place in 2016. A reserve list was then drawn up and adopted in 2016, which was used in 2017 to provide a job offer.
The selection process of REA for contract staff was revised and implemented later in 2017, taking into account the recommendation of the IAS of 2016.
The revised selection process for contract staff considers the demands for clearly documented search criteria for life life and fitness and for admission and selection criteria.
The search criteria used by the selection bodies for the search for life documents are documented in their minutes.
Thus, the weaknesses raised by the Court in the amended procedure have already been resolved.
In the field of procurement, the REA relies on service agreements with the Commission or on the Commission's framework contracts.
REA would only initiate a special procurement procedure if there is a special need which is not covered by these agreements or contracts.
In 2017, REA only carried out a procurement procedure for a low-value contract.
The current tools for electronic tendering and electronic submission of tenders are only applicable for public procurement procedures of the size of which is above the threshold of 144,000 euros. As the REA has not yet launched a procurement procedure the size of which is above this threshold, it has not been able to use the tools for electronic tendering and the electronic submission of tenders in 2017.
Furthermore, the introduction of the electronic tender and the electronic submission of tenders in accordance with the Commission's roadmap for all EU institutions and agencies will be mandatory at the end of 2018, and the implementation process did not begin until 2018.
The Agency is already using electronic invoicing and will also use the modules for the electronic tendering and the electronic submission of tenders when launching a tendering procedure, as soon as these modules also cover medium and low-value modules.

Emphasis on a situation 3.42.7.

The Agency's budgeting has been weak. In the case of Title III of the budget, large amounts of committed appropriations of EUR 1.6 million or 63% (2016: EUR 1.2 million or 48%) were transferred from 2017 to 2018 respectively.

EN 10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/7 GENERAL INTRODUCTION 0.1.
The European Court of Auditors is the institution responsible for the audit of the European Union's (EU) finances under the Treaty.
As an external auditor of the EU, we contribute to improving EU financial management while acting as independent guardians of the financial interests of EU citizens.
More detailed information on our work can be found in the Annual Activity Report, which is available on our website www.eca.europa.eu, as well as the special reports on the EU's expenditure programmes and revenue, as well as the opinions on new or amended legislation.
This is our 38th annual report on the implementation of the EU budget, covering the financial year 2014.
The annual report on the European Development Funds shall be presented separately.
0.3.
The EU's general budget is adopted annually by the Council and the European Parliament.
Our annual report, together with the special reports, forms the basis for the discharge procedure, during which the European Parliament, following a Council recommendation, decides whether the Commission has carried out its discharge tasks satisfactorily.
At the same time as we send the report to the European Parliament and the Council, we send our annual report to the national parliaments.
0.4.
The main element of our annual report is the statement of reliability of the consolidated annual accounts of the European Union and the legality and regularity of the transactions (hereinafter referred to as the regularity of the transactions).
We complement this Statement of Assurance with specific assessments of all major EU activities.
0.5.
The chapter structure now reflects the headings of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), which makes our report even more relevant.
The financial framework entered into force in 2014 and is intended to determine the extent and distribution of EU expenditure in the period to 2020.
This should make it easier for readers to link the findings of our report to the relevant budgetary and accounting information.
0.6.
There are no separate annual accounts for each MFF heading and therefore the conclusions presented in the context of specific assessments do not form an audit opinion.
0.7.
This year's report is structured as follows: — Chapter 1 contains the Statement of Assurance and a summary of the results of our audit on the reliability of the accounts and the regularity of the transactions. — Chapter 2 presents our findings on budgetary and financial management. — Chapter 3 contributes to our strategic objective of improving the EU's public accountability. The focus is on the extent to which the performance framework enables the Commission to monitor and manage progress towards Europe 2020. — Chapter 4 contains our findings on revenue. — Chapters 5 to 9 (on the MFF headings 1a, 1b, 2, 4 and 5)(1) contains the results of our audits on the regularity of transactions, as well as the audit of selected systems and annual activity reports.
0.8.
The Commission's replies (or, where appropriate, the replies of other EU institutions and bodies) to our comments are contained in the report, and our findings and conclusions are taken into account in the replies of the audited body.
However, as an external auditor, it is our sole responsibility to present our audit findings, to draw conclusions from these findings, and to carry out an independent and impartial assessment of the reliability of the accounts and the regularity of the transactions.
(1) We do not provide specific assessments of the expenditures of the MFF Headings 3 (security and citizenship) and 6 (compensation payments).

DE C 373/10 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 DE C 373/10 RELIABILITY DECLARATION OF THE HOFES — REMARK OF THE INDEPENDENT DEPARTMENT I. We have (a) the consolidated annual accounts of the European Union, the consolidated annual accounts(1) and the aggregated accounts of the implementation of the budget (2) for the financial year ending 31 December 2014 and approved by the Commission on 23 July 2015, and (b) the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying the accounts, as referred to in Article 287 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU).
Management II's responsibility. In accordance with Articles 317 and 318 TFEU and the Financial Regulation, the Commission is responsible for the establishment and proper presentation of the consolidated annual accounts of the European Union on the basis of internationally recognised public sector accounting principles and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
This responsibility shall include the design, establishment and maintenance of internal control structures necessary for the preparation and presentation of financial statements which are free from material misrepresentations, intended or unintended.
The Commission bears the ultimate responsibility for the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying the accounts of the European Union (Article 317 TFEU).
The responsibility of the auditor III. Our task is to provide the European Parliament and the Council, on the basis of our examination, with a statement of the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying them.
We have conducted our audit in accordance with the International Standards on Auditing as well as the professional conduct requirements of IFAC and the International Standards for Supreme Audit Institutions of INTOSAI.
According to these standards, we have to comply with professional conduct requirements and to plan and conduct the audit in such a way that sufficient certainty is obtained as to whether the consolidated annual accounts of the European Union are free of material misrepresentations and the underlying transactions are lawful and proper.
IV. An audit shall consist of the carrying out of audit acts in order to obtain audit evidence of the valuations and other information contained in the consolidated annual accounts and of the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
The selection of audit acts shall be at the discretion of the auditor, including the assessment of the risks of material, intentional or unintended, misrepresentation in the consolidated annual accounts, as well as material, intentional or unintended, infringements of European Union legislation in the underlying transactions.
In assessing these risks, the auditor shall take into account all internal controls relevant to the establishment and proper presentation of the consolidated accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions in order to plan audit actions that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not in order to give an audit opinion on the effectiveness of the internal control system.
An audit shall also include an assessment of the adequacy of the accounting methods used, the representativeness of the estimated values in the accounting and the overall presentation of the consolidated annual accounts.
V. In the field of revenue, we use the macroeconomic aggregates relevant for their calculation as the starting point for our examination of own resources based on VAT and on gross national income, and we assess the Commission's systems for the processing of these data until the Member States' contributions are received and until they are identified in the consolidated annual accounts.
In the area of traditional own resources, we examine the accounts of the customs authorities and analyse the tax flows until they are received by the Commission and until the amounts are recorded in the accounts.
1. The consolidated financial statements shall include the balance sheet, the profit and loss account, the cash flow account, the changes in net assets, and a summary of key accounting rules and other explanatory notes (including segment reporting).
DE 10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/11 VI. In the area of expenditure, we will review the payment transactions after the expenditure has been incurred, recorded and accepted, and will review all types of payments, except advances, (including payments for the acquisition of assets) only after they have been made.
Advance payments shall be examined if the beneficiary provides or has to provide proof of their proper use and if the advance is or can be recovered.
VII. We believe that the audit evidence obtained is sufficient and appropriate to serve as the basis for our audit opinions.
The audit opinion on the reliability of the accounts VIII. In our opinion, the consolidated annual accounts of the European Union for the year ending on 31 December 2014 shall, for the year ending 31 December 2014, be the Union's financial and financial position as at 31 December 2014, the results of its operations and its cash flows and the changes in net assets for the financial year ending on that date in accordance with the Financial Regulation and the accounting rules for the public sector, based on internationally recognised accounting principles, in all essential respects as a whole. The legality and regularity of the transactions underlying the accounts Revenues Payments The audit opinion on the legality and regularity of the revenue underlying the annual accounts IX. The annual accounts for the financial year ending on 31 December 2014 are, in all essential respects, lawful and regular.
The basis for the failure to assess the legality and regularity of the payments underlying the annual accounts X. The expenditure booked in 2014 to the detriment of headings 1 to 4 of the multiannual financial framework (3), which cover operational appropriations, is substantially affected by errors.
Our estimated error rate for payments underlying the annual accounts is 4.4%.
Our conclusion is underpinned by the analysis of the risk levels presented by the Commission in the synthesis report.
Failure to give an opinion on the legality and regularity of the payments underlying the annual accounts XI. According to our assessment, the payments underlying the annual accounts for the financial year ending on 31 December 2014 are substantially affected by errors due to the importance of the facts described in the paragraph "Base for the failure to give an opinion on the legality and regularity of the payments underlying the annual accounts".
3. These headings shall be dealt with in Chapters 5 to 8 of this Annual Report.

10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/13 DE OBSERVATIONS OF THE COURT INTRODUCTION EU expenditure is an important instrument for achieving policy objectives 1.1.
EU expenditure is an important tool for achieving policy objectives.
Other important instruments include legislation, the free movement of goods, services and capital and the free movement of persons throughout the Union.
EU expenditure is on average 1.9% of total expenditure of the general government of the EU Member States (see Figure 1.1).
According to the Treaty, our role is, among other things, to assess whether the use of the EU budget is in line with the relevant laws and other legislation; — to give our opinion on the EU's annual accounts; — to report on the economy, efficiency and effectiveness (4) of EU expenditure; — to submit opinions on legislative proposals with financial implications.
With our audit work to support the Statement of Assurance, we are fulfilling the first and second of these objectives.
This audit work allows us to identify risks that affect economy, efficiency and effectiveness.
It also provides an important input to the opinions we give on proposed financial rules.
(4) In Article 30(2) of Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2012 on the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the Union (OJ L 302, 30.11.2012, p.
1), these terms are defined as follows: ‘The principle of economy requires that the resources used by the institution concerned in its [sic] activities are made available at the right time, in sufficient quantity and appropriate quality and at the lowest possible cost.
The principle of economic efficiency concerns the optimal relationship between the resources used and the results achieved.
The principle of effectiveness concerns the achievement of certain objectives and the desired results.

C 373/16 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 REPLY OF THE COMMISSION 1.7.
In 2014, the Commission amended the presentation of the annual accounts several times.
These amendments are intended to take account of the new Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and to further align it with international standards.
Considerable improvements have been made in the presentation of certain explanatory notes to the financial statements (8).
Points affecting the annual accounts 1.8.
The following points have an impact on the annual accounts: 1.8. a) The Commission has made progress on the presentation of a) Explanatory note 6 on the annual accounts (on the protection of the EU budget), as discussed in point 1.13 of our annual report on the financial year 2013 and in point 2 of this year's follow-up report (Annex 1.2).
The explanation now contains more targeted information.
In the area of cohesion, it shows the extent to which corrections are made before expenditure is recorded, during implementation and at the end of the year.
Furthermore, the explanation now includes, although not always in quantified form, a description of the impact of corrective measures (such as the creation of assigned revenue, expenditure withdrawn and replaced by Member States, etc.) on the EU budget (9). (b) The explanation 2.5.2 on pre-financing (proposals to Member States) shows that the Commission has limited information on the use of the resources available for financial instruments under shared management (EUR 3.8 billion) and other aid schemes (EUR 3.6 billion).
The Commission may need to make significant adjustments at the end of the 2007-2013 programming period.
(8) Including a consolidated presentation of short-term and long-term assets and liabilities and a simplified presentation of segment reporting.
(9) In its explanatory note 6 to the 2015 financial statements, the Commission seeks to take account of the decisions of the Court of Justice of the European Union of June 2015, which annulled decisions on financial corrections amounting to EUR 457 million.
In the explanatory note 2.10, ‘Reserves', these decisions are already treated as adjustments due to events after the closing date (judgment of the Court of Justice of 24 June 2015 in Joined Cases C-549/12 P and C-54/13 P annulment of two Commission decisions of EUR 94 million in connection with ERDF programmes in Germany and judgment in Case C-263/13 P annulment of three Commission decisions of EUR 363 million in respect of ERDF programmes in Spain).

REPLY OF THE COMMISSION 1.11.
The Commission notes that the error rate reported by the Court is an annual estimate that takes account of the accounting corrections of project expenditure made before the Court's audit is announced.
The Commission notes that it is bound by the Financial Regulation, which lays down in Article 32(2)(e) that its internal control system, inter alia, should ensure that the risks associated with the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions are adequately addressed, taking into account the multi-annual nature of the programmes and the nature of the payments concerned.
In the 2014 Synthesis Report (COM(2015) 279 final), the Commission estimated the future impact of correction mechanisms to be EUR 2.7 billion, corresponding to 1.9% of payments from the EU budget.
The Commission will continue to exercise its monitoring role by making financial corrections and recoveries at a level consistent with the level of irregularities and deficiencies identified throughout the period and also after the closure of the programmes.

COMMENTS FROM THE COURT 1.12.
EU expenditure consists predominantly of two types of expenditure programmes with very different risk patterns (12): — programmes based on payment entitlements, where payment depends on whether certain conditions are met; such programmes include scholarships for students and research scholarships (Chapter 5), direct aid for farmers (Chapter 7), direct budget support(13) (Chapter 8) and salaries and pensions (Chapter 9); — reimbursement schemes where the EU reimburses eligible costs for eligible activities, such schemes cover research projects (Chapter 5), schemes for investment in regional and rural development (Chapters 6 and 7), training programmes (Chapter 6) and development projects (Chapter 8).
(12) These different risks are dealt with in more detail in points 1.20-1.22.
(13) Budget support payments are a contribution to the general budget of a State or to the budget allocated by the State to a specific policy or objective (see also paragraphs 8.7 and 8.8).
THE COMMENTS FROM THE COURT A new audit approach...
For 2014, we have redesigned our approach to quantify serious breaches of procurement rules.
This approach clarifies how we assess the impact of these infringements.
In particular, we have introduced a proportional approach to the calculation of errors related to the modification of contracts.
1.14.
In order to ensure comparability of the results presented in this report, we have adjusted the figures for 2012 and 2013 in Table 1.1 and in Figures 1.2, 1.3, 1.4, 1.5 and 1.6 in accordance with this new approach.
Annex 1.4 contains the unadjusted historical data on the estimated error rates for the period 2009-2013.
This adjustment reduced the estimated overall error rate by 0.2% in 2013 and by 0.3% in 2012.
The adjustment does not affect the conclusions we reached in relation to those years, and it remains a clearly significant error rate.
1.15.
In 2015, we will adapt our approach to cross compliance to the revised regulatory framework for the common agricultural policy.
While we will continue to report on the information provided by the Commission on cross-compliance, this element will no longer be the subject of our audit proceedings.
This year we found numerous cross compliance errors with regard to one in four of the farms visited.
The share of these errors in our estimated total error rate is 0.2 percentage points (2013: 0.2)(14) and the error rate for the chapter ‘Natural resources' is 0.6 percentage points (2013: 0.5).
The Commission welcomes the change in the Court's approach from 2015.
For 2014, it reiterates its view that cross compliance infringements do not affect the conditions for aid for payments (see the Commission's reply to point 7.7).

C 373/24 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 REPLY OF THE COMMISSION OF THE COMMENTS OF THE HOFES Type of expenditure and error rates are closely related to 1.20.
We have analysed the relationship between the type of expenditure and the risk of error.
EU expenditure is characterised by the extent to which the correct calculation of payments to beneficiaries depends on information provided by the beneficiaries themselves.
This applies to the largest category of expenditure schemes based on payment entitlements: the area-related aid paid to farmers.
This is of particular importance in the area of reimbursement schemes: the beneficiaries must indicate in their application in order to demonstrate that they are participating in an eligible measure and that they have incurred costs that are eligible for reimbursement.
All types of management are affected (15).

The cash flows are grouped according to their nature.
The size of the circles in this figure represents the respective share of total expenditure, with their respective positioning along the 45-degree line indicating the respective estimated error rate, their colour indicating whether they are claims-based or reimbursement-based expenditures.
1.22.
This figure includes both elements of mandatory discretion (assessment of the impact of systems and risks related to the type of operation — see Annex 1.1, point 1) and empirical elements (measurement of estimated error rates over a two-year period).
On the one hand, the aim is to meet the wishes of our target group for more information on the different risk profiles, on the other hand, to assist the Commission in taking action on areas with persistently high error rates.
1.20.
The integrated management and control system (InVeKoS), which includes the Land Parcel Identification System (LPIS), contributes significantly to the prevention of errors and to the reduction of the error rate (see point 7.32).
LPIS is established and maintained by the national authorities.
Payments to final beneficiaries are only possible after the data in the area identification system have been compared to the data in the area identification system.
LPIS means that the error rate for area-related aid is lower than for all other types of aid under shared management.

C 373/26 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 REPLY OF THE COMMISSION DE COMMENTS FROM THE HOFES The results in the various areas of expenditure show different error patterns 1.23. "Competitiveness" (Chapter 5): The estimated error rate is 5.6% and is thus higher than the corresponding results for 2013 (4.0%(17). The majority of expenditure is based on cost reimbursement and the errors in this area mainly reflect the different categories of ineligible costs (especially personnel costs, other direct costs and indirect costs).
1.24. ‘Cohesion' (Chapter 6: The estimated error rate is 5.7%, higher than the corresponding results for 2013 (5.3% (17)).
Almost all expenditure in this area is in the form of reimbursement.
The main causes of error include serious infringements of procurement rules (around half of the estimated error rate), followed by ineligible costs in declarations of expenditure (more than a quarter of the estimated error rate).
Infringements of the State aid rules and ineligible projects constitute the remaining part of the errors.
1.25. ‘Natural resources' (Chapter 7): The estimated error rate is 3.6%, lower than the corresponding results for 2013 (4.4 % (17).
The European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF) accounts for more than three quarters of expenditure in this area, and this Fund is less prone to error than the rural development sub-sector, for which we have long observed high error rates, in particular for expenditure on the basis of reimbursement.
Overall, farmers' excessive area or number of animals contributed about one third of the estimated error rate.
Errors related to non-eligible beneficiaries, activities or expenditure accounted for the second highest proportion (around a quarter of the estimated error rate).
The main remaining shares are cross compliance infringements (one-sixth) and administrative errors (one-sixth).

C 373/28 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 REPLY OF THE COMMISSION DE REMARKS OF THE HOFES Box 1.1 — Example of errors in the reimbursement of costs of a project under the MFF heading 3 "Security and citizenship of the Union" The subject of our sample was a payment of the Commission to a beneficiary, who was the coordinator of a cooperation project under the "Fundamental Rights and Citizenship of the Union" programme.
The beneficiary public body assigned two permanent staff (officials) half-days to the project and charged part of its salaries in the project cost statement.
The costs of the staff of the Member of the European Parliament shall be borne by the Member of Parliament only where the staff of the Member of the European Parliament have to be recruited in order to replace the officials in their usual duties and where the costs are actually incurred by the staff of the Member of the European Parliament.
As the beneficiary institution has not made provision for the replacement of officials, these costs are not eligible.
Overall, the ineligible costs reported by the beneficiary entity amounted to EUR 58 000 of the total cost invoiced, amounting to EUR 237 000.
We identified ineligible costs for eight of the 25 projects in the sample for the MFF heading 3, which were reimbursed by the Commission.
Box 1.1 — Examples of errors in the reimbursement of costs of a project under the MFF heading 3 "Security and citizenship of the Union" The Commission has been aware of the difficulties of public bodies in complying with eligibility rules applicable to staff costs for public bodies (who hire other personnel to replace the staff in their ordinary activities).
For this reason, from 2011 onwards, the Commission amended the eligibility rules applicable to staff of public bodies, taking advantage of the flexibility provided for in the implementing rules of the Financial Regulation.
Therefore, the non-eligible costs found by the Court in the grant mentioned above (personnel costs for staff in public bodies, which do not grant compensation) would now be considered eligible.

10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/29 REPLY OF THE COMMISSION OF THE COMMENTS OF THE HOFES There are many forms of corrective measures with different effects 1.30.
Our study of "mistakes and corrections" aims to shed light on the complex mechanisms of implementing and recording corrective measures and to explain the various ways in which these mechanisms can be applied to our audit work.
In some areas of expenditure, new instruments will be available to the Commission when expenditure is incurred for the new programming period.
Corrective measures 1.31.
We seek to take account of corrective measures taken by the Member States and the Commission in the run-up to the payment or our investigation.
We also take note of corrections that take place after our audit announcement. However, we cannot reduce the estimated error rate whenever the audit itself triggers the corrective action (24).
We review the application of these corrections (including the recovery of beneficiaries and corrections at project level) and, where appropriate, adjust the calculation of the error rate.
However, the impact of the corrective measures varies considerably depending on the expenditure area and on the corrective action.
1.32.
The Commission and the authorities of the Member States had applied corrective measures for 24 of the operations examined in a sample in 2014 which had a direct impact on the operation concerned and were relevant for our calculations.
These corrective measures led to a reduction of our estimated error rate by 1.1 percentage points (2013: 1.6 percentage points), representing around 1.6 billion euros.
Changes in the number of operations concerned and the impact on our estimated error rate are not an indication that the corrective measures are more or less effective: as these measures apply to a relatively small proportion of our sample, fluctuations are to be expected from year to year.
1.30.
The Commission considers that the Court's annual representative error rate should be considered in the context of the Commission's corrective capacity in the various annual activity reports and the synthesis report.
The Financial Regulation requires appropriate consideration of the risks associated with the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions, taking into account the multi-annual nature of the control systems and the nature of the payments.
1.31.
Joint response to paragraphs 1.31 and 1.32: In the 2014 synthesis report (COM(2015) 279 final), the Commission estimated the future impact of correction mechanisms to be EUR 2.7 billion, corresponding to 1.9% of payments from the EU budget.
For a breakdown of the figures by policy area, see Table 1 in the synthesis report.
The Commission underlines that all types of financial corrections and recoveries exclude illegal expenditure from the reimbursement from the EU budget (see explanatory note 6 on the financial statements).

COMMENTS FROM THE COURT 1.35.
The corrective measures discussed in this section of the annual report shall also include the work of the Member States' authorities and the recoveries made by the national authorities and the Commission.
C 373/32 Official Journal of the European Union REPLY OF THE COMMISSION 10.11.2015 THE REMARKS OF THE HOFES The impact of corrective measures is largely tangible at the time when the Commission accepts the expenditure 1.36.
All relevant sectoral regulations in the area of shared management contain rules on the primary controls to be carried out by national authorities or reductions in the amounts claimed by the final beneficiaries before the expenditure is certified.
Sometimes the national authorities also agree to reduce or delete certain costs which appear constantly in the declarations due to errors with long-term effects (such as ongoing payments under a contract in which an error with regard to the procurement rules exists).
Such adjustments may have a measurable impact on the amount of refund requested for individual projects or on the aid paid to individual farmers, and the correction will then help to reduce our estimated error rate.
1.37.
In the area of direct and indirect management, the ‘recoveries' covered by the Commission, inter alia, consist in the deduction of ineligible amounts in the case of cost applications before the payment is authorised.
The eligibility of the amounts shall be established on the basis of the examination of the file of the available documents or on the basis of the results of the checks carried out (see also Figure 1.7).
This also allows us to reduce our estimated error rate.
Conformity decisions ("financial corrections") are often made on a flat-rate basis.
Generally speaking, they relate to system deficiencies rather than to errors at the level of the final beneficiaries.
In the rarest cases, they result in the recovery of the farmers concerned.
Such corrective measures are an incentive for Member States to improve their management and control systems.
They contribute to the legality and regularity of the operations at the level of the final beneficiaries if they lead to constant improvements in the cost statements accepted by the paying agencies (see boxes 1.2 and 1.3).
The Commission services also carry out recoveries ‘at source' by deducting ineligible expenditure (as determined in previous or current cost statements) from payments made.
1.38.
Financial corrections made by the Commission on agricultural expenditure are intended to protect the EU budget and are imposed on the Member States.
They do not directly result in the recovery of farmers, since the Commission does not pay the final beneficiaries directly, but the payments made by the Member States to farmers are reimbursed.
However, if these incorrect payments are identifiable as a result of the conformity clearance procedure, the Commission would expect the Member States to pursue them through recovery measures against the beneficiaries.
See answer to Box 1.3.
Payers implement conformity decisions by reducing future applications for reimbursement by the Commission for payments to farmers.
The Commission shall record the full amount paid out to farmers as expenditure, i.e. the adjustment shall not entail the reduction in the amount of the payments recorded.
Instead, the difference between payments to farmers and refunds to paying agencies is recorded as assigned revenue available to finance agricultural expenditure (26).
More than two thirds of the ‘financial corrections' in the cohesion area in 2014 consist of the replacement of new expenditure,...
1.40.
In the area of cohesion, ‘financial corrections', in more than two thirds of the total amount covered, are cases in which the authorities in the Member States reduce expenditure declared and replace it with new expenditure.
In some cases, "reductions" do not identify any concrete projects as being withdrawn.
Instead, Member States report additional projects and thus receive a de facto lower co-financing rate.
1.40. The Commission considers that any financial corrections, including those allowing Member States to contribute new projects and new expenditure to re-use the corrected amounts, protect the EU budget from unlawful expenditure and encourage Member States to recover from beneficiaries (and thus contribute to improving management and control systems).
Nevertheless, the deterrent effect of net financial corrections, in which Member States cannot reuse the corrected and recovered amounts and thus lose the funds, is certainly higher.
(26) For example, if an agricultural paying agency is subject to a 5% financial correction and makes payments of EUR 100 million to farmers, the Commission will reimburse EUR 95 million, but the Commission, for its part, will record expenditure of EUR 100 million, which will be offset by assigned revenue of EUR 5 million.
C 373/34 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 REPLY OF THE COMMISSION OF THE COMMENTS OF THE HOFES... while net corrections are less frequent 1.41.
If a replacement is not possible, the corrections for the Member State concerned will result in a loss of EU funds(27).This case, although relatively rare, may occur if Member States are unable to provide sufficient eligible expenditure and if a replacement is no longer possible (28) or permitted (29).
The Commission anticipates that, as a result of amendments to the legislation, net corrections will be applied more widely in the future. 1.41.
Following the example of the agricultural sector, the legislator has decided to apply a similar mechanism of net financial corrections for the 2014-2020 programming period to cohesion policy.
This will give Member States an additional incentive to prevent or detect and remedy serious deficiencies in the management and control systems before the financial statements are sent to the Commission.
Otherwise, and if serious deficiencies continue to be identified by the Commission or the Court after the financial statements have been sent, the Commission must make net financial corrections under the conditions laid down in the relevant regulations, which means that the funds have been lost to the Member State.
The Commission also considers that, under shared management, all financial corrections and recoveries, irrespective of the method of implementation, have a negative impact on national budgets.
In order to avoid a loss of EU funding, the Member State must replace non-eligible expenditure with additional eligible operations.
This means that the Member State, with its national budget, must bear the financial consequences of the loss of EU co-financing of expenditure deemed to be ineligible, provided that it does not recover the amounts from the individual beneficiaries.
(27) Either as a reduction in payments or as a return to the EU budget leading to assigned revenue (see Figure 2.2).
(28) After completion of the programmes.
(29) In the event of disagreement between Member States and the Commission (see point 1.25(b) of the 2012 annual report).
10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union REPLY OF THE COMMISSION C 373/35 OF THE REMARKS OF THE HOFES In 2014, the Commission and the Member States applied all these forms of corrective measures 1.42.
Box 1.2-1.4 shows different types and effects of corrective measures. Box 1.2 — Example of improvement of management and control systems — Greece: adjustment of the area identification system The Commission has taken measures to improve the identification of agricultural parcels (LPIS) system, which serves as the basis for payments to agricultural holdings, such as the single payment scheme (the largest single EU expenditure scheme).
This process took place at various stages and resulted in the ‘Eligible permanent grassland' in the Greek LPIS falling from 3.6 million hectares in 2012 to 1.5 million hectares in October 2014.
Non-legislative applications for ‘permanent grassland', which is not eligible for EU aid, has been a key factor in our estimated error rate for ‘natural resources' for several years.
We took into account the impact of adjustments in respect of individual payments made to final beneficiaries, which were the subject of our sample of operations of the EAGF and the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD).
Another effect is that the paying agency rejected many non-eligible applications, which resulted in the corresponding expenditure falling out of our sample.
Box 1.2 — Example of improving management and control systems — Greece: cleaning up the area identification system Other examples of the positive impact of action plans are given by the Court in Chapter 7.
Action plans are implemented whenever deemed necessary and the Commission monitors their implementation with great care and reports on the corrective actions taken in the annual activity report of the Directorate-General for Agriculture and Rural Development.
The area identification system shall prevent beneficiaries from claiming claims for land which does not exist or which does not meet the eligibility criteria or for land for which claims have already been made by another beneficiary.
If properly implemented, it is a very effective tool to reduce the error rate.
It covers 75% of CAP expenditure.
As the Annual Activity Report 2014 of the Directorate-General for Agriculture and Rural Development shows, the error rates for area-related payments are lower than for other measures.
C 373/36 Official Journal of the European Union REPLY OF THE COMMISSION 10.11.2015 DE COMMENTS FROM THE HOFES Box 1.3 — Example of corrections resulting from conformity clearance procedures (30) — Conformity Decision 47 and its consequences for French farmers In 2014, France accepted an adjustment of EUR 1.1 billion (984 million for the EAGF and EUR 94 million for the EAFRD)(31).
The national authorities stated that this would have no impact on farmers and that the amount would be disputed from the national budget.
In previous annual reports, we pointed out that such a procedure does not encourage beneficiaries to correct errors (32).
The main reasons for the correction were shortcomings in the LPIS/GIS (695 million euros) and the exceedance of the ceiling for payment entitlements, resulting in excessive payments to farmers (141 million euros).
Another reason was, albeit to a lesser extent, violations of the cross compliance obligation of timely notification of movements of animals (123 million euros).
All these reasons are related to payments made between 2009 and 2013.
No adjustment was made for 2014, and the non-compliance with the ceiling for payment entitlements and the non-eligible areas covered by the LPIS of France contributed 0.3 percentage points to our estimated error rate for ‘Natural resources' this year.
Box 1.3 — Example of adjustments resulting from conformity clearance procedures — Conformity Decision 47 and its consequences for French farmers Under shared management, Member States are responsible for ensuring that the control systems function properly.
The EUR 1.1 billion financial correction will be repaid to the EU budget in three annual instalments (2015, 2016 and 2017).
The Commission notes that, due to the nature of the conformity clearance procedure that applies ex-post, it is very rare, after the clearance of the accounts of the year and after a counter-dicatory phase in which the Member State concerned is able to make its own reasoning and calculation, that a financial correction is already decided in the following year of the expenditure in question.
An ongoing conformity clearance procedure will protect the EU budget for 2014.

(42) The Directorate-General for Health and Food Safety (DG SANTE) has lifted its reservation regarding the programmes for the eradication and monitoring of animal diseases in the food and feed policy area.

(44) Report on discharge in respect of the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2013, Section III — Commission and executive agencies 2014/2075 (DEC) (A8-001/2015).
THE COMMENTS OF THE COURT 1.50.
In accordance with the request from the discharge authority, the Commission further developed its internal guidance (45) on the presentation of information in Annual Activity Reports in 2014.
The Directors-General are now to present an 'average detected error rate' (46).
The application of this error rate to the total payments of the year leads to the calculation of the ‘risk amount'(47).
The synthesis report shows this amount together with the estimate of the future correction capacity of the ex post controls carried out by the Commission. The Commission acknowledges that the expenditure is substantially affected by errors...
1.51.
In the 2014 synthesis report, the Commission identifies the ‘risk amount' as the range of EUR 3.7 to 5 billion.
This represents between 2,6 % and 3,5 % of the payments for 2014(48) covered by the synthesis report.
These figures show that total expenditure is significantly affected by errors.... however, points to the estimated impact of future corrections 1.52.
The 2014 synthesis report provides an estimated total of estimated future corrections (correction capacity).
On the basis of the corrections recorded during the last six years(49), the Commission estimates that in the coming years it will be able to "identify and correct errors in the total amount of around EUR 2700 million" (50).
(45) Standing Instructions for the 2014 Annual Activity Reports (SEC(2014) 553).
(46) This is the error rate detected or estimated at the time of payment (not the residual error rate), i.e. without adjustment due to subsequently corrected errors.
